fields.headline: Chagal Chagal
fields.standfirst:
Rocket @ St John's Hall
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Rocket @ St John's Hall
****
fields.body:
The Belarus artist Marc Chagall died in a lift, half way between the earth and sky: an appropriate place for a visionary inspired by ideas of flight. Other influences were memories of his Jewish upbringing in his hometown of Vitebsk.

In this affecting piece from the Belarus State Theatre, Chagall's final moments are recreated in a welter of images, fragments of dreams and half forgotten phrases. As his life slips away he returns to its beginnings.

In some ways this show should be entirely inaccessible for a British audience. It is performed in Belarussian, the synopsis is no great help, and it assumes that everyone is familiar with Chagall's work. But it works, not least because its spare, measured, distinctly eastern European modernist style is tempered by the welling emotion of Jewish folk memory and dance.

Not knowing what is being said means that you end up relating to the piece on an imagistic level. Tables transform into picture frames, whitewashed buildings fly across the air, Chagall's lovers, family and rivals metamorphose like ghosts in faded photos or old paintings, captured forever at that moment when the past meets the future and which is now lost forever.

 Till Saturday. Box office: 0131-228 7555.

fields.headline: Do you believe in e-quality?
fields.standfirst:
Work Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: On the face of it, the new economy looks like a nirvana for women. The skills required for success are cerebral (ideas generation, IT knowledge) or semi-social (networking, team-building).
fields.body:
On the face of it, the new economy looks like a nirvana for women. The skills required for success are cerebral (ideas generation, IT knowledge) or semi-social (networking, team-building). And the entrepreneurial spirit required to jump the "not com" old economy corporate ship and establish a start-up seems to reside in the X chromosome: US women are in the forefront of new business creation and British women are not far behind.

The technological slaying of distance, with websites and email allowing new economy recruits to work as and where they please, is particularly helpful to women trying to marry paid work with childcare. Throw in some glamour in the shape of Martha Lane Fox and the feminisation of the new economy seems complete. Women sick of banging their heads against the glass ceilings of the old economy can give it up as a bad job and join the flexible, gender-neutral new one instead.

Except things aren't quite as they seem. The surface impression of a new dawn of gender equality does not fit with the reality of the changing economy. Helen Wilkinson, a writer on gender and technology, argues that a harsher dot.com environment means women are struggling to establish themselves in start-ups. "The new economy looks good for women on paper - technology allows new ways of working, creating the potential for better work-life balance," she says. "But start-ups require a huge initial investment of time and energy, meaning long working hours. The dot.com culture is still quite male-oriented and in a climate in which investors are cautious, there is a tendency to go with safe options."

Wilkinson points out that the venture capital firms backing dot.com start-ups are dominated by men; the specific IT skills required for website building and e-commerce are still being acquired by more men than women - indeed the number of women applying to study IT has dropped slightly. And while the image of the new economy worker logging on from home seems attractive, the truth is less futuristic: a study by the Institute for Employment Studies found that women telecommuters were three times more likely than men to be interrupted by children.

Perhaps most importantly, the working culture of dot.coms is more macho than the old economy, with the possible exception of City trading rooms. Start-ups operate in a go-go, flat-out climate and the line between success and failure is often so narrow - and the gains from stocks options so great - that working all the hours God sends is entirely rational. Far from prefiguring a feminine future, dot.commery is fuelled by testosterone and takeaways, with friends and lovers found in the late-night office and "start-up sex" made more exciting by the shared sense of pace and risk in many e-ventures.

In the US, there are signs of a backlash against start-up craziness. The initiatives to reduce pressure on employees speak volumes about the levels of insanity. Justin Kitch, founder of Homestead.com, decided to rebalance his life when he got married, cutting back his office hours to just 60 and putting in, on top, a mere 20 at home. Charlie Kim, head of Next Jump, which produces online college guides, told Fast Company magazine he was cracking down on long hours by banning sleeping in the office and removing all beds and futons.

On this side of the pond, too, the atmosphere of dot.coms remains relentlessly macho. Employees boast of pulling "all-nighters" - an activity once reserved for just-in-time essay production at university.

Of course, it is not just men who are adopting a work-all-hours approach - Lane Fox herself rises at dawn, rushes around until dusk and puts in more work in between than most of us manage in a week. Which is fine until children appear on the scene because women still have most of the childcare responsibilities and the dot.com culture is about as family-unfriendly as you can get.

Without relinquishing their command of the old economy, men are colonising the new one, too. Far from narrowing the gap between men and women, the rise of the dot.com is in danger of widening it. So much for e-quality.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

fields.headline: Nicholas Parsons Happy Hour
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Over the Road
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance Over the Road
****
fields.body:
Adam Hills bounds onstage just as a mobile phone goes off in the front row. Hills seizes the phone and holds it up to the mike to prove this is all authentic. The poor guy at the other end gets the shock of his life. Hills barks down the phone: "Would you like to speak to Nicholas Parsons?"

"Hello," says the guffawing Parsons. "This IS Nicholas Parsons. Are you Dreamtime Escorts?" The audience erupts.

This is just one howling moment in the venerable Parsons' unscripted Happy Hour. Intended as an hour of "cocktails and chat", the show varies depending on the quality of the guests. Here, they are superb. Hills is a fabulous stand-up. Irish comic John Maloney has some terrific one-liners (and the cruellest jokes ever about the Queen Mum, a "six-fingered inbred beast"). Andy Parsons makes a willing stooge for his namesake's witty banter. It's a shock to hear him use the word "arsehole", but at 78, the great man has lost little of his sharpness.

"Any questions for Andy?" asks Nicholas, having amiably demolished his guest. Someone pipes up: "Andy, why are you on this show?" Priceless, although it might not always be this good.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: Well worth the trouble
fields.standfirst:
Salvator Rosa
Bloomsbury Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Salvator Rosa
Bloomsbury Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
In an admirably enterprising venture, Dorset Opera has staged the first performances in Britain of Salvator Rosa by Carlos Gomes, firstly in its home base of Sherborne and now at the Bloomsbury Theatre. A resurgence of interest in the works of Gomes is currently brewing: later this year the UK premiere of Lo Schiavo arrives at Sadler's Wells from Brazil. Both that and Salvatore Rosa are presented as part of a festival commemorating the 500th anniversary of the discovery of Brazil, Gomes's native land.

Not that anybody would ever guess that the music of Salvator Rosa was written by a Brazilian. In this production a huge map of Italy hung from the ceiling during the second act - just in case anyone needed reminding. Gomes (1836-96) spent most of his working life in Milan, and assimilated the fashionable operatic style with more flair than most of his native Italian counterparts. In fact, much of the score of Salvator Rosa could almost (but not quite) have been by Verdi, who, recognising the imitation, was duly flattered and, in a rare display of praise, pronounced Gomes "a genius".

Gomes knew his craft, and Salvator Rosa contains all the elements necessary for a good night out at an Italian opera: a supposedly true story, complete with tyrannical duke, sensitive artist, revolution, forbidden love, a mad scene, murder and, finally, suicide. Among the more memorable numbers - and there are several - is an aria for the hero that one can easily imagine being belted out by Carreras in a football stadium. Perhaps most effective is the penultimate scene, a confrontation in a convent between the Duke and his daughter against an aural backdrop of pious bells and church organ.

When Gomes's usually keen dramatic sense flags, a few judicious cuts in the score would work wonders. The opera's uneven pace wasn't helped in this production by Michael Beauchamp's straightforward and rather unimaginative direction.

The Dorset Opera principals were all professionals. Fernando del Valle's performance in the title role was marred by a tendency to sing under the note, but there were strong showings from the sopranos Andrea Baker and Lisa Livingstone, as well as from Michail Milanov as the Duke. The orchestra was a little rough round the edges, but the musical performance that conductor Patrick Shelley drew out was spirited and alive. A creditable reading of an opera that was well worth the trouble of resurrecting.

fields.headline: Blues can be fun
fields.standfirst:
Shawn Lee
Monarch, London
****
fields.trailText:
Shawn Lee
Monarch, London
****
fields.body:
It takes a minute to realise that the man with the unruly hair, baggy T-shirt and grin isn't the guitar tech, but Shawn Lee, the star of the show. He may not look pampered and preened, but he knows what he's capable of. "I'm the enchanted wizard of rhythm," he announces, throwing his head back with a cackle to rival Janis Joplin's.

As he slowly builds the vibrant blues of Kill Somebody you can see what he means. Savouring each note, body moving in time, he infuses dark stories of Jack Daniels and working girls with a joyful exuberance, loving every minute. Robert Johnson never looked like this.

But this is a blues-jazz fusion for the dance generation. Floating sees the strong beats of drummer Joe Cooper emphasising Lee's fantastic voice, one minute a fragile falsetto, the next a husky, chocolatey drawl. He's from Wichita, Kansas, but has a lot in common with Minneapolis boy Prince in versatility and the desire to push boundaries.

If you thought the blues was a forgotten genre, something that is an inspiration for today's artists rather than an ongoing musical force, Lee will prove you wrong. In a forceful rasp he declares: "I'm still floating, although you try to drown me in bullshit."

While he's on stage he conveys a happy-go-lucky image - chatting to the audience, admitting that an impressively held note wasn't as easy as it looked. Even so, it's a defiant performance. Dodge sees Lee throwing his head back, tongue out, shaking his hair furiously like Ozzy Osbourne, while Eight Million Ways to Die is a seaside waltz of a song, spinning and turning loveliness, but revealing something nasty behind the faded glamour. Introducing Happiness, from upcoming album Monkey Boy, Lee comments: "It's not a song about death per se, but it could be if you want it to," before the bossa nova beats get funky and Lee sings of fleeting contentment.

But after darkness comes light, with Lee offering a copy of the new album to anyone who can name the four songs on his I Can't Save You EP released earlier this year, a request greeted with embarrassed silence. Finally he's reduced to asking if anyone can name the second song of the set. As someone down the front shouts it out and then admits to reading it from the set-list, hilarity sets in. "Well, you can kiss my ass," Lee laughs, proving that the blues can be fun after all.

fields.headline: New front opens against Standard
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Insurance group Standard Life yesterday came under attack from a second internet-based campaign group pressing for it to convert to a public company and pay windfalls to members.
fields.body:
Insurance group Standard Life yesterday came under attack from a second internet-based campaign group pressing for it to convert to a public company and pay windfalls to members.

The emergence of the Standard Life Alliance for Members, or Slam - which is calling for a special meeting to be held to vote on demutualisation - came on the day the company met businessman Gordon Hart, who on Monday announced he would also be seeking to persuade it to hold a fresh vote on shedding its mutual status.

Slam is run by Edinburgh business consultant and long-term policyholder Mike Anthony, who said he had founded the group following complaints from members about "alleged irregularities" in the way the last ballot was carried out.

Its intervention means Standard Life faces a two-pronged challenge to its status as Europe's biggest mutual insurer less than two months after it defeated a conversion attempt led by a Monaco-based Australian, Fred Woollard.

However, the insurer will at least be cheered by the news that Mr Anthony and Mr Hart are not only refusing to work together but also appear to be at loggerheads over the best way forward.

Mr Hart, who is the chairman of the internet-based Members' Rights Campaign, said his group "does not endorse" the resolutions proposed by Mr Anthony and that it had attempted to persuade him to stop his campaign.

Slam has drawn up nine resolutions on its www.a-way-worldwide.com website, including one calling on it to "take steps to demutualise the company". Mr Anthony said he had already received more than 70 completed "requisitions" from supporters.

Under Standard Life's rules, a resolution can be put forward to a special meeting if it has at least 50 supporters.

Mr Anthony said the present Standard Life board "cannot be trusted", and added that the company would be better demutualising "so outside parties can keep an eye on what the board is doing".

He denied that he was a carpetbagger, and said that if the company were to provide satisfactory answers to his questions his group may come down in favour of its staying a mutual organisation.

Mr Hart has said there should be an "unbiased referendum" on demutualisation early next year. He claimed the 2.3m member policyholders could receive windfalls averaging almost £8,000 if it were to float on the stock market.

Following yesterday's meeting between Standard Life and Mr Hart, at which he presented it with 22 questions, a spokesman for the insurer said it had had a "cordial and constructive" discussion.

fields.headline: Dive Urgence
fields.standfirst:
Continental Shifts at St Brides
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Continental Shifts at St Brides
***
fields.body:
Unlikely though it sounds, circus company Dark Horse have created a show based on socialist historian Eric Hobsbawm's vision of a society in the new millennium. The result isn't enirely convincing, but you've got to cheer this group for injecting ideas into juggling and taking British circus into the theatre.

Sequences that illustrate The Rise and Fall of Great Ideologies and The Generalised Improvement in Living Standards jostle with two men doing oral juggling who are alone worth the price of admission. The idea of circus as a force for social change is agreeably mad, and all this charming, effective piece needs is a sharper script to hold it together.

 Till Saturday. Box office: 0131-226 5138.

fields.headline: Alcina
fields.standfirst:
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
*****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Edinburgh Festival Theatre
*****
fields.body:
Stuttgart State Opera's modern staging of Handel's Alcina is visually striking, vocally outstanding and dramatically intoxicating. The sorceress Alcina's realm is a voluptuously ornate but dilapidated salon, in whose centre is an enormous gilded frame that acts as both mirror and magic portal.

Right from Alcina's entrance, sex is in the air. Catherine Naglestad sings her first aria in the arms of her beloved, Alice Coote's Ruggiero, in a scene of feverish, highly charged eroticism. The other characters can only watch, half bewitched, half shocked by Alcina's brazen sensuality. The relationship between her and Ruggiero is critical to the opera's drama, and in Naglestad and Coote this production has a magnificently matched pairing. Alcina is slowly reduced to the status of a mere mortal by her love for Ruggiero, as he rejects her in favour of Bradamante, his wife-to-be in the outside world.

Naglestad gives a vivid portrayal of Alcina's gradual emotional collapse in her string of violently contrasting arias in the second part. She lurches with raw terror from sorrowful defeat - in an ice-cold monody, supported by a solo violin - to impassioned revenge, as she comes to know the torments of human love. Coote's singing of Ruggiero's dissolution as the first part progresses is no less psychologically penetrating. Caught between duty and passion, Ruggiero loses confidence in all his feelings. Everywhere seems to be deception and duplicity.

The other characters also spend the opera trying to escape from the power of their passions in Alcina's realm. Rolf Romei's Oronte becomes a cross-dressing temptress in his first-act aria; Catriona Smith's Morgana finds herself in love with the disguised Bradamante. But to regain their liberty and humanity, the other characters degenerate into precisely the bestiality of which they accuse Alcina, and murder her. The final chorus in this production reverses the emotional polarities of the whole opera: singing about their new-won freedom, the humans fight, flirt and fornicate. It is only Alcina who finds her humanity and escapes from illusion to truth.

Jossi Wieler and Sergio Morabito's direction is unflinching in its exploration of the complex core of Handel's drama. Only Alan Hacker's conducting and the energetic but unforgiving playing of the Stuttgart State Orchestra are at odds with the incisiveness of the rest of the production.

 Till tomorrow. Box office: 0131-473 2000.

Alcina is slowly reduced to the status of a mere mortal by her love for Ruggiero, as he rejects her in favour of Bradamante, his wife-to-be in the outside world. Naglestad gives a vivid portrayal of Alcina's gradual emotional collapse in her string of violently contrasting arias in the second part. She lurches with raw terror from sorrowful defeat - in an ice-cold monody, supported by a solo violin - to impassioned revenge, as she comes to know the torments of human love. Coote's singing of Ruggiero's dissolution as the first part progresses is no less psychologically penetrating. Caught between duty and passion, Ruggiero loses confidence in all his feelings. Everywhere seems to be deception and duplicity. The other characters also spend the opera trying to escape from the power of their passions in Alcina's realm. Rolf Romei's Oronte becomes a cross-dressing temptress in his first-act aria; Catriona Smith's Morgana finds herself in love with the disguised Bradamante. But to regain their liberty and humanity, the other characters degenerate into precisely the bestiality of which they accuse Alcina, and murder her. The final chorus in this production reverses the emotional polarities of the whole opera: singing about their new-won freedom, the humans fight, flirt and fornicate. It is only Alcina who finds her humanity and escapes from illusion to truth. Jossi Wieler and Sergio Morabito's direction is unflinching in its exploration of the complex core of Handel's drama. Only Alan Hacker's conducting and the energetic but unforgiving playing of the Stuttgart State Orchestra are at odds with the incisiveness of the rest of the production.  Till tomorrow. fields.headline: At this price?  Lastminute.com
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Has Lastminute.com finally turned the corner? Shares in Britain's highest profile dot.com climbed 20.5p to 182p yesterday as the market digested its acquisition of French online travel agency Degriftour. For investors who bought in at the flotation price of 380p and have seen the shares fall steadily it was a rare day for optimism.
fields.body:
Has Lastminute.com finally turned the corner? Shares in Britain's highest profile dot.com climbed 20.5p to 182p yesterday as the market digested its acquisition of French online travel agency Degriftour. For investors who bought in at the flotation price of 380p and have seen the shares fall steadily it was a rare day for optimism.

Analysts are broadly positive about the French deal, but then the analysts who cover Lastminute are broadly positive about it anyway. Those that don't follow Lastminute tend to ignore it simply because they do not believe it has a viable business model.

Analysts say that the company has paid very little for Degriftour - based on its own rating - and has attracted a strong management team to boot. About £100m of cash remains in the bank - probably enough to see it through to profitability.

Valuing Lastminute.com on fundamentals alone remains very difficult. Revenues are still very small, losses very large. By buying Degriftour it has taken a significant chunk out of its cash reserves.

However, it is now potentially a much stronger company with a much greater presence in Europe. If Lastminute's founders can manage the Degriftour integration they will have pulled off a coup. But as QXL will tell you, in light of its own problems with German partner Ricardo.de, it is not always an easy task.

Lastminute also needs to introduce the new version of its website as soon as possible. The current version is painfully slow and puts off many potential customers. The improved version is six weeks behind schedule.

A successfully enlarged Lastminute, complete with Degriftour and new technology is a much more attractive proposition. But until investors can actually log on and experience the company's progress for themselves the shares are no better than a hold.

fields.headline: Barclays opens African windows
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: Barclays is to turn some of its branches into access points for adventures in cyberspace.
fields.body:
Barclays is to turn some of its branches into access points for adventures in cyberspace.

The new internet centres are not being opened in Britain, however, where the threat of 100 more branch closures has been raised following the bank's takeover of Woolwich, but in Africa where it has 250 branches across 12 countries.

Through a deal with internet service provider Africa Online, which is backed by London stock market listed African Lakes, Barclays will next month open three pilot centres in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, with a view to opening centres across Africa.

"The internet in Africa is very much perceived as a window on the world," said Owen Woodley, head of change management management at Barclays. But, the cost of logging on from home is prohibitive for many Africans.

A PC can cost five times as much to buy as in Britain while internet service providers charge as much as $70 a month. Barclays is considering allowing its 1m customers across the continent to pay preferential rates compared to non-customers.

Barclays, which is spending £250,000 on the pilot scheme, will provide advice from experts for users of the internet service which is to be separately branded.

Africa Online has internet centres across Africa under its etouch brand. The operation with Barclays will be more upmarket, with higher grade technology such as flat-screen computers and better telephone lines.

Barclays, which recently suffered some technical glitches with its online bank in Britain, will eventually start internet banking in Africa but for the time being the internet "cafes" will provide access to email and web browsers.

The bank claims to be Britain's biggest internet bank with more than 1m online customers.

fields.headline: The Bicycle Bridge
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance 2
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance 2
****
fields.body:
A city under siege, caught up in civil war isn't the most promising context for a surreal treat, but in the smart hands of the Rejects Revenge Theatre Company this scenario becomes a richly comic, darkly bizarre prospect. Maniacally told, with more than a nod to postmodern playfulness, this is like Calvino on speed; Umberto Eco meets Fawlty Towers after one too many ice lollies.

The story - an attempt at liberation across a bridge by bicycle - is told in flashback, with plenty of reminders that we are being told a tale: "I'm not here of course", "they were getting ahead of themselves". Add in funny faces, silly songs, an accordion, a touch of classy farce (a man sent to slaughter an elephant to feed hungry citizens can't do it and comes back with two flamingo legs instead), a love story and some big themes connected to the cruelty of war, and you get something almost very marvellous.

Almost, because despite the crazy joy of the show and the three performances, it's all a little too self-referential. We might find the productions's fizzing energy intoxicating, but the smartness gets in the way of anything more than a rather detached, cold-hearted pleasure.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: Societies to share branches
fields.trailText: Two building societies yesterday announced a branch sharing agreement but stressed the move did not herald a merger.
fields.body:
Two building societies yesterday announced a branch sharing agreement but stressed the move did not herald a merger.

From early next year Britannia's 2.2m members will be able to pay in and withdraw money free of charge from savings and mortgage accounts at Yorkshire's 132 branches, and Yorkshire's 1.8m members will be able to use Britannia's 190-branch network.

Work on developing the necessary computer systems has already started.

The agreement comes amid fears that thousands of branches could close as banks offer more services through post offices, and follows the announcement that 100 branches will close with Barclays' acquisition of Woolwich.

The Yorkshire, Britain's third-largest society, has 80 branches in towns and districts where Britannia does not have a presence; Britannia, the second-largest society, has 135 branches in areas where the Yorkshire does not.

"Sharing our branch network is a practical way of enhancing the benefits we offer," said Yorkshire chief executive David Anderson.

fields.headline: Weill's tricky concerto
fields.standfirst:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/Vanska
Royal Albert Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/Vanska
Royal Albert Hall, London
****
fields.body:
During the course of the various Kurt Weill retrospectives that have featured strongly in concert schedules over the last year, one of the composer's best works hasn't surfaced quite as frequently as one might expect, namely the Concerto for Violin and Wind Instruments. Written in 1924, it is by far the most popular of Weill's orchestral works. The Proms have redressed the balance a bit with a blistering performance from the great Dutch violinist Isabelle Van Keulen and the BBC Scottish Orchestra under its Principal Conductor Osmo Vanska.

It's a tricky piece to get right, its detractors arguing that a preponderance of influences leads to an inherent lack of stylistic unity. The Concerto does, it is true, nod in the direction of Schoenberg, Stravinsky and Busoni (Weill's teacher) before the snappy sardonicism of the mature composer emerges, but here one is struck by its homogeneity of tone and the impressive gradation of its emotional content. It's inherently bleak, a possible reflection of Weill's angst at the emergence of the political far-Right (Mussolini had just gained power in Italy). The wind ensemble seems permanently about to mutate into a military band, its arrogant trumpetings goading the soloist into a response which is by turns shocked and enraged. Lyricism is brief, humour scarce.

Written for the Hungarian virtuoso Joseph Szigeti (he never played it), it makes formidable demands on the soloist. Van Keulen, dark-toned, vehemently expressive, is superlative throughout, while the BBC Scottish Orchestra's wind ensemble perform with an uncompromising, steely grittiness.

Vanska flanked the work with two of the 20th century's great exercises in colouristic tone painting, Ravel's Mother Goose and Stravinsky's Petrushka. Ravel's fairy-tale suite was swathed in a limpid, tremulous sexuality, its sudden flashes of darkness hinting at burgeoning adolescence. Petrushka was spectacular, though Vanska didn't always quite get to the heart of it in a performance that veered closer to pathos than genuine tragedy. The soul-shattering isolation of Petrushka in his cell didn't quite tear you in two as it should, though the fairground scenes, spiky and intensely driven, swirled with an exhilarating, Dionysian clamour.

fields.headline: Commons 'misled' over Post Office
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The government has been accused of misleading the House of Commons over the future of the Post Office.
fields.body:
The government has been accused of misleading the House of Commons over the future of the Post Office.

The row centres on comments made by competition minister Alan Johnson to the trade and industry select committee in July which indicated that discussions were going well with the banks over establishing a universal bank.

The minister's positive mood appeared misplaced when, within days, the British Bankers Association rejected the idea.

John Butterfill, a committee member and Conservative MP for Bournemouth West, said he would be raising the issue at the next committee meeting in October.

He said: "[The minister] certainly misled the committee. The only question left is whether he did so out of ignorance."

The universal bank is a government initiative to provide an independently branded current account backed by the big banks to those excluded from the banking system.

Mr Butterfill said he was "very worried" about the future of many rural post offices.

He said Mr Johnson had claimed there would be no preventable closures of more branches, and that this could partly be assured by the introduction of new initiatives such as the universal bank.

A DTI spokesman rejected the criticism, insisting that the universal bank concept was far from dead.

The DTI insisted that even if the universal bank proved an unworkable concept it would not change the outlook for rural post offices.

The department insisted that government money could still finance a banking scheme, but that a range of other initiatives - such as providing internet access, the payment of some state benefits and offering a range of other services from some of the 10,000 rural post offices - would help to re-establish their viability.

fields.headline: Colin Murphy
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Upstairs
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance Upstairs
****
fields.body:
There's nothing radical about Colin Murphy apart from his preposterous sideburns, but he is distinguishably good. Armed with a long black cable and a microphone, this Northern Irish maniac races through an hour of stand-up that never falls down. His delivery is immaculate, ultra-fast but never unintelligible. More infectiously, he has a knack of making each member of the audience feel like a friend, delivering pin-sharp observations in the form of shared confidences.

While the subjects he covers are predictable, the humour isn't. Murphy rants about everything from the problems in Irish athletics ("I'm not going anywhere until you put down that starting pistol") to how Cockneys are difficult to impress (Cockney on the Coliseum: "S'alright" - pause, scratch of the genitalia - "Could do with a roof"). There's a chunk of improvisation, which is perhaps understandable when you find an audience member called Verdum Swanson Moor, but Murphy never gives the impression that he is struggling to make up for a scarcity of material. Hilarious, although his mime piece illustrating an English person having sex could do untold damage to the nation's sexual health.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival review: If I Were Me

fields.headline: If I Were Me
fields.standfirst:
Assembly Rooms
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Assembly Rooms
***
fields.body:
"You wanna know why? I'll tell you why." So promises a face cream peddler in a New York drugstore, just one of the unlikely places Gay Marshall visits during this endearing dip into Songs and Angst of an American in Paris.

You wanna know why it works? I'll tell you why. Good tunes (Cole Porter, Noel Coward, Irving Berlin), simple format (singer about to go on stage takes a good look at her life), plus lots of cross-cultural funnies as American self-obsession meets Parisian hauteur. A tour guide tells some US tourists in Paris of their sartorial crimes; French customer service is shown to be a snooty contradiction in terms; we see auditions from the point of view of a 5ft tall 39-year old woman.

There's a little too much of the doubling theme, with Marshall giving herself a good talking to too often. She reminds us of her crisis through her hair: when it is up, it is up, and when it is down, it is down. It is never only half way up, because this is a show about polar opposites, harking back to the good old bad old days of musicals when everything seemed clear. Think about If I Were Me too hard afterwards and you might blush at its naivete. If I were you, I'd just enjoy the moment.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

fields.headline: Lawrence Weiner
fields.standfirst:
Inverleith House
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Inverleith House
***
fields.body:
Another cool, slight offering from Inverleith, this time in the form of text-based work by Californian artist Lawrence Weiner. He once said that art is always presentation, "never an imposition," and so it is here. Scraps of meditative words are written in charcoal letters on the walls, in Offline font (a blank line running through each character).

"Found due to its nature after any given time" is the main elliptical thrust, all illusion of precision (finding) and yet vacancy (at any given time). There are big, weird symbols on the walls too, a little like the male and female symbols in science. Wandering through the galleries is like being on a trail for meaning, one which erases itself as you approach. There's a military quality to the lettering and symbols too which gives the otherwise laid-back atmosphere an edge. That too erases itself pretty quickly.

Weiner is known for having placed phrases outside of institutional contacts (on beer-mats, escalators, songs) and the gallery tries to claim some radical points too because it is "sited within a public garden". So is Buckingham Palace. I'd like to see what Weiner would scribble on those walls.

 Till October 29. Details: 0131-248 2983.

webTitle: Workers of the world, stop moaning!

fields.headline: Workers of the world, stop moaning!
fields.standfirst:
It's more stressful, demanding and time-consuming than ever. At least, that's the latest line on work. But is it true? Evan Davis explodes a few popular myths

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's more stressful, demanding and time-consuming than ever. At least, that's the latest line on work. But is it true? Evan Davis explodes a few popular myths
fields.body:
In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread." When God felt wrathful, one of the worst of his punishments, in the case of the snake, the tree and the apple, was to condemn humankind to work. The primal curse today typically lasts 80,000 hours in a lifetime. That sounds like one hell of a punishment and in a sense it is. It consumes physical and mental energy, fills our conversation - and yet it takes up barely 12% of the average allotted span on earth. So is 80,000 hours a big number or not and how angry was God? Work is said to be in the throes of a massive upheaval, but compared with the past, how much of a revolution are we really seeing?

There's no job security

We may feel insecure but the idea that we have lost the common expectation of a job for life is a myth. Go back 100 years and uncertainty and casual employment were the norm. To some extent, it's a myth perpetuated by the memory the labour movement and trade unions have of their own history. Many developed on the strength of organising workers in, say, the coal industry or shipping and protecting members in those trades all their working lives. But then, as now, most people did different jobs for different employers. There is little evidence of a fall in job tenure which remains at between three and five years.

Lads get left behind

Unskilled young men are seen as the disaffected casualties of the modern economy - and they often have been. Before the first world war, there was great agitation about the "boy worker problem". Boys leaving school at 14 with few, if any, qualifications were drifting into jobs as messengers, for example, which left them time on their hands to loiter in the streets. Youth clubs and Scouts appeared around this time, in part in the hope that they could instil in the yobs some notion of civilisation. There is no evidence this generation grew up more degenerate than any other; whether saved by the Scouts, we can only guess.

Stress levels are rising

Unlikely. One in five of us now suffers from workplace stress, so we're told. But conditions in the past could be atrocious. The memory of the Depression encouraged some to take whatever work they could get, to stick with it and be thankful. Piece-rate payments and perpetual insecurity could leave workers anxious and under the cosh. There was not much recourse for bullying or sexual harassment, either - now the tribunal would beckon. If there is a rise in stress, it is often driven by ambition, or among select groups such as teachers who are subject to greater scrutiny than in the past.

We're all working harder

In fact, we have never had it so easy. At the beginning of the 20th century, children would typically start work at the age of 13 or 14 and stay there until 65 or older. Today it's normal for people to stay longer in full-time education and (the occasional bout of summer pint-pulling excepted) not enter the labour market until their early 20s, before retiring commonly by the age of 60. So the typical working life has shrunk from around 50 or 55 years to around 38 - a massive reduction.

Not only are our working lives shorter but so are our working hours. A hundred years ago, people would in all likelihood have been working a six-day week. That had come down to five and a half days by the middle of the 20th century and it is now down to five.

Those working days are shorter, too. After the first world war, they fell by around seven or nine hours per week, then fell again after the second world war from around 54 hours per week to 46 or 48; in the past 30 years or so there has been a steady decline from around 44 hours to around 37 today. The perception that we are working harder is often associated with progress in our career as we acquire increasing responsibility and seniority, rather than with any aggregate change across the economy.

Modern jobs? McJobs!

If McJobs are seen as our future, they are also our past. Services are not a modern invention: the last great surge in the service economy was in the late 19th century when there was a boom in pubs, similar to the revival of pubs, bars and the cappuccino economy today. It has been said that jobs in Indian restaurants now outnumber those in steel, mining and shipbuilding put together, and there has been a big change here. But it is not unprecedented. There was a swift retail expansion in the late Victorian era, too, with the first big movement towards working and buying in the high street. Regional financial centres began moving to London and northern manufacturing wealth was already being eclipsed by the south.

The modern domestic service boom was also prefigured about 100 years ago. There is some truth in the idea that more of us are becoming wedding video-makers, aromatherapists or one of the thousand other consultants as we seek out a specialist service niche. But specialisation has been around since Adam Smith in 1776. In the past you might have been a ponty-sticker, a doctor maker, a butt woman or maybe one of the 60 or 70 different and equally forgotten occupations listed in a turn-of-the-century census of the shoe-making trade alone.

Home-working is here

There is some evidence of an increase in teleworking (for instance in Finland) but not much. Rates in the UK are little changed; self-employment levels actually show a slight fall. To insist the brave new world is possible because of new technology is to forget that jobs from fur-pulling (plucking out the long hairs to make smoother pelts) to chain-making were carried out at home in the past. The latter, done in the back yard, was a woman's job because it could apparently be combined (goodness knows how) with childcare. Work and a home life of leisure were slowly separated over the centuries. If they do begin to merge again, it'll be a return to ways of old.

Our difficulty is to reach beyond the postwar imagery that informs most living memory of what work means. The longer sweep of history suggests that few trends in the labour market are new. And if in the future we fear a life without work, bear in mind a forecast by American economist Paul Krugman: the jobs that flourish will be the ones information technology can't foreseeably replace. So it's goodbye accountants and office workers, and welcome back... gardeners. God really was angry.

fields.headline: New York City Ballet Programme 1
fields.standfirst:
Edinburgh Playhouse
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Edinburgh Playhouse
***
fields.body:
It is 11 years since New York City Ballet last danced in the UK, yet British audiences have been seeing more of the company's prized George Balanchine repertoire than ever. Acknowledged as some of the great works of 20th-century art, Balanchine's ballets are being performed by more and more companies around the world.

One inevitable consequence of their popularity has been that they have suffered a certain internationalising slipperiness of style. We now take it for granted that the Kirov, for instance, will inflect Balanchine's choreography with a vernacular very different from the British, the French and certainly the Americans. So Edinburgh's coup in securing NYCB for the festival this year should have offered a rare reminder of how Balanchine looks when he is danced in his original idiom and by the company he created more than 50 years ago. However, on the disappointing evidence of Monday's opening night, it seems NYCB may be no more in touch with their founding genius than anybody else.

When the curtains opened on Agon (choreographed in 1957), the four male dangers commanding the stage did generate a frisson. Peter Boal, with his heroic swagger, and Jock Soto, with his square - almost loutish - grace, captured exactly the mix of court and ghetto that defines this masterpiece of acerbic dance wit. Rarely have I seen its atmosphere of competitive male display look so muscularly loaded. Wendy Whelan as the first female principal was more than a match for them. She pushed her movements to the same dynamic extremes of quiet tension and drastic force, and, in her duet with Soto, honed her style to a fine blade of lethal glamour. The tentacular lash of her leg as she whipped it up and around Soto's neck, the slow voluptuous malice with which she presented her body to him, were mesmerisingly, fabulously deadly.

Yet Maria Kowroski, the company's vaunted new prodigy, lacked the same killer instinct. Looking surprisingly weak in her torso, she rarely capitalised on the power of her long, lush body to articulate the drama of the choreography.

A similar lack of spark was evident in the other great Balanchine work of the evening, Symphony in C (1947). Here the female corps looked ragged and distracted, and, apart from Jennie Somogyi, the ballerinas rarely exploited their opportunities to glitter and impose. Again it was the men who dominated, especially the almost fanatically precise and elegant Nikolaj Hübbe, and Albert Evans, with his contrasting exuberant grandeur.

The middle work of the evening was Dances at a Gathering (1969) created by NYCB's other veteran choreographer, the late Jerome Robbins. It's a piece revered in the American canon, yet British audiences may wonder why, for Robbins's response to his chosen music (a series of Chopin piano pieces) is one of limp, pastel-sprigged whimsies. The choreography is arch and skippy and drifts indecisively around wisps of contrived emotion. Frustratingly, given the choreography's weakness, this was the work that displayed the most consistently assured dancing, especially from Hélene Alexopoulos, who shaped her movements with an impressive boldness, clarity and exotic colour.

Hopefully, as the dancers shake down into the season we'll see more of them live up to the legend that surrounds them.

 Further performances tomorrow and Saturday. Box office: 0131-473 2000.

Club Pleasance @ Potter Row
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Club Pleasance @ Potter Row
****
fields.body:
Reworked for the better since it was first seen in London last year, Shunt's show takes you into the skies and then drops you from a great height. It's based on the true story of the South American rugby team who, after crashing in the Andes, stayed alive by eating each other.

The company wallow in the macabre humour of this situation in a performance piece that celebrates the importance of ritual in our lives: the absurdity of the air safety announcement; the trolley dolly with her comforting offer of drinks and peanuts; the way that even when we are reduced to cannibalism we do it with the best of table manners.

From the moment you gather in the waiting room, Shunt get every detail right but skew reality with a cockeyed humour. The experience is genuinely horrifying: as the plane began to spiral downwards the person next to me began to hyperventilate.

Once the smoke clears and you've got over your initial sense of terror, the real horror begins. Shunt takes you to the top of a mountain where the survivors huddle in the wind and show you the end of civilisation. Very clever, very disturbing.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Branded by the hand of fate

fields.headline: Branded by the hand of fate
fields.standfirst: Everton's Abel Xavier is fired up by a sense of European injustice
fields.trailText: Ian Ross meets Everton's Abel Xavier and finds him fired up by a sense of European injustice.
fields.body:
Eclipsing the likes of Zinedine Zidane, Luis Figo and Paolo Maldini was never going to be easy but, credit where credit is due, the Everton utility player Abel Xavier left most of his contemporaries in the shade during a blistering Low Countries summer.

You can neither miss nor ignore Portugal's Mr Xavier - 6ft 5in, slim as an architect's pencil and dressed to kill. His entrance is enough to bring one of Liverpool's trendier waterside restaurants to a standstill - a feat more normally achieved by members of the city's soap opera and rock music fraternity.

If dying his hair, together with his finely manicured beard and moustache, peroxide blond at Euro 2000 was something of a PR masterstroke, the handball that effectively lost Portugal the semi-final (and his ensuing protests) has ensured that Xavier is now instantly recognisable at 200 paces.

The hair is easily explained away, but the handball is most certainly not. Time's tide may have washed away much of the hurt, but a sense of injustice continues to burn with almost frightening intensity inside a man who feels he was badly wronged.

"For the first time in many, many years, we were connected," he says. "For once Portugal was a team and not just a collection of individuals."

Having emerged as winners of Group A - ensuring Kevin Keegan's England were home before their postcards in the process - Xavier and his mates rolled over Turkey in the quarter-finals before moving on to Brussels to contest, with the world champions France, a place in the final. As Sylvain Wiltord attempted to settle the game with a golden goal, Xavier's hand intervened.

"You know, the question I ask now is, if it was so clear cut, why is it that everyone I meet continues to ask me whether or not it was handball?" he says. "It was just one person who was certain it was a penalty - just one person - but now everyone seems to have their doubts.

"I have seen it on television many, many times and I still cannot understand why it was given. As Wiltord shaped to shoot I was in a natural position to defend. I could not have moved my left hand to make contact with the ball because it was helping me maintain my balance.

"I did not intend to stop it. When he struck the ball I assumed it was going in. I was very surprised when it did make such firm contact with my hand. I remember that as I fell after the ball had touched me I was thinking: 'Oh God, I hope the referee doesn't think that was deliberate'. Unfortunately, after talking to the linesman, he did and it was a death sentence because Zidane was never going to miss from the penalty spot."

The protests that followed were to guarantee Xavier notoriety to go along with new-found fame. "We regret what happened. We regret our behaviour," said Xavier. "People should remember, though, that when you play football at that sort of level things like this will always happen. Every other team - England, France, Italy - would have done exactly the same as we did. We were expressing feelings in the heat of the moment."

Uefa did not concur and Xavier's punishment was a nine-month suspension from international and European club competition. Not that Xavier would have been treading the European stage this season with Everton, a club where he would like to think he has laid down roots after a career that had hinted at the nomadic.

"I had already played for several big clubs in various countries before joining Everton from PSV Eindhoven last season," Xavier says, referring to his spells with Parma and Benfica. "I have never moved on in search of money. If I leave a club it is to join a bigger one - to improve myself."

Whether or not his love affair with the city of Liverpool and all things scouse will eventually blossom into a lasting relationship remains to be seen, but for the time being at least the 27-year-old Xavier is a largely contented man.

"I love the city, the people and the club," he says. "When I got back from Euro 2000 people were stopping me in the street to ask why it was I wanted to leave. It was weird; I never, ever said that. I'm happy here." Nevertheless his future remains uncertain and he is unlikely to feature in Everton's opening game at Leeds on Saturday.

Oh, yes - the hair.

"As football players we have to accept we have a responsibility to the club, to the country and to the fans. Sometimes people think that we are easily manipulated individuals who do not have personalities. But I am an individual.

"Anyway, I like it the way it is. It was my talisman and my team's talisman."

webTitle: Ipswich's Icelandic swoop put on ice

fields.headline: Ipswich's Icelandic swoop put on ice
fields.trailText: Ipswich Town and Wimbledon are embroiled in a row over the future of Hermann Hreidarsson.
fields.body:
Ipswich Town and Wimbledon were embroiled in a row over the future of Hermann Hreidarsson last night, with Ipswich claiming to have bought the defender for a club-record £4m and Wimbledon insisting they had not even agreed a fee for the sale. The south London club, meanwhile, are lining up Everton's Richard Dunne as a possible replacement.

Ipswich announced yesterday that the 26-year-old Iceland centre-half would join at the end of the week subject to a medical.

The Premiership club said their chairman David Sheepshanks and Wimbledon's chief executive David Barnard had agreed a fee on Saturday by telephone and that personal terms had been settled with the player on Sunday before he flew to Iceland for tomorrow's friendly against Sweden.

"We are delighted that we have got a proven international player to boost our defence," said Sheepshanks, who negotiated Hreidarsson's contract along with the Ipswich manager George Burley.

Within hours, though, Barnard accused Ipswich of jumping the gun. "We have not yet accepted the offer they have made," he insisted. "They made an original bid which we rejected as unsatisfactory. They have since made a second offer, which we are now considering.

"Nothing can be done until Hermann returns [on Thursday] and I can tell you from experience that a week in football is a very long time indeed; anything can happen."

Despite Barnard's retort, Ipswich said they expected Hreidarsson to sign before their opening game at Tottenham on Saturday.

Meanwhile, the Everton manager Walter Smith yesterday told Wimbledon that £2.5m would secure Dunne's services. The centre-back is expected to travel to London today to discuss personal terms.

Smith will use his windfall to fund his bid for the Newcastle United striker Duncan Ferguson, who is poised to return to Everton less than two years after departing for Tyneside in an £8m deal. The former Scotland international is arguing with Newcastle over loyalty bonuses but is expected to undergo a medical today.

Everton have agreed an initial £3.75m fee plus an additional £1m when - or if - he features in 60 senior games.

Charlton have snapped up the Iran international Karim Bagheri from the Iranian club Piroozi for £400,000, potentially rising to £1.1m. As an attacking midfielder the 26-year-old scored 20 goals in qualifying for France 98, but can also operate as a sweeper.

Bradford City hope to complete the £1.5m signing of the Blackburn striker Ashley Ward in time for their opener at Liverpool on Saturday.

The Cardiff City striker Dai Thomas has been fined the maximum two weeks' wages for his part in the Euro 2000 riots. The 24-year-old was caught on camera as hundreds of supporters ran riot in Brussels before an England game.

"This is as near as we have come to letting a player go for non-playing matters," said Cardiff's chairman Steve Borley. "Clearly, his full apology went a long way towards our decisions."

Barcelona will take their summer spending to £48.5m today when the Spain striker Alfonso completes an £8m move from Real Betis.

The Cardiff City striker Dai Thomas has been fined the maximum two weeks' wages for his part in the Euro 2000 riots. The 24-year-old was caught on camera as hundreds of supporters ran riot in Brussels before an England game. "This is as near as we have come to letting a player go for non-playing matters," said Cardiff's chairman Steve Borley. "Clearly, his full apology went a long way towards our decisions." Barcelona will take their summer spending to £48.5m today when the Spain striker Alfonso completes an £8m move from Real Betis.

webTitle: The Pink slips into the sunset

fields.headline: The Pink slips into the sunset
fields.trailText: No matter what embarrassments Joe Royle and City suffer on the opening day of the Premiership against Charlton, Manchester will not be turning pink this Saturday evening - nor any other Saturday. The Pink is dead. Long live the Sunday Pink.
fields.body:
No matter what embarrassments Joe Royle and City suffer on the opening day of the Premiership against Charlton, Manchester will not be turning pink this Saturday evening - nor any other Saturday. The Pink is dead. Long live the Sunday Pink.

For decades the Football Pink Final of the Manchester Evening News has faithfully charted the ups and downs of the Blues and Reds and in its heyday, when websites were found only on the fringes of park ponds and Saturday night television reporting meant a talking head, The Pink was mandatory reading.

Students leaving the city for far-flung universities, polytechnics or teaching colleges demanded their mothers parcel up The Pink and send it on so that nothing was missed. Up to last weekend it was an institution, its glory faded but still much loved and cherished.

Now it is gone, buried a week before a particularly titillating season, with both City and United in the Premiership. It is bizarre timing.

And, even though the soccer fanatics of Greater Manchester have been promised a "fantastic new-look Sunday Pink", it will never be the same. For Saturday Pinks or Greens or Blues and occasionally Buffs are dangerous animals, produced on a tightrope, with the thrill of the chase from reporter to printing press to shop counter or street corner redolent of thinly disguised panic.

The first place to look is always the late scorers column, for a front-page headline proclaiming "Tense struggle for United" might disguise an 87th-, 88th- and 90th-minute hat-trick.

Football Finals are a modern marvel, with match reports reaching the public not much more than an hour after the final whistle. Ceefax and the internet may have bruised the magic but a warm Pink 'Un after one's team has won is as lingeringly loving as any other Saturday night caress.

My footballing youth did not include away matches, which made the rush for the Football Final all the more memorable. The Grimsby Evening Telegraph always included on its front page a simple, child-like representation of a face whose mouth was upturned for a win, down-turned for a defeat and in a straight line for a draw. I can still feel that lurch of the stomach when the mouth signified the Mariners had sunk.

For close to 40 years David Meek revelled in the challenge of writing his Manchester United match reports for The Pink. "It wasn't exactly an exercise in quality writing but it was the most exciting part of the week for me."

And he remembers how Tom Henry, a football-daft former MEN editor, would check the front page of The Pink and often rewrite the headline. One painful afternoon at St James' Park, after United had been thrashed 6-1, he came up with: "United lose seven-goal thriller".

This may not quite match the Dundee Evening Telegraph's blazing "Broughty ferryman dies in sea tragedy", run with a smaller, subsidiary headline: "Titanic Sunk In Maiden Voyage", but it underlines the wonderfully one-eyed nature of football pinks.

The new MEN Sunday Pink promises "more in-depth match analysis". Meek takes umbrage. "Our match reports were entirely our own thoughts and not influenced by what the managers might say later, or the players."

The story is told of an elderly MEN news editor who, as a boy, was sent to Old Trafford on a Saturday to attach the reporter's match report to the legs of homing pigeons and despatch them to the office a few miles away.

To stop the birds flapping he clamped their wings with elastic bands. After attaching the first couple of paragraphs he rushed to the back of the stand and released the pigeon with a steady throw. Splat! He had forgotten to remove the elastic. This Saturday it would not have mattered.

webTitle: Who will be first to hit the roof?

fields.headline: Who will be first to hit the roof?
fields.standfirst: Australia and South Africa meet tomorrow in an historic indoor match
fields.trailText: Australia and South Africa meet tomorrow in an historic indoor match at Melbourne's Colonial stadium.
fields.body:
Australia and South Africa meet here tomorrow in the Super Challenge 2000 series with the book closed on one line of betting. No bookie will give odds on how many overs will be lost to rain.

The game nurtured by gentlemen on the fields of St John's Wood more than a century and a half ago is about to move indoors for the first time. The three one-day internationals over the next six days will be played in mid-winter, in direct competition to the Australian Rules play-offs, yet are expected to attract nearly 50,000 spectators a time.

For varying reasons both teams have been chastened by recent events. South Africa have lost a captain, Australia a vice-captain, though at least Shane Warne is playing, whereas Hansie Cronje has gone for good. Sex and gambling notwithstanding, the big talking point is the venue.

Colonial stadium, the latest "jewel" in Melbourne's sporting crown, sits in the heart of docklands, behind the main railway station, opposite a bus terminal and a postal depot, across the road from a prison remand centre. It has copped more bad press than Warne.

Built at a cost of more than £200m, it was running about six months behind schedule in March but opened for the start of the Australian Rules season anyway. It is essentially "boutique", pitched at those wealthy enough to join the Medallion Club, where a few thousand a year buys a padded seat and a personal TV screen on which to watch replays, the races, Neighbours, whatever.

Regular punters have had their own reception problems. From some of the "cheap" seats, on the top level, the playing area is obscured by the two electronic scoreboards. From others a boundary catch could be out of view. Ticketing problems seem to have been ironed out, but not before time. At a Rules match in June thousands of fans were waiting outside at kick-off, with the ground less than half-full.

There have been bad acoustics at a Barbra Streisand concert, as if one could tell, a power failure in the players' changing rooms, a computer glitch that left the retractable roof only half-closed, and growing pains with the surface - which spends most of its time in the shade, even with the roof open - that would put Alan Titchmarsh to the test.

Cricket at Colonial is a gamble, not least because a football final was played there last Friday. A wicket grown in a hothouse two hours north of Melbourne has since been lowered into place. How it will play is a question not even Warne and Mark Waugh could answer.

Another question is whether anyone will launch a drive that hits the roof (which will constitute a dead ball). There will surely be some wagers on that.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Warwickshire's Nick Knight continued with his rich vein of form in one-day competition at Riverside yesterday as the Bears defeated Durham by seven wickets in the National League Second Division and with 15 balls to spare.
fields.body:
Warwickshire's Nick Knight continued with his rich vein of form in one-day competition at Riverside yesterday as the Bears defeated Durham by seven wickets in the National League Second Division and with 15 balls to spare.

The discarded England left-hander's 75 followed his century in the NatWest Trophy semi-final win against Hampshire at Edgbaston on Saturday, and helped the Bears pass Durham's 202 for seven with some comfort.

The home county, put in with rain threatening, slipped to 25 for two before Simon Katich and Paul Collingwood put on 72 in 18 overs, the latter's 73 not out being the highest one-day score by a Durham player this season. But even with the help of 40 extras, their total proved to be inadequate in improving conditions.

Knight and Anurag Singh promptly took 19 off the first two overs of the reply and thereafter Warwickshire never looked like faltering.

Knight faced 110 balls and hit six fours before he was leg-before to a quicker ball from the off-spinner Nicky Phillips.

Glamorgan Dragons beat Hampshire Hawks by five runs in their Second Division game at Southampton but only after surviving an onslaught from the last-wicket pair of Will Kendall and Chris Tremlett, who came together with 58 runs required and three overs remaining.

Adrian Dale bowled the last over with with 22 still needed and after Tremlett had hit the first ball for six, 12 were required from the final two deliveries. However he missed the first but hit the last one out of the ground for six.

Kendall was 85 not out, his best score in the competition, the innings including two sixes and eight fours while Tremlett, playing only his second National League match, finished with an undefeated 30 off only 15 balls.

Glamorgan made 263 for five after winning the toss, Keith Newell and Matthew Elliott putting on 126 for the first wicket. Newell finished with 64 and the Australian with a top score of 68.

fields.headline: Storms hamper sub rescue bid
fields.trailText: Rescuers mounted a desperate undersea mission on Tuesday afternoon to evacuate 116 sailors trapped in a stricken Russian nuclear submarine on the sea floor before the oxygen ran out.
fields.body:
Rescuers mounted a desperate undersea mission on Tuesday afternoon to evacuate 116 sailors trapped in a stricken Russian nuclear submarine on the sea floor before the oxygen ran out.

The Itar-Tass news agency said a first attempt to dock a rescue capsule to the sunken submarine had failed due to heavy storms, and that a second had been launched. Dwindling oxygen supplies on the vessel were pushing rescuers to speed up their efforts.

The crew of the Kursk, one of Russia's most modern submarines, have been able to communicate with the outside world only by tapping on the hull since an accident at the weekend forced them to shut down the reactor and let the craft sink to the bottom.

But a Russian Navy spokesman said the tapping was growing fainter. "The signal is getting weaker. Of course, the oxygen is running low, people just need to lie or sit down," the spokesman at the base at Severomorsk told Reuters by telephone. It was not clear how the signals were being monitored.

Vladimir Kuroyedov, a Russian navy commander, told RTR television: "All we know is that there are still people alive, and they are signalling SOS. Our calculations show that by August 18 they will run out of oxygen."

The commander had earlier given a bleak assessment of the crew's chances of survival in a report to President Vladimir Putin, currently on vacation in a Black Sea resort, saying the prognosis was "very grim". "I am not a pessimist, I am a realist," he told RTR.

Officials have been careful not raise hopes too far. The undersea evacuation is a complex manoeuvre made far more difficult by the fierce weather and the stricken submarine's position. A rescue vessel will have to join the ship's escape hatch and bring the men up in groups of 15-20.

Interfax quoted navy commander Vladimir Kuroyedov as saying the rescue capsule had a three-man crew, who could see through video cameras and portholes to guide the vessel. A spokesman for the Russian northern fleet at base in Severomorsk described some of the difficulties by telephone. "The ships are being blown off their anchors. It is difficult for the ships to hold their course," he told Reuters. "The storms have calmed down somewhat, although waves are still high. But the current is more important."

The submarine is tilted on the sea bed, with its bow pointing down, and also listing sharply to one side. As a result, "these capsules and devices are sliding off it and cannot join with the vessel," he said.

Commander Kuroyedov said rescuers were driven by fear for the sailors' lives. "Our lack of knowledge about the fate of the crew has marked all our work," he said.

RTR showed the Commander pointing out damage to the bow of the craft on a diagram. On the starboard side a torpedo hatch was wide open and a command tower was slightly damaged. On the port side, some bits of the vessel were scattered on the sea floor.

Officials have said the damage may have been caused by a collision or some kind of explosion on board, but have been reluctant to give firm theories at this stage.

There were conflicting reports of exactly when the accident took place. Norway said it had received official Russian reports that it happened on Saturday, a day earlier than officials had earlier said.

Russia's Prime-Tass news agency quoted an unnamed US official saying on Tuesday that two US submarineslose to the Kursk heard a blast late on Saturday or early on Sunday.

webTitle: End of transfers to hit England hardest

fields.headline: End of transfers to hit England hardest
fields.trailText: The Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore believes the threatened abolition of the transfer system would hit England harder than any other nation.
fields.body:
The Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore believes the threatened abolition of the transfer system would hit England harder than any other nation.

Officials from Fifa, Uefa and all Europe's football associations are desperately trying to protect the traditional transfer market, which is under investigation by the European Union, who could decree it illegal, possibly by the end of the year.

Yesterday Fifa, the sport's world governing body, said this week it was sending the EU proposals that could avoid some of the most feared consequences of abolition.

After analysing the Perugia case, in which the Italian club refused to pay a fee for a player signed while he was still under contract in Belgium, the EU is set to challenge the requirement of compensation for contracted players changing clubs.

EU officials believe the transfer system may infringe workers' right of free movement under its employment law.

Fifa's general secretary Michel Zen-Ruffinen has already predicted "the end of football" should a workable solution not be found.

Although Scudamore does not make such a stark assessment, he left little doubt about the Premier League's concern.

"It is the number one issue in the game just now," he said. "It is top of our agenda because it would affect us more than any other country.

"The depth of professional football is greater in England than anywhere else in Europe. If the transfer market collapses it would affect 30 clubs in France and 40 in Spain. Here, you are talking about 92 and even some beyond that."

The consequences of abolition would be that players could move clubs at will, without cost to the buyer, and with a minimum amount of notice.

Scudamore added: "One of the fundamental principles of the game is that you have to be able to build a team. There must be a mutual agreement between a player and club for a contract to be ended. You can't have a system where someone signs an agreement then says, 'I'm off tomorrow'."

webTitle: Oxygen running low in stranded sub

fields.headline: Oxygen running low in stranded sub
fields.standfirst: Graphic: the nuclear threat
fields.trailText: Oxygen is running out in the stranded submarine amid reports that rescue operations may begin at 7pm British time.
fields.body:
Oxygen is running out in the nuclear submarine stranded at the bottom of the Barents Sea, the Russian navy said this afternoon.

A spokesman at the navy base in Severomorsk said signals from the 116 sailors trapped on board the Kursk were getting weaker. "The oxygen is running low, people just need to lie or sit down," he said.

The crew had been sending signals to rescuers by knocking on the side of the ship. It was not clear how rescuers monitored the signals.

But a spokesman for the navy in Moscow said rescuers would remain "optimistic about saving the crew until Friday."

Meanwhile, rescue efforts may recommence later today. A senior Russian admiral says poor weather and heavy seas, which have made rescue attempts impossible so far, are expected to clear and allow evacuation of the craft to begin.

Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov said: "We hope that the weather will allow us to launch a full-scale operation to rescue the Kursk submarine at 2200 hours Moscow time (7pm British time)."

He had earlier admitted: "The projection of possible consequences of the accident in the Kursk for the lives of its crew remains extremely grave."

British marine search and rescue teams are on standby to help in the operation but, so far, the Russians have declined offers of assistance from both the UK and US.

Strong winds, 20ft waves and rain have hampered efforts to connect air and electricity lines to the sub, lying some325ft beneath the surface of the Barents Sea, north of the Arctic Circle.

Russian naval officials today admitted for the first time that fatalities "could not be ruled out". Naval spokesman Captain Igor Dygalo said some 15 rescue vessels and warships had been sent to the area, and pledged: "We'll work with all our strength and means... to the last moment."

Initial suggestions that the sub had been involved in a collision on Sunday were today being played down, after experts observed damage to its bow area.

Admiral Kuroyedov said it was now thought there may have been an explosion in one of its torpedo tubes, the apparent site of a water leak which has flooded several compartments of the vessel. Analysts suggested that this would inevitably have caused extensive injuries, but it is not known whether there have been casualties among the crew or how long their oxygen will last.

The 500ft long, 14,000-ton Kursk is one of eight Oscar-2 class submarines in the Russian fleet and was commissioned only five years ago. It is designed to carry 24 nuclear-tipped cruise missiles, but Russian military officials have said that none were on board at the time of the incident.
