fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman
fields.body:
Tuesday

I am completely intrigued by a familiar concept enjoying a renaissance in the Times. That paper is currently obsessed by "health tourism", the bizarre phenomenon whereby every sick person on the planet makes their way here for free treatment. As with non-health tourism, the obvious question is why anyone would want to come here when there are so many obviously superior countries in Europe.

Wednesday

And yet people do choose England for their holidays. We do, at least, and tomorrow, I am off to join the family in a cottage in a part of Devon which, although absurdly exquisite, is ill-suited to health tourism. I doubt there's a hospital within a 30-minute drive, and God alone knows where the nearest MRI scanning machine is located. Please God I hit a rare patch of wellbeing.

Thursday

Twenty minutes before I am scheduled to leave, the vision on the periphery of my right eye is assailed by dancing psychedelic shapes, while I also feel nauseous and start mumbling. This could be a transient aeschemic attack (mini stroke), an early indication of a brain tumour or possibly a migraine. Two pain-killers stifle the symptoms, but residual thumping behind the eyes makes a long drive in my tiny car too hideous to contemplate, and - postponing my departure until first thing tomorrow - I take to my bed.

Friday

My annual holiday - all three days of it, because I have to go home on Sunday - gets off to a worrysome start when, within minutes of unloading the car, I am riven by classic symptoms of lymphatic cancer... exhaustion to the point of dropping off over lunch, a nagging ache in the lower back and a peculiar stiffness in the neck. When I tell Rebecca, she launches into her beloved Socratic mode. "What time did you get up?" she begins. "Just after 5am." "Why?" "To drive here from London." "And how long did that take?" My patience is thinning, but a caustic glance thickens it up. "Five and a half hours," I answer. "In a big, comfortable car?" "No, a small, extremely cramped one." She pauses in the portentous manner of a leading silk poised to ask the killer question. "So then," she resumes, "why do you think you are tired with backache and a stiff neck?" "Hodgkin's disease?" Remembering that nothing in this rented cottage is ours, she thinks better of assaulting the crockery and heads for the bedroom.

Saturday

This, the only full day of my annual holiday, is spent sheltering from driving rain under a parasol in Torquay, eating fish and chips that might have been more effectively deployed in biological warfare. What I really need now, I reflect as we drive home across Dartmoor, is a fortnight's health tourism - in a French hospital, ideally, having tests on my blood, kidney, colon, brain and testes.

Sunday

Back in London, I am overwhelmed by profound fatigue. It could mean anything from too much Jack Daniels or a nameless virus all the way to acute myeloid leukemia. Since I have no coherent set of symptoms, my physician Sarah Jarvis would doubtless advise less drinking, proper eating, exercise, etc, rather than refer me. But what I want is a blood test, and it occurs to me that going abroad may be the only way to get one.

Monday

"Haematology, g'day. How may I help?" It is late Monday night in London, but early Tuesday morning in Australia when I get through to a Sydney teaching hospital. "Ah yes, a very good day to you too. I'm a health tourist from England coming over next month for the Olympics, and I'd like to book a blood test." "I'm sorry I don't understand. Health tourist?" Briefly, I outline the concept, and the perplexed-sounding young woman says she needs to transfer me. The phone rings again. "Psychiatric out patients, g'day. How may I help?" I replace the receiver, and reflecting that this health tourism lark isn't as easy as it sounds, I make a mental note to call Thomas Cook's medical department and retire disconsolately to bed.

webTitle: Health: Did Simon Hervey commit suicide or was he killed by prescription drugs

fields.headline: Little boy lost
fields.standfirst: Simon Hervey was intelligent, good-looking and deeply depressed. He died, unexpectedly, aged 28. Was it suicide? Or was he killed by a lethal cocktail of prescription drugs?  Victoria Macdonald, who has read his diaries, reports
fields.trailText: Simon Hervey was intelligent, good-looking and deeply depressed. He died, unexpectedly, aged 28. Was it suicide? Or was he killed by a lethal cocktail of prescription drugs? Victoria Macdonald, who has read his diaries, reports
fields.body:
Sunday, January 21 1999

Two one-night stands later - I swear they weren't intentionally one-night stands so far as I was concerned - I was USED!! Anyway, while I'm feeling bitter, here's a list of the things Georgia has so far copied from me!! CREAM rotary phone, PANASONIC walkman, her new love of candles, religious imagery, ROBOCOP (!!) Rocky Horror, Elvis and his tacky ways. Priscilla, CULTURE CLUB!! (I got a photo, signed to no-one, sent to me recently), colours, my favourites green, orange and blue, cosmetics, Cosmetics To Go, silver jewellery. She even wanted some bike boots (I successfully got some in Camden). NO SHAME. That's all I can remember for now. I will eventually write about London and explain the Savoy/Fortnum receipts opposite. So much has happened and psychotherapy is a total mind FUCK!! I'm psychotic!! (and suicidal).

This entry was the last ever in Simon Hervey's diary. He died, sitting up in bed in his small flat in Newcastle, on March 8 last year. He had a book on his lap, and a crisp packet by his side; there were still crisps in his mouth. At the inquest six months later, the coroner recorded an open verdict. "Open in the sense that one simply does not know what happened," he said.

Simon was just 28. For 14 of those 28 years, he was prescribed a cocktail of drugs by a variety of doctors. The first prescription for Valium was because he was unhappy about being bullied at school and because he was concerned about his acne. Between then and his death he was put on uppers, downers, more benzodiazepines (the drug group to which Valium belongs), Prozac, Heminevrin, normally given under hospital conditions to alcoholics, and finally Epilim, an anti-epileptic.

The year summed up: 1992.

"In 1991, September 18, my Grandma C died and I found out by accident on Jan 10, '92 from a phone call to Grandad. Thanks Mum, I never knew her, thanks to you... I've now been sick with depression for four years and it's going to come to a head. Valium is not enough, nor is librium. I've had every antidepressant going and none of them work."

Simon died alone. The evening before, he had rung his father Adrian Hervey, 58, who works at an all-night garage, and asked him to drop by with some chocolate on his way home. Adrian recalls seeing Simon with the book and crisp packet. "I chatted to him for a while and then realised something had happened. I called an ambulance but I knew he was dead," he says.

Simon was flamboyantly gay; he was clever and artistic. In his Newcastle flat, he dreamed of fame and fortune. In his diary, he has left a record of those dreams and of his descent into depression, and into drug-induced confusion; his battle with alcohol and his longing to leave the city. The diaries, from 1990 until that final entry nine years later, are brutal, yet often written with warmth, wit and lucidity. And on virtually every page is a cry for help. I never knew him but I feel that I did; for anyone who has read his diaries, there is an enormous sense of loss.

Adrian Hervey's wife left when Simon was eight, leaving Adrian to bring up his son. Now he is alone - bewildered, grieving and proud. Pictures of Simon cover the walls in his high-rise flat in the centre of Newcastle: Simon as Boy George, made-up eyes and high cheekbones; Simon outside the Pompidou Centre in Paris, looking gleefully wicked in one picture and as innocent as a choir boy in another. Simon was a chameleon and he was deeply, deeply unhappy.

I met Adrian Hervey six months after Simon died, while reporting on the NHS complaints system for Channel 4 News. I was looking at what kind of redress people have when something has gone wrong. In Hervey's case he wanted to know why Simon had been prescribed this cocktail of drugs for so long. And why he had been given repeat prescriptions of drugs such as Valium which is supposed to be prescribed only in the short term, with the patient seen regularly by the doctor.

Adrian was beginning to contemplate the complaints process. Should he demand to see Simon's notes from the hospital and the GP? Should he sue? Like all parents whose children die before they do, he needed some answers because he felt the system had failed his son.

"My son died unnecessarily," Adrian says. "There was a crass lack of care. In any other country in the world he would have been put in hospital and got off those drugs." According to Adrian, Simon had begun to fall over, crash into furniture and black out shortly before he died. The coroner noted the bruising on his body and acknowledged Adrian's evidence that his son had begun to lose his coordination.

Peter Cooper, the pathologist who gave evidence at the inquest, said that there were benzodiazepines, Heminevrin and co-proxomol in his blood as well as of Epilim, all at a therapeutic dosage level. There were no empty pill bottles or packets in his flat to indicate this might have been suicide.

"He was looking for help all the time, desperately," says Adrian. "The effect of the benzodiazepine is to make the person dependent. He screamed to be off them. He tried to get help from doctors but, every time, he would come back with another drug. He lost his self-esteem, his self- confidence."

Simon tried to kill himself three or four times during the 14 years that he was ill. Adrian believes that each incident was a cry for help. "He knew that if he got to hospital he would get hands-on care," he says.

November 2 1993

"I can't think of any more reasons to live, I disgust myself. I mistrust others and make life difficult for my father... I will never have what I want - I DON'T EVEN KNOW WHAT I WANT. I'm thick, my grammar is awful and I'm just plain tired of being ashamed of myself. I'm fat, ugly, spotty and obnoxious. My father can't even think of a decent reply when I tell him I'm dying!!"

November 5 1993

"I know a lot of dead people, and one of them is me. "

November 6 1993

Well, one bottle of Smirnoff and a squillion diazepam later and I'm still here - unfortunately."

November 14 1993

"This week I took all the anti-depressants I had - and lived!! Took my reserve of Valium - and ditto! I don't think alcohol and drugs can kill me. Dad called the doctor. I feel like shit."

March 8 1994

"Invest my sexual energy. IN WHOM? That's what I want to know!! ... My shrink told me this bizarre piece of nonsense this afternoon... I think my craziness is beyond help and that I will inevitably end my own life."

November 19 1995

"I'm so frightened of living, I hide in bed all day... And yet I'm so preoccupied with the thought that it may improve of its own accord, of course, that I haven't the guts to end the farce... My head aches. I feel 100 years old, I'm only twenty frigging five."

There is no diary for 1998. It is as if life had become so unbearable he could not longer stand to record it. But in 1999 he appeared to rally. On the front page of his diary he has stuck a card, saying: "New Year Same Shit." But on the next page is a map of the London Underground, in preparation for a visit to the capital, and pictures of orchids. He made that trip, between January 29 and February 1. There is a picture of the hotel he stayed in and, finally, on the last entry but one, a receipt from the American Bar at the Savoy Hotel, for a packet of Malboro Light cigarettes and, from Fortnum and Mason, for one Welsh rarebit and a glass of Guinness. We do not know how the visit went, despite his promise to write about it.

They played Boy George's Church of the Poison Mind at Simon's funeral. He had made a tape in case one of his suicide attempts worked. Is that what finally happened?

Adrian is still trying to find out whether the drugs his son was prescribed could, in combination, have killed him. He has sent part of his research to his local MP, Jim Cousins, and the health secretary, Alan Milburn. A copy has gone to North Tyneside health authority, which has said it will investigate.

 Victoria Macdonald is social affairs correspondent for Channel 4 News.

webTitle: Time running out for sailors trapped in sub

fields.headline: Time running out for sailors trapped in sub
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A frantic rescue effort was under way in the Arctic last night after a Russian nuclear-powered submarine sank to the sea bed with more than 100 crew on board. Senior Russian navy officers said the sinking might have been caused by a collision with a foreign vessel and suggested there would be casualties.
fields.body:
A frantic rescue effort was under way in the Arctic last night after a Russian nuclear-powered submarine sank to the sea bed with more than 100 crew on board. Senior Russian navy officers said the sinking might have been caused by a collision with a foreign vessel and suggested there would be casualties.

The Oscar-II class Kursk submarine, powered by two nuclear reactors, was lying between 100 and 150m (330-490ft) below the surface of the Barents Sea, more than 100 miles north of the Russian port of Murmansk.

When the accident happened, the Kursk, the flagship of Russia's northern fleet, was on manoeuvres as part of the country's biggest naval exercises in the Arctic for years.

While western environmentalists speculated on whether radiation could leak from the 14,000-tonne submarine, Russia's navy chief said the accident was probably caused by a collision at sea and that the salvage prospects were not good.

"The signs are of a major and serious collision," said Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov. "I can not yet say what the submarine collided with. The situation is difficult and the chances of a favourable outcome are not very high."

There has been speculation in Moscow that the submarine collided with a foreign surveillance vessel, possibly from Nato, which was observing the three days of manoeuvres.

Such remarks suggested that the submarine sinking could yet turn into a major international incident.

By last night a nuclear missile cruiser, Peter the Great, a patrol boat, another large ship and five rescue boats were on the scene. An aircraft carrier was providing a base for fleets of helicopters.

A submersible craft surveyed the damage to the vessel, which included damage to the bow, hull, and conning tower. One of the craft was also said to be supplying the crippled vessel with fuel and oxygen for the 107 trapped crew members.

The Russian navy press office said that there had been no casualties but other navy sources in the northern fleet headquarters in Murmansk told Interfax news agency that there had been some deaths.

Interfax also said that rescue teams planned to fix special equipment called kolokol (bell) on the body of the submarine, which would restore an air supply and help the crew escape through hatches. However, ORT public television said experts feared the hatches had been damaged in the collision. Nor was it clear last night whether the Kursk had been fitted with escape capsules.

It is not inconceivable that the sailors could climb into the torpedo tubes, rocket out of the vessel and float safely to the surface, experts said, noting that British submariners have escaped in 185 metres of water during training exercises. However, Jim Jenkin, a Royal Navy spokesman, said it had never been tried for real. "Their escape facility may be nothing like ours," he added.

Last night, naval analysts agreed that the collision theory was the most plausible because the submarine was on the sea bed with its nuclear reactors idled, suggesting that the accident had happened very quickly. The submarine's commanders would normally surface before switching off the reactors if at all possible.

The Pentagon said that a surface electronic surveillance ship had been monitoring the exercise but declared that it had "no indication" that any of its vessels were involved in the accident.

The Ministry of Defence insisted there were no British submarines in the area. A Royal Navy spokesman added: "Any request for help would be met extremely favourably."

The Royal Navy has an LR5 mini-submarine, on lease from a private company, but it is not clear whether it would be compatible with Russian technology.

The Kursk, commissioned in 1994 and capable of carrying 24 cruise missiles and four torpedoes, was on the final day of exercises on Sunday when the disaster struck. The manoeuvres involved dozens of ships, submarines, and aircraft commanded from Murmansk and the nearby naval base of Severomorsk.

Russian officials insisted yesterday that there were no nuclear weapons on board the stricken submarine. However, in previous accidents the Russian navy has also issued such denials and later admitted missiles had been on board.

Another suggested cause for the accident was a flood in the front of the submarine when hatches failed to close during firing practice. However, a Russian navy spokesman dismissed this theory.

While Norway, which also borders on the Barents sea, convened a crisis committee to monitor the accident, western anti-nuclear campaigners warned of a radiation disaster.

If the submarine is flooded and sunk, its total weight could be more than 30,000 tonnes. The Russians do not have the engineering equipment to raise such a weight, experts said.

Greenpeace, which says there have been more than 120 accidents in the Russian and Soviet nuclear submarine fleets in the past 40 years, said the disaster illustrated the hazards posed by all nuclear submarines.

The Kursk is believed to be the seventh nuclear submarine to sink; two were American, the rest Soviet or Russian.

Alexander Nikitin, an environmentalist and former Russian navy officer who was tried for spying after he blew the whistle on Russian nuclear leaks in the far north, said the depth of the sinking would make it nigh impossible to raise the stricken vessel. He said there were no emergency escape capsules for the crew.

Other Russian experts contested this, stating that the Kursk is fitted with escape capsules and that crew members could also try to escape through the torpedo tubes and swim to the surface, though this was dangerous.

webTitle: Russian submarine crew faces dreadful fate

fields.headline: Russian submarine crew faces dreadful fate
fields.standfirst:
Russia's refusal of help to rescue a sunken nuclear submarine shows it cares more about its wounded pride than the 116 crew members on board, thinks Derek Brown

Submarine rescue bid 'under way'
fields.trailText:
Russia's refusal of help to rescue a sunken nuclear submarine shows it cares more about its wounded pride than the 116 crew members on board, thinks Derek Brown.
Submarine rescue bid 'under way'
fields.body:
Being buried alive is one of the ultimate nightmares common to all humanity. Anybody aware of the plight of the stricken Russian submarine Kursk must be filled with horror today, as rescue efforts are hampered by rough seas and inadequate equipment.

The Kursk plunged to the bottom of the icy Barents Sea, far above the Arctic Circle, on Sunday. Since then she has rested silently on the seabed 354ft below the surface, where a fleet of Russian ships has assembled in apparent impotence.

The stricken sub was taking part in large-scale fleet exercises when disaster struck. At first, the Russian navy said the vessel had been damaged in a collision. Now it says there was probably an explosion in the bow torpedo compartment.

Similar confusion swirls about the official accounts of rescue attempts. Earlier today, navy officials let it be known that power and fuel lines had been attached to the Kursk, and that contact had been established with its crew.

Now they have acknowledged that the submarine has received no direct assistance. Nor has there been any communication with her crew of 116 officers and ratings.

That admission has dashed hopes of an early rescue, and the gloom has been deepened by forecasts of bad weather continuing for three more days.

Facing a horrific tragedy, the Russian military seems to have rediscovered a taste for Soviet secrecy, compounded by a knee-jerk refusal to countenance offers of help from western navies. Wounded national pride, it seems, is a higher priority than plucking the trapped submariners from their steel tomb.

There are severe doubts about the Russian navy's ability to rescue the men, even if the submarine's own escape equipment is still functioning. Like the rest of the once mighty Soviet military machine, the navy has been corroded by years of underspending, corruption and neglect.

The submarine service, which used to patrol the oceans of the world, is now littered with rusting relics of the cold war. No fewer than 107 nuclear-powered vessels are waiting to be scrapped - a complex and dangerous procedure which has proved well beyond the atrophied capacity of Russian shipyards.

What has flicked the raw nerve of the naval high command is that the Kursk was no obsolescent tub, but rather a spanking new attack vessel commissioned within the past five years.

Ominously, western defence sources have cast doubts on the claim that the Kursk was carrying no weapons during the fleet exercise. The Oscar II-class submarine's main armament is a battery of 24 nuclear-tipped cruise missiles.

webTitle: Win a pair of tickets to an exclusive screening of Time Code

fields.headline: Win a pair of tickets to an exclusive screening of Time Code
fields.standfirst: and meet the director afterwards
fields.trailText: We have five pairs of tickets to give away to a screening of Time Code on Sunday 20 August at The Gate cinema, London W11, followed by a Q&A with director Mike Figgis
fields.body:
Released this Friday, Mike Figgis's Time Code looks set to be the year's most technically inventive feature: a Hollywood satire that plays out on four separate frames, in real time and without a single edit. But if the film sounds too art-school pretentious, think again. Time Code is also funny, irreverent and exuberantly acted by the likes of Salma Hayek, Saffron Burrows and Stellan Skarsgard. Viewed either as a radical film experiment or a sharp comedy-drama, the picture works a treat.

We have five pairs of tickets to see the film at a London cinema on Sunday 20 August in a special screening which will be followed by a live on-stage interview with director Mike Figgis conducted by Film Unlimited's editor, Xan Brooks.

Time Code screens at 6.40pm at The Gate Cinema, 87 Notting Hill Gate, London W11; Mike Figgis will be on stage between 8.20 and 9.10pm. To win a pair of tickets, email us at feedback@filmunlimited.co.uk. Please put "Time Code competition" in the subject line, and include your full name and an email address where we can reach you on Friday afternoon, if this is different to the address from which you are writing. Winners will be notified by email by 4pm on Friday 18 August.

Please note, tickets are for this screening only, and cannot be exchanged for any other. Entries must be received by 1pm on Friday 18 August.

webTitle: Birmingham's Odeon dampens the passion of cinema-goers

fields.headline: Birmingham's Odeon dampens the passion of cinema-goers
fields.trailText: The days of romantic trysts in the back row for passionate Brummies could be numbered. The Odeon eight-screen multiplex has threatened to expel any kissing couple who go too far.
fields.body:
Birmingham's cinemas are breaking the mould in more ways than one (see last month's story). The days of romantic trysts in the back row for passionate Brummies could be numbered. The Odeon eight-screen multiplex has threatened to expel any kissing couple who go too far.

"We've found them in the back row, at the rear of the building and even behind the stand-up adverts in the corridors," Odeon spokesman Michael McLean told the Daily Mail. "This is a family place, we cannot allow these things to go on here."

Cinema ushers will use torches to probe the dark corners and couples who are deemed to be behaving inappropriately will be asked to leave.

The Odeon management would be better advised to ban mobile phones in their cinemas. Cinema-goers whose phone rings during a film could be pounced on by said ushers, and strung up by their feet outside the auditorium - where they could continue their conversations to their heart's content - while leaving the rest of the audience to watch the film in peace. Now that's a campaign that really would win the backing of the nation's film fans.

fields.headline: Ipswich Town
fields.trailText: Ipswich have been tipped to go straight back down by almost every pundit with the ability to write (and you'd be surprised how many that excludes). A defence built around Tony Mowbray, they say, is unlikely to contain Thierry Henry and pals. Strikers David Johnson and Marcus Stewart, they say, are very much an unproven pairing at the top level. The midfield too, Matt Holland aside, is uninspiring they say. And to be frank, this pundit is inclined to agree with them.
fields.body:
Ipswich have been tipped to go straight back down by almost every pundit with the ability to write (and you'd be surprised how many that excludes). A defence built around Tony Mowbray, they say, is unlikely to contain Thierry Henry and pals. Strikers David Johnson and Marcus Stewart, they say, are very much an unproven pairing at the top level. The midfield too, Matt Holland aside, is uninspiring they say. And to be frank, this pundit is inclined to agree with them.

It is an achievement in itself for Ipswich to be in the Premiership this season and holding onto captain Holland and Richard Wright is also a bonus. But the club does not have the resources to compete in the top flight, and in David Sheepshanks they have a chairman who will not bankrupt the club in order to avoid relegation.

This is no bad thing, but it will not help George Burley this season. His summer spending looks unlikely to do so either. John Scales, even on a free transfer, is a gamble given his history of injury, and goalkeeper Keith Branagan is unlikely to do anything but sit on the bench. The impending signing of the wandering Hermann Hreidarsson doesn't really inspire either, but the permanent addition of the impressive Martijn Reuser should help add a cutting edge to the midfield.

If Reuser and Holland, plus skillful wingbacks Fabian Wilnis and Jamie Clapham can get frequent service to Stewart and Johnson they may have a chance of occasionally scoring more goals than they concede. But it is equally likely that George Burley, like Graham Taylor last year, will enjoy a season in the sun while strengthening his squad in the hope of a quick and more fruitful return in 2002.

In: Martijn Reuser (Vitesse), John Scales (Spurs), Keith Branagan (Bolton).

Out: Marco Holster (Go Ahead Eagles)

Odds: 1000-1

Football Unlimited prediction: 20th

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Clint Eastwood insists on aging gracefully, Gwyneth turns from blubbing to warbling, Ben Affleck changes lanes, Jennifer Lopez to play Mexican painter Frida Kahlo, and Raquel Welch returns in remake.
fields.body:
 Clint Eastwood (pictured) has insisted he will not reprise his role as Dirty Harry because he is too old. The star has said he's no longer interested in the action genre, and isn't too keen for the public to see him jumping around either. He explained that film bosses "want me to have Dirty Harry retired and on a fishing trip where he suddenly becomes involved in a murder investigation". But he doesn't want "to go back and imitate myself. I have no desire to do the kind of action movies I did in the 1970s and 80s I don't think I could do that very well any more and, frankly, I don't think anybody would really want to see me trying."

 Gwyneth Paltrow has turned her attention to singing and has recorded three songs for the soundtrack of her latest film Duets (see our earlier story). Paltrow joined with co-star Huey Lewis to record her own versions of Crusin', Just My Imagination and Bette Davis Eyes. Rarely one to hide her light under a bushel, Paltrow reckons she has a good voice: "My mother and I would always sing and harmonise together. I was three years old and imitating her jazz singing. I was singing a Sesame Street song and I would put this spin on it and it was hilarious."

 Meanwhile, Paltrow's ex-squeeze Ben Affleck is in final negotiations to star in the thriller Changing Lanes. The film will begin shooting in December before Affleck takes over the role of Jack Ryan from Harrison Ford in The Sum of All Fears, according to Ananova. The film spins the tale of a minor car accident between a lawyer and a businessman that goes out of control.

 Latina bombshell Jennifer Lopez is poised to play Mexican painter Frida Kahlo in her next film project. According to Variety, La Bamba director Luis Valdez has been trying to get the project on the big screen for over a decade and now has Francis Ford Coppola in place as executive producer. Although the deal has yet to be signed and sealed, the plan is for Lopez to begin shooting the film in early 2001.

 Sex siren Raquel Welch is set to return to the silver screen after years out of the limelight. The 60-year-old actress is to star in an American remake of Ang Lee's 1994 Taiwanese comedy Eat Drink Man Woman.

fields.headline: Swine fever
fields.standfirst: Tens of thousands of British pigs are marked for slaughter and the European Commission has banned the export of English pigs to the continent after an outbreak of swine fever. Angelique Chrisafis explains the latest crisis to hit Britain's farmers
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 1.30pm: Tens of thousands of British pigs are marked for slaughter and the European Commission has banned the export of English pigs to the continent after an outbreak of swine fever. We explain the latest crisis to hit Britain's farmers.
fields.body:
What is swine fever?
Also known as hog cholera or pig typhoid, it is the most infectious virus known to affect pigs. It can wipe out whole pig herds but is harmless to people and other animals. Symptoms of swine fever in pigs are loss of appetite and high temperature. The animals may have red or purple patches of discoloration on the skin. Infected pigs are known to cough, vomit and huddle together. With the most acute form the virus, pigs can die within five days.

Where has it hit?
Signs of the virus were discovered last week on a pig-breeding farm in Norfolk. Cases were reported elsewhere in East Anglia, on farms linked with Quality British Pigs, the biggest outdoor pig farming enterprise in Britain. Experts are trying to contain the outbreak in East Anglia, but fear it may spread to other areas of England. So far, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have not been affected.

How is the virus spread?
This outbreak is likely to have been caused by pigs eating waste food containing infected material or transporting the animals in contaminated lorries. Swine fever is spread by direct contact between animals, through secretions, excretion, semen or blood. It can also be carried between pigs by vets and pig traders. Indirect contact through pig pens, vehicles, clothes and vets' instruments can also be to blame.

Can it be stopped?
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food hopes that slaughtering all pigs from original breeding units will stop the outbreak. Six thousand animals have already been slaughtered in East Anglia and another 10,000 are set for destruction. Carcasses are taken away in sealed bags to be burned at incinerators built to deal with BSE-infected cattle. A six-mile surveillance zone has been established around the affected farms. But the Pig Vetinary Society is sceptical, warning that the large bird, deer and fox populations in East Anglia may spread the virus further. At this time of year, land is usually fertilised with pig manure and vets warn that local muck spreading was a significant factor in a previous Dutch epidemic of the virus.

Is this the new BSE?
The virus is not harmful to humans, but it could signal a BSE-style collapse in the pig export trade, which is worth £126m a year. The Meat and Livestock Commission has warned that the slaughter of so many pigs will have a devastating effect on the industry. The National Farmers Union says many British pig farmers currently rely on markets in France, Germany, Italy and Poland. Export bans will affect this trade.

Which countries have banned British pig exports?
Yesterday, the European Commission issued a ban on live English pig exports and pig sperm for breeding. They have not banned exports of frozen pork. The ban will be reviewed by EU vetinary experts on August 22. Belgium, the Netherlands and Spain had already banned the export of British pigs while waiting for the EC decision. The supermarket chain Asda has threatened to remove Belgian pate from its shelves if the European embargo is extended to cover all pork products and is not reviewed at the end of the month.

Should we stop eating pork?
No. Scientists say bacon, sausages and other pork products do not transmit the virus to meat-eaters. In any case, swine fever is considered harmless to humans. Nick Sheldon of the National Pig Association said the Asda chain had confused the issue by threatening to remove Belgian pate from its shelves as a retaliation for any ban by Belgium on British pork products. He said it was unlikely that British pork products would be banned and Asda should not draw comparisons with the severity of Belgium's dioxin food last year. "That was a public health matter," he said. "This swine fever in pigs is a matter for the pigs and the pig farmers, but it's not a human health issue."

Is swine fever a new disease?
No, but this is the most severe outbreak in Britain in 30 years, and the first one here in 14 years. In 1998, an epidemic in Holland forced the destruction of up to 10m pigs and cost the Dutch government millions of pounds in compensation. Herds were also hit in Germany, Spain and Italy. Swine fever occurs in much of Asia, Central and South America and parts of Europe and Africa, but many countries are totally free of it.

Will farmers be badly affected?
Yes, the enforced slaughtering and the EC ban could not come at a worse time for pig farmers, who are already struggling against low prices and cheap imports. Under the policy of compulsory slaughter of pigs, farmers receive 50% of the market value for infected animals, nothing for dead stock and 100% for uninfected pigs. There is no compensation for loss of income or slaughter costs. Tim Yeo, shadow agriculture minister, has argued that the EC should compensate pig farmers for the ban.

webTitle: Pitt joins Coen Brothers on Asian escapade

fields.headline: Pitt joins Coen Brothers on Asian escapade
fields.trailText: Brad Pitt has signed up to star in the next Ethan and Joel Coen project, To the White Sea, the story of a second world war tail gunner who finds himself stranded in Japan and is forced to embark on an epic journey through Asia to get home.
fields.body:
Brad Pitt has signed up to star in the next Ethan and Joel Coen project, To the White Sea. The actor, who recently married Friends actress Jennifer Aniston, will begin shooting next year after completing Steven Soderbergh's star-studded remake of the Rat Pack's Ocean's 11, according to Yahoo.com.

It seems that Hollywood's finest are lining up to work with the off-the-wall brothers behind the critically acclaimed Barton Fink and Fargo. ER alumnus George Clooney stars in their latest release O Brother, Where Art Thou? which is released in Britain on September 15.

To the White Sea is based on a James Dickey novel and tells the story of a second world war tail gunner who finds himself stranded in Japan and is forced to embark on an epic journey through Asia to get home.

This is the second time that Pitt is appearing in a project based in Asia. In 1997 he played a real-life Austrian mountaineer who escaped from a second world war POW camp and ended up spending Seven Years in Tibet.

Pitt will next be seen in Guy Ritchie's latest, Snatch, which will premiere next week in London and is released on September 1.

webTitle: Russia makes saints of its imperial martyrs

fields.headline: Russia makes saints of its imperial martyrs
fields.standfirst: Net Notes: St Tsar Nicholas
fields.trailText: More than 82 years after the Bolsheviks murdered the last Russian tsar with a bullet in the head, Nicholas II was canonised last night by the Russian Orthodox church.
fields.body:
More than 82 years after the Bolsheviks murdered the last Russian tsar with a bullet in the head, Nicholas II was canonised last night by the Russian Orthodox church.

Making a saint of the autocrat whose 21 years of misrule spanned two lost wars and two revolutionary uprisings, and contributed hugely to the victory of communism in 1917, is controversial and divisive.

Nicholas, his wife Alexandra, and their five children were killed in July 1918 in the basement of a house in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg, Boris Yeltsin's power base. All seven were proclaimed Orthodox martyrs and saints at the assembly of bishops' millennium meeting in the newly restored Christ the Saviour Cathedral near the Kremlin in Moscow.

Another 1,100 Christians persecuted during 70 years of communist rule became saints, making this by far the biggest mass canonisation ever held. The nearest equivalent was in the mid-16th century when 39 Orthodox saints were canonised in a single session.

Nicholas is as much reviled in Russia as he is revered by the Orthodox faithful, and the arguments over whether he should be canonised have been raging for years.

Highlighting the delicacy of the issue the head of the church, Patriarch Alexei, told the assembly that the canonisation could cause a split.

"There are different opinions in the church as to whether to attach the tsar's family to the assembly of saints," he conceded. The debate had to be especially thorough, "so that making a decision will not cause dangerous schisms in our community".

In canonising the imperial family, the church hierarchy was anxious to stress that it was not endorsing Nicholas's record as tsar or making a political judgment, though that argument was dismissed as nonsensical by critics.

"In the last Russian Orthodox monarch and his family, we see people who sincerely tried to carry out the commandments of the gospels," said the proclamation, which was agreed unanimously.

"The light of all-conquering Christian faith was seen in the suffering the royal family endured during their incarceration with gentleness, patience, and humility, and in their martyr deaths."

Nicholas, Alexandra and the children, Alexei, Olga, Tatiana, Maria and Anastasia, were canonised as "passion-bearers", the lowest category of Orthodox sainthood, because of the humility and forbearance they showed in accepting their deaths at the hands of 11 Bolshevik gunmen in the early hours of July 17 1918.

"What! What!" were said to be the tsar's final words on being told by Yakov Yurovski, the local Bolshevik secret policeman who led the firing squad, that he was to be shot.

The seven Romanovs and four servants were shot at point-blank range, ushering in the Red Terror. The sole survivor was Joy, the imperial spaniel.

"Nine out of 10 of the virulent advocates of canonisation are people who are convinced that Nicholas II was ritually killed by Jews as part of a global conspiracy," commented a church analyst, Alexander Morozov.

The Moscow theology professor Alexei Osipov said there were absolutely no grounds for canonising the Romanovs, particularly as, unlike the thousands of religious victims of communist persecution, they did not die for their faith. "[Nicholas] suffered not for his Christian convictions but as a political figure," he said.

Sainthood requires evidence of miracle-working. As recently as three years ago the head of the church canonisation commission, Metropolitan Yuvenali, ruled out sainthood for the tsar on the grounds that there was no such evidence.

fields.headline: St Tsar Nicholas
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the martyred Autocrat of All the Russias, and why he was not really a tsar
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the martyred Autocrat of All the Russias, and why he was not really a tsar.
fields.body:
1. Nicholas II, the last emperor of Russia, has been officially declared a saint by the Russian Orthodox church. A minor one, but still a saint.

2. He was known in his lifetime by many titles, including Autocrat of All the Russias. Now he has another one: Passion Bearer.

3. Strictly speaking, a miracle should have been ascribed to Nicholas before he was canonised. At least one devotee claims that there was one.

4. The Orthodox church is bitterly divided over the saintly status of the last emperor, who was an utterly useless ruler. But outside Russia, his elevation to the holy family of saints - along with his own family, who have all been canonised - has been warmly welcomed, by the faithful and by those with - shall we say - unconventional views.

5. Life in royal Russia, for the royals at any rate, was elegant, ostentatious, and banal. In their last days, the lives of Nicholas, his Empress Alexandra, and their five children were simply banal.

6. Throughout his troubled times, Nicholas was a staunch believer.

7. Even after he had abdicated, he showed an almost saintly stoicism as the shadows around him lengthened. His very moving letters and telegrams to Alexandra reveal naivety and stubbornness in equal measure.

8. The brutal assassination of the Romanovs in Yekaterinburg in July 1918 was followed by even more ghastly killings. Some of those martyrs have also joined the crowded gallery of Orthodox saints.

9. The royal remains for Ekaterinburg were exhumed, identified and reburied in great splendour in 1998. Russia's monarchist minority rejoiced, but there is not much hope for a Romanov restoration - though there are plenty of them.

10. The last tsar of Russia was not Nicholas, but Peter the Great, in the 17th century. All subsequent monarchs should correctly be styled as emperors. Only pedants know this.

fields.headline: Cyber co-star for Pacino
fields.trailText: Al Pacino's next leading lady will be completely computer-generated. A cyber character will play the eponymous role in Simone, the story of an actress whose dreams come true and becomes a film star overnight.
fields.body:
Al Pacino's next leading lady will be completely computer-generated.

A cyber character will play the eponymous role in Simone, the story of an actress whose dreams come true when she becomes a film star overnight. Pacino will co-star as her Hollywood film producer.

Writer/director Andrew Niccol, who wrote the Truman Show and directed Gattaca, said that he decided to create a cyber character for the part after failing to find a real-life actress who could fulfil the requirements of Simone.

The Screen Actors Guild is however unhappy with the decision, according to E!Online. "It's not a big deal when it's an animated picture, but in the case of this thing an actor is losing a job," said SAG spokesman Greg Krizman.

Niccol believes the technology is already in place to make the cyber character seem realistic. He was apparently inspired by Sony's Final Fantasy: The Movie, where life-like characters were created using actors wearing motion-capture suits.

Simone starts shooting next month.

webTitle: Perilous history of Soviet nuclear fleet

fields.headline: Perilous history of Soviet nuclear fleet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Since Russia commissioned its first nuclear-powered submarine more than 40 years ago, the vessels have suffered numerous accidents.
fields.body:
Since Russia commissioned its first nuclear-powered submarine more than 40 years ago, the vessels have suffered numerous accidents.

Between 1956 and 1991 there were at least 121 incidents involving Soviet nuclear submarines, according to Greenpeace. Lack of resources since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 have aggravated the difficulty of servicing the fleet.

Many submarines are not only driven by nuclear reactors but are also armed with ballistic missiles tipped with nuclear warheads. At least 10 accidents have involved damage to nuclear reactors. Twice, it is thought, partial meltdowns occurred.

July 1961 The captain and seven crew died when radiation spread through the Soviet Union's first nuclear-powered submarine. A pipe in a reactor's control system had ruptured.

March 1968 A Golf-2 class diesel-powered submarine armed with three nuclear SS-N-5 missiles sank in the Pacific.

April 1970 A November class nuclear-powered attack submarine sank in the Atlantic off Spain. It was carrying two nuclear torpedoes.

September 1977 A Delta-1 class nuclear-powered submarine accidentally jettisoned a nuclear warhead off Russia's eastern Kamchatka peninsula. The warhead was recovered.

August 1985 An explosion devastated the Shkotovo-22 ship repair facility which services Soviet nuclear-powered vessels. Ten people were killed and many died later from radiation exposure.

October 1986 A nuclear-armed submarine caught fire and sank 600 miles east of Bermuda. A Russian scientist later claimed that nuclear warheads broke open, spewing plutonium-239 into the Atlantic.

April 1989 The Komsomolets, a Mike class nuclear-powered attack submarine sank in the Barents sea with the loss of 42 lives after a fire.

September 1991 A missile misfired on a Typhoon class nuclear-powered submarine in the northern White Sea during a training exercise. The submarine, armed with nuclear missiles and torpedoes, returned to base safely.

June 1992 An explosion killed an officer and injured four crewmen while a nuclear submarine was being repaired on the Kola peninsula in northern Russia.

November 1992 A nuclear submarine caught fire while under repair in the Arctic port of Murmansk.

March 1993 A Delta-3 class nuclear-powered ballistic missile submarine, operating in the Barents sea, was struck by the US nuclear-powered submarine USS Grayling. Both returned to base.

Summer 1993 An accident in a nuclear submarine killed 21 sailors and injured two more, but navy commanders tried to cover it up.

March 1994 Two Russian submarines with nuclear weapons on board grazed each other during an exercise in the Barents sea.

September 1995 Mains electricity to nuclear submarines was cut off, causing a cooling system on one vessel to break down. It took emergency measures to stop its reactor from overheating.

January 1998 An accident on board a nuclear-powered submarine at an Arctic base in Listafjord, on the Kola peninsula, released toxic fumes that killed a naval officer and injured four sailors. There was no radiation leak.

The US navy has also lost nuclear submarines at sea. In April 1963, the USS Thresher went down in 8,500 feet of water, 220 miles east of Boston. Five years later the USS Scorpion sank when a torpedo malfunctioned; all its crew were killed. In March 1986, the USS Nautilus ran aground in the Irish sea and was retired from service.

The Royal Navy has suffered no serious accidents to its nuclear submarine fleet, although HMS Tireless has been undergoing repairs in Gibraltar since May after its cooling system developed a leak.

fields.headline: Journey to the bottom of the sea - how Russians plunged to disaster
fields.trailText: High up in the Arctic circle where the sun barely sets at this time of the year, the long-suffering sailors of the Russian navy had a few reasons to be uncharacteristically cheerful this weekend after years of shambles, accidents, underfunding and neglect.
fields.body:
High up in the Arctic circle where the sun barely sets at this time of the year, the long-suffering sailors of the Russian navy had a few reasons to be uncharacteristically cheerful this weekend after years of shambles, accidents, underfunding and neglect.

The sailors of the northern fleet, based at Severomorsk near Murmansk, were finally at sea, putting their cruisers, submarines, and destroyers through the most ambitious exercises in the area in years.

They started on Friday just as President Vladimir Putin was pledging radical reform of the military at a crucial meeting of the top brass in the Kremlin. "How can things be optimal when our sailors barely put to sea," the president told the security council session.

But Captain Gennadiy Lyachin had just put to sea. The 45-year-old career navy officer and submarine commander has dedicated his adult life, 22 years, to the northern fleet, advancing through the ranks, being decorated a couple of times, and taking charge of the Kursk, the five-year-old nuclear-powered Oscar-II class submarine based in Zapadnaya Litsa, close to Murmansk.

The Kursk is the flagship of its submarine division, capable of carrying 24 seven-tonne cruise missiles with either nuclear or conventional warheads. The missiles have a range of up to 550 km. Capt Lyachin commanded a crew of 106 men, most of them navy professionals.

On Friday and Saturday the three-day northern exercises were believed to be going well, with 33 surface vessels and submarines as well as 40 aeroplanes and helicopters taking part. Sunday was August 13th. "The 13th is always a bad day for sailors," said another navy captain who asked not to be named. "We don't have any cabins numbered 13."

Some time on Sunday morning, disaster struck Capt Lyachin and his crew. Around 100 miles north-east of Murmansk and west of the Russian nuclear proving ground of Novaya Zemlya, the Kursk went down with all hands on board, according to the Norwegian defence ministry.

"It's not clear what happened," said an unnamed navy officer. "But whatever it was, it must have been very sudden. The first thing a commander does in an emergency like that is get the sub up to the surface and then switch off the nuclear reactors. In a situation like that the reactor is your salvation. The crew must have been helpless. Now it's a very negative situation."

Emergency

Valeriy Danilyan, a naval safety expert who served nine years on submarines, said: "No nuclear-powered vessel goes to the bottom except in an extreme emergency."

Alexander Nikitin, the ex-navy whistle-blower whom Mr Putin has been trying to jail for his revelations about Russian radiation leaks into Arctic waters, said: "The crew failed to cope with the situation."

The unnamed captain said the Kursk suddenly lost radio contact with the command point for the exercises, though communications were said to have been re-established last night when the Kolokol rescue vessel submerged more than 300 feet to the Barents sea-bed to survey the condition of the stricken sub and attempt to bring in fuel and oxygen supplies for the trapped crew.

In a pessimistic, if perhaps premature assessment of the tragedy, the navy chief, Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, said there was little chance of salvaging the crippled submarine, raising the possibility that the two nuclear reactors which fuel the 500ft long vessel may be left to leak their lethal payload into the bed of the Arctic.

The Kursk is the pride of the northern fleet, which has seven such submarines. It last underwent dry dock repairs and inspection in January 1998, said the well-informed captain.

If the submarine has been flooded, potentially doubling its 14,000-tonne weight, said the experts, it will be virtually impossible to raise. NTV television news quoted Russian navy sources as saying that the prow was flooded when the torpedo hatches failed to close.

But the flooding scenario was last night shifting to the more menacing variant of an underwater crash with another submarine. There was also the possibility that it had been hit by friendly fire.

That the hull and bow were dented, according to first reports from the salvage crews on the scene, supported the crash theory. That the conning tower was also said to have been hit suggested that any collision occurred under water.

The crash could have knocked out the ship's systems, triggered an emergency shutdown of the two reactors, and very quickly plunged the vessel to the sea bed, said the experts.

According to the Russians, any crash with another vessel taking part in the manoeuvres would have been promptly verified by the military. There was speculation about a collision with a Nato craft in the area to monitor the manoeuvres. "Can't be ruled out," northern fleet officers told the Interfax new agency.

But British officials said there were no UK vessels in the area. In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman, Rear Admiral Craig Quigley, said: "We have no indication that a US vessel was involved in this accident."

Officer Danilyan said the Kursk, which can descend to more than 1,500 feet and can operate autonomously for four months, has life support systems for two months. "There is no chance of radioactive leaks unless the reactors are destroyed," he declared. "If there is no fire and no smoke, the depth of 110 metres is nothing terrible."

The big fear among northern fleet officers last night was that the crew of the Kursk would be unable to get out because the escape hatches had been jammed during the accident.

It was unclear whether the submarine has escape capsules on board. "The men train regularly for this eventuality," said the unnamed captain.

Naval experts said that the greatest hope for the crew would have been to block off the front half of the submarine, which is dedicated to living quarters and weapons systems. If the living area could be sealed off in time, an operation regarded as very difficult to pull off, the crew could survive for several days.

The more likely hope would be that some crew reached escape compartments. There they could survive for several days, depending on their oxygen supplies, pressure in the compartment and the concentration of carbon dioxide in the air.

"It would be very, very dark and exceedingly frightening inside," said Commander David Perfect, a member of the UK Submarine Rescue Service. "Potentially the crew could be quite panicky. Whether or not they survive may well depend on the strength of the man leading them."

They started on Friday just as President Vladimir Putin was pledging radical reform of the military at a crucial meeting of the top brass in the Kremlin. "How can things be optimal when our sailors barely put to sea," the president told the security council session. But Captain Gennadiy Lyachin had just put to sea. webTitle: DNA tests will reveal Kirsty's killer, say Thai police

fields.headline: DNA tests will reveal Kirsty's killer, say Thai police
fields.trailText: The body of British backpacker Kirsty Jones was on the way back to Britain today, as Thai police announced they were confident of identifying her killer.
fields.body:
The body of British backpacker Kirsty Jones was on the way back to Britain today, as Thai police announced they were confident of identifying her killer.

The painted wooden coffin containing the 23-year-old's body was collected by a British embassy official from the northern Thai hill resort of Chiang Mai this morning. It will be driven to Bangkok and put on a flight to the UK tomorrow.

As the investigation into her death continues, Thai police have said they know who her killer is and are waiting for DNA testing to confirm their suspicions.

The body of Miss Jones, from Tredomen in south Wales, was found in her hostel room at the Aree guest house last Thursday. She was lying half-naked and face down on her bed with her sarong wrapped around her neck.

An autopsy showed her neck was bruised where it had been squeezed with a piece of cloth until she could not breathe.

Police have taken samples and blood from eight suspects - six tourists and two locals - but the results of blood-group testing failed to narrow down the list of suspects. However police were certain DNA tests would identify the killer.

Police have also revealed that her body was discovered five hours earlier than previously thought. A maid who said she had found Kirsty's body at 4pm on Thursday has now admitted she was "leaned upon" by guest house manager Surin Channet to give a false statement.

In her fresh witness statement, the maid told police that Mr Channet stumbled across the body shortly after 2pm. Mr Channet yesterday admitted having "sat upon the problem," although he denies having discovered the body on his own.

The discovery that several residents secretly knew of the murder hours before police were alerted comes as police announced they were sure Kirsty's killer was staying at the guest house.

Senior officers believe the killer was known to the Liverpool University graduate.

Among those being questioned is Andrew Gill, 32, from Northern Ireland, the owner of the Aree hostel. He was arrested on Saturday and questioned about Kirsty's death and is now being held over alleged visa offences.

An Australian guest at the hostel, Stuart Crichton, 28, is also being questioned over the death. All eight suspects have denied murder and none has asked for a lawyer. Thai police said a "firm arrest" would be made within 10 days.

fields.headline: Iron coffin
fields.standfirst:
A Russian vessel lies on the seabed with 107 men on board. It's every submariner's nightmare, says former Royal Navy officer Narendra Sethia

Special report: Stricken Russian submarine
fields.trailText: A Russian vessel lies on the seabed with 107 men on board. It's every submariner's nightmare, says former Royal Navy officer  Narendra Sethia
fields.body:
The accident that has befallen the Russian Oscar-class submarine Kursk, 480ft beneath the surface of the Barents Sea, is the ultimate nightmare upon which every submariner reflects at some stage during the course of his career - and, in many cases, long after he has retired.

Until the second half of this century, few submarines were fitted with escape equipment as it was believed that, given the operating circumstances of a submarine, such equipment would be superfluous. But in later years, the powers-that-be bowed to public pressure and fitted submarines with escape hatches, making a great show of conducting escape training exercises, though most submariners will tell you that they had little confidence of survival in the event of a serious accident at any appreciable depth. An escape tower might be handy when you're in a depth of 100ft in the North Sea, but when a submarine is more likely to be operating in the deeper waters of the Atlantic, Pacific, or Arctic, it is more likely to be regarded as a useful storage compartment than as a viable means of escape.

I first read the book Das Boot, which chronicles the missions of a German U-boat during the second world war, while serving on a nuclear submarine about 20 years ago. I could not sleep for several nights, and had recurring dreams that our "boat" was on the bottom, 500ft down, and unable to surface. In my dreams, men lay perspiring in their bunks and their only sounds were whispered words and fear. In my dreams, all machinery had been shut down, and I could hear condensation dripping off the maze of pipework, and electrical wiring sparking in the darkness. Today, with the Kursk nearly 500ft down and reportedly seriously damaged after an unspecified collision, the 107 men on board must be feeling, awake, what I could only feel in my dreams.

In Das Boot, of course, the submarine in question was of 1940s design. The Kursk, by contrast, is a modern (launched 1995), 14,000-tonne nuclear-powered submarine which bears little resemblance to the "boats" of that era. Air-conditioning, movies and good food are all features of modern submarines, and, with water-making equipment on board, submariners are even able to enjoy regular showers - something unheard of 40 years ago (or even 20 years ago on a diesel-powered submarine).

Nevertheless, despite the amenities, life on board any submarine is still cramped by most people's standards. There may not be sufficient bunks for every crew member and, on one long patrol, I remember we carried so much food that we had to use every inch of deck space and effectively raise the level of the deck by two feet. We were able to stand upright only after we had eaten our way through the food.

The cramped conditions and the fact that a submariner's only "view" of the outside world is by means of electronic listening devices, intensifies one's feeling of isolation. There are no windows through which to peer, no sun or sky at which to look. All that the men on the Kursk can see are the instruments, machinery and pipework which surround them, and the anxious looks on the faces of their colleagues.

The fact that the Kursk has not apparently attempted to surface reinforces the fears that her damage must be serious. The possibilities include damaged propulsion systems; ruptured ballast tanks, which would prevent her from achieving positive buoyancy; and flooding, as the result of collision or other mishap. With her nuclear reactor shut down, Kursk may not be able to operate air purification equipment such as electrolysers, which produce oxygen, or scrubbers, which eliminate carbon dioxide. The air will grow stale. As carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide levels rise, the crew will develop severe headaches. I have experienced that, and even remember being unable to light a match on account of low oxygen levels. But I, at least, was not sitting at the bottom of the Barents Sea.

At 480ft, the submarine is subjected to extreme pressure. Without the assistance of a DSRV (deep submergence rescue vehicle) or a diving bell which could withstand the stresses encountered at that depth, escape will be all but impossible. The US Navy's DSRVs are incompatible with non-US submarines and it is unlikely that the Russians have similar technology. The tragic reality is that the Kursk is likely to become an iron coffin, the name by which submarines have been known for nearly a century.

Twenty years ago the cold war was alive and well, and Russia was "the enemy". As I think of the Kursk now, I do not see her crew as Russians but as fellow submariners.

The close-knit community of submariners signifies a profession in which, even in war, there is no gulf of nationality or language, but a singularity of human spirit which transcends such borders. My heart goes out to every member of the Kursk's crew, and to every one of their relatives. I feel sure that all other submariners, the world over, will feel the same as I do.

 Narendra Sethia served on HMS Conqueror

fields.headline: Leicester City
fields.trailText: When an emotional Martin O'Neill finally tore himself away from Filbert Street, many Leicester fans feared that three of their best players - Matt Elliot, Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon - would go with him. They didn't however, all three choosing instead to sign new contracts at Filbert Street. This is great news for Leicester and no small tribute to the talents of new manager Peter Taylor.
fields.body:
When an emotional Martin O'Neill finally tore himself away from Filbert Street, many Leicester fans feared that three of their best players - Matt Elliot, Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon - would go with him. They didn't however, all three choosing instead to sign new contracts at Filbert Street. This is great news for Leicester and no small tribute to the talents of new manager Peter Taylor.

Neil Lennon admitted as much after finally deciding to stay last week. "I have been very impressed with Peter full stop since he has come in," he said. "Obviously Matty and Muzzy signing the new contracts, and the five lads we have brought in has shown to me that the club is not a selling club anymore."

The proverbial hard-up provincial club throughout the 90s, Leicester are now suddenly awash with cash, thanks to the sale of Emile Heskey and a lucrative £12.5m deal with NTL. So far Taylor has spent £10m -more than Manchester United, Liverpool and Aston Villa - on five lower division players: Gary Rowett, Callum Davidson, Simon Royce, Trevor Benjamin and Ade Akinbiyi. Most of them lack experience at the top level, and how they perform will say a lot about Taylor's judgement - and his coaching ability.

It's hard to draw too many assumptions from pre-season friendlies, but from what we've seen it's not unreasonable to expect Taylor smooth the Foxes rough edges, and get them playing the same enterprising and insightful football his England U-21's and Gillingham sides were noted for. There could also be a change of formation. During Leicester's final friendly against RKC Waalwijk, Taylor started with 4-4-2, with Rowett, Elliott, Walsh and Davidson in the back four, Collymore and Akinbiyi up front and Darren Eadie on the wing. Yet - ever versatile - he switched to 3-5-2 at half-time.

The only worry for Leicester fans must be their front line. Collymore is brilliantly erratic; Akinbiyi is pacy, powerful and profligate; and Benjamin is big and bustling but very raw. Goals could be a problem - and they have been in pre-season - but the Foxes have enough quality elsewhere to maintain their mid-table position.

In Gary Rowett (Birmingham), Callum Davidson (Blackburn), Simon Royce (Charlton), Trevor Benjamin (Cambridge), Ade Akinbiyi (Wolves)

Out Pegguy Arphexad (Liverpool), Fernando Pasquinelli (Boca Juniors), John Hodges (Plymouth), Theo Zagorakis (AEK Athens), Ian Marshall (QPR)

Odds 250-1

fields.headline: Film council fingers flop-makers
fields.trailText: In an audit carried out by the British Film Council under Alan Parker (pictured), three British film studios that have received over £100m of lottery money between them yet have failed to produce a single box-office success, have been condemned
fields.body:
In an audit carried out by the British Film Council under chairman Alan Parker, three British film studios that have received over £100m of lottery money between them yet have failed to produce a single box-office success, have been condemned.

The Sunday Times reported that one studio in particular, The Film Consortium (TFC), was singled out for attack, and was warned that it risked losing its franchise if it continued to release box-office flops. A recent TFC film, Janice Beard: 45 wpm (pictured) which starred Rhys Ifans and Patsy Kensit, was critically condemned as "grimly unfunny" and "bad almost beyond belief", and even the A-list appeal of Kate Winslet failed to make 1998's Hideous Kinky a success.

The three studios were chosen from 34 rival bidders in 1997 to receive lottery funding. The other two studios fared slightly better in the report. Pathé produced Ratcatcher which, although critically acclaimed, didn't have the pulling power required for box-office success.

DNA Films, which produced the hugely successful Notting Hill for an American studio with American money, was accused of using its lottery money for funding films with little popular appeal.

Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said: "There may be a role for lottery funding of films but nobody has cracked the problem of how to run it. Good films don't need it, while films that nobody wants to see do not deserve it."

fields.headline: Loyalist terrorist escapes bomb attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A former loyalist terrorist leader survived a murder attempt early today when a pipe bomb exploded on his car. Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, former commander of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, escaped with minor cuts and bruising.
fields.body:
A former loyalist terrorist leader survived a murder attempt early today when a pipe bomb exploded on his car. Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, former commander of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, escaped with minor cuts and bruising.

The attack happened on Beechpark Street in the Protestant side of the Oldpark district in north Belfast at 12.30am. Mr Adair had just parked his Proton car and was about to get out to talk to a group of loyalists when the assailants drew up alongside him in a vehicle and threw the device, shattering the windscreen.

"He's very, very lucky to be alive," said John White of the UFF's political wing, the Ulster Democratic party. Army bomb disposal experts later recovered the remains of a pipe bomb from the scene. Mr White said: "If that device had landed inside the car, there's no doubt everyone inside would have been killed."

Mr Adair has survived numerous past attempts on his life. He was the IRA's intended target when it bombed a fish shop on the Shankill Road in Belfast in 1993, killing nine Protestants and one of the bombers.

He was jailed for directing terrorism but was released from prison early under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement. The device used in today's attack is a weapon usually associated with loyalist terrorists but Mr White blamed republican paramilitaries for the attack.

He said: "The pipe bomb has been sophisticated by the IRA in the form of drogue bombs and coffee jar bombs. I believe the reason they used a pipe bomb is that a gun can be traced back, whereas anyone can make a pipe bomb."

Last week the RUC warned Mr Adair that republicans would attempt to kill him, Mr White said. webTitle: Briton dies in Australia bus crash

fields.headline: Briton dies in Australia bus crash
fields.trailText: A British backpacker was killed and four other Britons were injured when their bus collided with a four-wheel-drive vehicle as they returned from a vegetable-picking trip in Queensland, Australia.
fields.body:
A British backpacker was killed and four other Britons were injured when their bus collided with a four-wheel-drive vehicle as they returned from a vegetable-picking trip in Queensland, Australia.

According to unconfirmed reports, one of the 12 passengers on board the minibus - a New Zealand woman - told local police she had survived the Childers hostel fire in which 15 people died.

Ten people, including two Irish nationals, were injured in the crash which killed Jason Walsh, 28, of Redruth, Cornwall, and another man instantly. The accident happened on the Bruce Highway, the main road along the coastline in northern Queensland.

"A minibus with 12 overseas tourists and one Australian driver was travelling on the Kirknie Road and was approaching the intersection with the Bruce Highway when the crash happened," a police official said. "A four-wheel drive was travelling north on the highway. The minibus was coming in from an adjacent road. It turned on to the highway and the two collided."

Six of the more seriously injured were taken to Townsville hospital suffering mostly broken bones. The rest of the injured, suffering mainly from bruises, were sent to a hospital in Ayr. Four British tourists - two male and two female - plus two women from Ireland were among the injured.

Backpackers from Canada, New Zealand and Korea, as well as the Australian driver, also needed treatment. Three of the British tourists are in a "stable condition" in intensive care at Townsville general hospital, police said.

The spokeswoman said: "Two English females, both aged 23, are at Townsville hospital. One woman, who is from Kent, has a pelvic fracture. The other woman has numerous injuries including internal injuries, back injuries and a fractured pelvis. A 25-year-old English male has a fractured pelvis and a broken leg."

The fourth English survivor, a 27-year-old male who suffered scratches and cuts, was released earlier from a hospital in Ayr. The Irish women, a 21-year-old from Limerick and a 20-year-old from Tipperary, who suffered cuts and bruises, were both being released today from the hospital in Ayr.

Mr Walsh's parents said their music-mad son had saved up for years for the trip of his lifetime. Jason, aged 28, had travelled out to Australia with his girlfriend Teresa Broglino for a 12-month trip.

Jason's father, Ian, 60, said: "They went out on May 30 and they were going to be there for 12 months. He planned it with his girlfriend and she was there as well but she was not on the bus because she had gone shopping.

"It is one of those things that happens to someone else. There had been other things recently like the fire in the hostel and it did cross my mind that something could happen."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Each and every piece of gossip picked up, put in a back pocket and sat on
fields.trailText: Manchester United have contacted Steve McManaman over a move to Old Trafford, according to the Sun. The England winger has not given a final response to the offer the paper reports, preferring to wait until United make a firm bid. How McManaman, who claims Liverpool is the only English club for him, would feel about playing for their deadly rivals is left unexplained.
fields.body:
Manchester United have contacted Steve McManaman over a move to Old Trafford, according to the Sun. The England winger has not given a final response to the offer the paper reports, preferring to wait until United make a firm bid. How McManaman, who claims Liverpool is the only English club for him, would feel about playing for their deadly rivals is left unexplained.

Spanish sports daily AS offers a more plausible assessment however. They claim three Serie A sides, Parma, Lazio and Fiorentina, are interested in McManaman as well as a number of Premiership clubs.

The Daily Mail reports that Gianluca Vialli will allow Albert Ferrer to leave Chelsea to the highest bidder. The paper believes his most likely destination will be Barcelona in part-exchange for Dutch winger Boudewijn Zenden, whose £8m move to the Blues looked more likely this morning after his father admitted: "Chelsea have contacted us and Boudewijn would like to play in the Premiership. That looks like a very real possibility now."

Valencia have offered Newcastle £5m for Didier Domi according to the Daily Mail. Bobby Robson may reluctantly part with the highly-rated fullback in order to finance a move for Wimbledon's Jason Euell.

The Sun also claims that Robson will attempt to strengthen his central defence by making one last bid for Deportivo La Coruna's Helder. The Portuguese international was on loan at St James' Park last season, but Robson has previously been unwilling to match Deportivo's transfer valuation of £6m.

Bordeaux have told Arsenal that the only way to sign Sylvain Wiltord is to pay £15m for him. "Offering £8m and then £13m for a striker like Wiltord is not enough", Bordeaux president Jean-Louis Triaud said. "I might as well make a £10m bid for Patrick Vieira."

Tottenham are ready to bid £4m for Norwich striker Craig Bellamy, according to the Mirror. Director of football David Pleat said, "He is a very good player and the sort of player we are interested in, but I can't say any more right now."

Gareth Southgate will stay at Aston Villa. The England international demanded a transfer from Villa Park earlier this summer but claims the club's £8m valuation put off potential suitors. "I know there have been enquiries about me," Southgate said, "but the price has been too high."

Middlesbrough are interested in Australian midfielder Simon Colosimo. The victim of a notorious challenge from Andy Cole in a pre-season friendly a year ago, he would cost Bryan Robson £600,000.

Wimbledon have agreed a £2.5m fee for Everton defender Richard Dunne. The Daily Mail claims the 20-year-old will travel to London for talks today.

fields.headline: Korean families reunited after 50 years
fields.trailText: A hundred North Koreans today embraced and wept with southern relatives whom they had not seen for 50 years in the latest gesture of reconciliation between Seoul and Pyongyang.
fields.body:
A hundred North Koreans today embraced and wept with southern relatives whom they had not seen for 50 years in the latest gesture of reconciliation between Seoul and Pyongyang.

The elderly North Koreans were ushered into a giant hall at a Seoul convention centre where relatives were waiting and the highly charged scenes were broadcast live on televison.

"Mother, be calm. Your son is here," a 68-year-old man told his 95-year-old mother, who was so overcome with emotion that a nurse rushed to her side to take her blood pressure. Another distraught man knelt on the floor and repeatedly bowed to his father, who sat in a wheelchair, too weak to respond.

There were shouts of "My sweetheart! " and "My brother!". Men and women clutched each other, weeping and wailing. They consoled each other with pats on the back and offered handkerchiefs to wipe away tears. Some were quiet, sad and pensive.

When emotions cooled, the relatives exchanged family stories and looked at old photo albums. Family reunions are among the most emotional issues on the peninsula, with many ageing family members having only a few years left to see relatives. Many people have died without making contact. There is no mail, telephone or other direct means of communication between private citizens in the two Koreas.

Today's emotional family reunion marked the latest sign of reconciliation since the Korean War of 1954 - the two nations are still technically at war. A rapprochement between north and south accelerated after their leaders held a summit in June and pledged to work towards eventual reunification.

While South Korea chose its 100 finalists for the reunions through a computer lottery, the North Korean list included a renowned poet, a painter, a film-maker, a scientist and other celebrated people. All the northern visitors are natives of South Korea who defected to the North.

When the North Koreans arrived, their plane picked up 100 South Koreans for a similar exchange.

On arriving in Pyongyang, the South Korean delegation chief, Chang Chung-shik, said: "I hope these reunions will not stop as a one-time event and will continue so that the day will come when dispersed family members in the two sides can go and come freely."

The head of the North Korean delegation, 78-year-old Yoo Mi Young, said, on arriving in Seoul, that more reunions would follow.

"I hope this development will help break down the wall of confrontation and division," said Mrs Yoo, who defected to North Korea from the south in 1986 along with her husband, former South Korean foreign minister Choi Duk Shin. He died in 1989. The 100 North Koreans were accompanied by 31 officials and 20 journalists.
