webTitle: Why Orson Welles is Hollywood's latest hot property

fields.headline: Back from the dead
fields.standfirst: Orson Welles may have died 15 years ago - but that hasn't stopped him from becoming Hollywood's latest hot property. Is it just another Tinseltown fad or is he finally getting the recognition he deserves?
fields.trailText: Orson Welles may have died 15 years ago - but that hasn't stopped him from becoming Hollywood's latest hot property. Is it just another Tinseltown fad or is he finally getting the recognition he deserves?
fields.body:
For a man who has been dead these past 15 years, George Orson Welles seems more than commonly busy. Like Elvis, Dick Nixon and Tupac, his ubiquity seems to increase the longer he spends in the grave. In recent years we have had the wonderful restored version of Touch Of Evil, while his planned film about the staging of The Cradle Will Rock eventually spawned Tim Robbins's Welles-bashing movie.

He's been more sympathetically treated in Tim Burton's Ed Wood (very briefly) and RKO 281, well played by Liev Schrieber. Best of all is Pinky And The Brain, the cartoon about a Wellesian lab mouse who tries to take over the world: any doubts about the Brain's inspiration were brushed away by an episode based on The Third Man.

The latest, and in some ways strangest, dead Orson moment is the mini-series adaptation of The Magnificent Ambersons about to start shooting in Dublin.

Rather than going back to Booth Tarkington's novel, the series will use the script for the 1942 film, thus including the scenes lost when RKO excised and destroyed 44 minutes of the picture that Welles believed was "much better than Kane".

The story is central to the Welles myth, because the film was particularly close to Welles's heart, and oddly prophetic. The Magnificent Ambersons was made as the commercial failure of Citizen Kane became clear. Despite the disappointment of that film's reception, Welles was still the great prodigy, only 26. He thought The Magnificent Ambersons, which was about love and families, might have a better chance of success with the public. And although it stuck closely to Tarkington's novel, the film is hugely autobiographical.

The character played by Joseph Cotton is an inventor involved in the early days of the car industry, as was Welles's father. But that's just the taster: the key character is a boy called George - like Welles, utterly and totally indulged by his parents - like Welles, with the result that he eventually destroys his mother's one chance at true happiness. The townsfolk spend their time waiting for the arrogant George Amberson Minafer's "comeuppance"; in his Welles biography Rosebud, David Thomson entitles the section following 1942, "Comeuppance". The film is full of wisdom about the folly of youth, about the sad inability of 40 to teach 20 anything. The irony of the film being made by a 26 year old with a raging ego wasn't lost on everybody: Welles's own painful path to wisdom, was just around the corner.

Towards the end of post-production in 1942, with a rough cut finished, Welles went to Brazil to work on the never-completed It's All True. While he was having a fine old time with the Rio carnival girls, RKO were panicking at test-screening reactions to The Magnificent Ambersons. "People like to laff, not be bored to death", read one comment. So RKO had the film re-edited to make it less gloomy, giving it a slighty less unhappy end at the cost of what legend has it were the most affecting scenes Welles ever filmed. The missing footage was disposed of. The bowdlerised film was still a flop, Welles's masterpiece was permanently damaged and his career started its steady downward slide.

Which is where the mini-series comes in. "What we now want to do is complete our homage and obligation to Welles", claims RKO's Ted R Hartley, to which Welles would probably reply, it's a bit late. Nevertheless, the mini-series is a respectable project, directed by Alfonso Arau (Like Water For Chocolate) and with a strong cast that includes Madeleine Stowe, Jennifer Tilly, James Cromwell, and Jonathan Rhys-Myers. There is no reason to think it won't be good. But sticking to Welles's script - if they really do - would be a mistake.

What made Welles's film great - and even the hacked-up version is outstanding - was the cast, the cinematography, the direction. As Arau is unlikely to use vintage cameras, or have his actors act in the style of the original cast, or pace the series like a movie from the 1940s, the new Ambersons will tell us nothing about those reportedly peerless lost 44 minutes. All it proves is that Welles - who when he was alive was offered nothing but sherry ads and guest spots on bad TV shows - is hot in Hollywood in a way he hasn't been since he arrived with a fanfare in 1939.

A final thought: just in case you thought the vandalism inflicted on The Magnificent Ambersons belonged in the past, it was just last year that the filmmaker-friendly FilmFour managed to destroy the outtakes from Peter Mullan's excellent Orphans. Mr Welles would surely raise a sardonically amused eyebrow at how little has changed.

fields.headline: WPP reports first half £1.2bn
fields.standfirst:
Revenge of the traditional companies as advertising industry continues to boom

Net news
fields.trailText: Revenge of the traditional companies as advertising industry continues to boom
fields.body:
The boom experienced by the advertising industry on the back of the emergent new economy showed little sign of faltering yesterday when marketing services group WPP turned in revenues of £1.2bn for the first half of the year.

Despite waning investor confidence in the internet sector, WPP, which owns the J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather advertising networks, said online-related business continued to grow at dramatic speed. Internet-related revenues now account for 15% of turnover - a third higher than the previous year.

WPP chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell said he had noted greater churn among internet-related clients but said there was still considerable demand, particularly among business-to-business websites.

He also noted a new phenomenon and said the group had begun to benefit from the "bricks and mortar" brands fighting back.

"You could call it the revenge of the traditional companies," he said. "I think many of them have scented the weakness among internet companies, particularly business-to-consumer, and they have increased their marketing spend. It doesn't seem to matter which way or whence it comes, we still do well."

The company has continued to invest in internet businesses, including logistics group Metapack and Inferentia, an Italian web consultancy, during the first half.

"Warren Buffett once said buy into advertising agencies because they are a royalty on the growth of companies like Procter & Gamble," Sir Martin said. "In a sense we are also a proxy on the growth of the new economy."

Group revenues were 19% ahead of the same period last year, while pre-tax profits for the six months to June 30 were 22% higher at £137m, in line with City analysts expectations. Shares in WPP closed 2p higher at 910p. The group said prospects for the second half of the year looked equally good but Sir Martin warned that it would be unrealistic to believe that current growth rates in the advertising market would continue indefinitely. "This kind of growth is not unstoppable and you can't achieve rates of 15% organically for ever. But our business model works at rates of 5% or 10%. We have heavy flexibility built into our cost base."

WPP also owns the Hill and Knowlton public relations business, market research company, the Henley Centre, and design group Coley Porter Bell among others.

In May it agreed the £3.1bn acquisition of rival Young & Rubicam and Sir Martin said the group was likely to spend the next few years bedding the takeover down.

A clutch of smaller deals were done in the first half to buy businesses in countries including China, Israel, Italy, Poland and Spain.

Growth in the US which ac counts for just under half of WPP's business was 18.5%, while in Europe the figure reached 19.8%. The biggest growth however came in Asia and Latin America, which continued to rebound with a 28% improvement on the previous year.

WPP makes a distinction between "narrowly defined" web revenues and broad internet revenues, which includes brand building advertising campaigns in traditional media for internet companies.

The more narrowly defined figure confined to web-based work was $90m (£60m) for the first half - up from $30m last year.

He also noted a new phenomenon and said the group had begun to benefit from the "bricks and mortar" brands fighting back. "You could call it the revenge of the traditional companies," he said. "I think many of them have scented the weakness among internet companies, particularly business-to-consumer, and they have increased their marketing spend. It doesn't seem to matter which way or whence it comes, we still do well." The company has continued to invest in internet businesses, including logistics group Metapack and Inferentia, an Italian web consultancy, during the first half. "Warren Buffett once said buy into advertising agencies because they are a royalty on the growth of companies like Procter & Gamble," Sir Martin said. "In a sense we are also a proxy on the growth of the new economy." Group revenues were 19% ahead of the same period last year, while pre-tax profits for the six months to June 30 were 22% higher at £137m, in line with City analysts expectations. Shares in WPP closed 2p higher at 910p. The group said prospects for the second half of the year looked equally good but Sir Martin warned that it would be unrealistic to believe that current growth rates in the advertising market would continue indefinitely. "This kind of growth is not unstoppable and you can't achieve rates of 15% organically for ever. But our business model works at rates of 5% or 10%. We have heavy flexibility built into our cost base." WPP also owns the Hill and Knowlton public relations business, market research company, the Henley Centre, and design group Coley Porter Bell among others. In May it agreed the £3.1bn acquisition of rival Young & Rubicam and Sir Martin said the group was likely to spend the next few years bedding the takeover down. A clutch of smaller deals were done in the first half to buy businesses in countries including China, Israel, Italy, Poland and Spain. Growth in the US which ac counts for just under half of WPP's business was 18.5%, while in Europe the figure reached 19.8%. The biggest growth however came in Asia and Latin America, which continued to rebound with a 28% improvement on the previous year. WPP makes a distinction between "narrowly defined" web revenues and broad internet revenues, which includes brand building advertising campaigns in traditional media for internet companies. The more narrowly defined figure confined to web-based work was $90m (£60m) for the first half - up from $30m last year.

webTitle: Clinton bows out with a bang, not a whimper

fields.headline: Clinton bows out with a bang, not a whimper
fields.standfirst: If Bill Clinton had been allowed to stand for another term, America's first rock 'n' roll president would, of course, have been re-elected, writes Martin Kettle in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: If Bill Clinton had been allowed to stand for another term, America's first rock 'n' roll president would, of course, have been re-elected, writes Martin Kettle in Los Angeles
fields.body:
In American Rhapsody, his excellent new book on the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal, the writer Joe Eszterhas makes the case that Bill Clinton is not just the first rock 'n' roll US president, he is also the Mick Jagger of politics.

So it was wholly appropriate that last night, in the Staples Centre in Los Angeles, Bill Clinton's managers lifted, without apology, a gimmick from the most recent Rolling Stones tour. As the stage darkened and the audience sensed that the star's entrance was near, a video clicked on, modelled precisely on the one the Stones used to orchestrate their own entrance a year or so ago.

Down an extravagantly long hallway came the ageing legend, slowly walking nearer and nearer to the camera. Then, as the music grew louder and the cheering less restrained, the iconic figure almost seamlessly moved out of the video and on to the stage, a shamelessly theatrical entrance. The audience loved it. Jumping Bill Flash was back.

But Clinton is not only a rock star. He is also the central character in a political soap opera that has held America spellbound for almost eight years. At the end of the last series, Bill and Hillary and daughter Chelsea almost split apart. The defining shot of the final episode was of the strained, stiff, don't-be-fooled image of the three central characters walking across the White House lawn hand in hand, jaws set. Would they survive? Most thought not, but only time would tell.

Well, as in all durable soaps, the Clintons of course survived. And last night was the counterpoint to those grim endings in 1998, before Monica Lewinsky was written out of the script. As Clinton finished his speech, he was joined on stage by Hillary and Chelsea yet again. This time the strain was gone. It was all hugs and kisses and smiles. As another curtain falls, the Clintons will all live happily ever after - or maybe not.

Last night was Clinton's bid to be taken seriously. His speech to the first night of the Democratic convention was a plea to his detractors that his presidency was not, like Seinfeld, a show about nothing. On the contrary.

Clinton pitched his claims high. He was the figurehead of "the New Democratic agenda that has taken our country to new heights of prosperity, progress and peace." He clearly felt he had nothing to apologise for, and this time he apologised for nothing. In the hall, hundreds of delegates deliriously waved placards bearing an unequivocal tribute to this most ambiguous of politicians: "Thank you, President Clinton".

If you are one of those who simply cannot take Clinton seriously, this farewell speech was simply hot air on a torrid southern California evening. But if instead you are one of those who sees Clinton at least in part as he sees himself, as a politician who is engaged in a historic task of redefining and re-applying the progressive legacy of the twentieth century, then this valedictory speech was an irresistible mix of high seriousness and questionable aesthetics.

Clinton's speech made huge claims. Some of them were laundry list claims - inflation down, jobs up, crime down, educational achievement up, and a lot more. Some list.

Others were vintage rhetorical Clinton. "The stars have never shone more brightly on any people at any time". America was "more hopeful, more secure, more free" than at any time in its history. It was closer than ever to "the America of our dreams." For a man who is bowing out, it was extraordinarily confident stuff.

There were all the references to Al Gore than any Gore lieutenant could possibly have demanded, but you could not miss the fact that here was a master politician quitting at the top of his game. If he was allowed to stand for more than two terms, he would unquestionably be doing so, and all Al Gore's excellent qualities would be as nothing. And if he were standing, Clinton would, of course, be re-elected.

He ended as he began eight years ago, quoting the Fleetwood Mac number that became his theme song in the 1992 election. "Don't stop thinking about tomorrow." He is an impossibly tough act to follow, and Gore has an unenviable task on Thursday when arrives to claim the crown.

By then, Clinton will be far away. As Los Angeles awakes this morning, Clinton is already far away en route to Michigan and the symbolic handover to Gore. The great speech was yesterday, and as the next line of the Fleetwood Mac song says, yesterday's gone.

webTitle: Cork and Thorpe suffer pay cut

fields.headline: Cork and Thorpe suffer pay cut
fields.standfirst: In the latest instalment of wisden.com's gossip column, Charles de Lisle reveals how two of England's top players are missing out, explains why Barry Richards has done his last piece of commentary for Channel 4 this summer, and uncovers the shambolic truth behind the Under-15 World Cup winners
fields.trailText: England stars suffer pay cut
fields.body:
England stars suffer pay cut

Dominic Cork may have been responsible for England's best moment of the summer so far, but it has left him out of pocket. The player who was Man of the Match in the unbearably tight victory over West Indies at Lord's is suffering the indignity of a 15 per cent pay cut for his Test appearances. Cork's Test fee, as a non-contracted player, is £3,300 per match, a reduction of £600 on what he would have picked up before the introduction of central contracts. That's because the ECB has quietly abolished the traditional extra payments for experienced internationals - £300 for every 10 caps. Cork, with 29 caps, would have collected a supplement of £600 per match, making a total of £3,900.

Graham Thorpe, also selected for this week's fourth Test at Headingley, has even more reason to feel hard done by. He's having to put up with a whopping 30pc pay cut. Under the old arrangements, he would have been paid £4,800 per Test: the standard £3,300 plus £1,500 for his 58 caps.

For players such as Cork and Thorpe, it is a double whammy as they were both overlooked for England Test contracts, which are worth £20-50,000 for the season - with the experienced players at the upper end.

The ECB confirms that the supplements have been abolished but is reluctant to discuss the thinking behind the move. "We picked the bulk of the team and awarded them central contracts, "says a spokesman. "Anyone else that comes in is on a flat fee."

David Graveney, the chairman of selectors, is slightly more illuminating, arguing that "one of the principles of the central contracts is that contracts should be earned as rewards. They are an incentive for players to do well."

Cork's agent, Bob Louis, recognises the force of that argument, and says that Cork is "desperately keen" to be awarded a contract. Louis adds: "Dominic won't be disappointed about the cut in remuneration: he's just pleased to be back in the England side and getting other sorts of reward. But it's a strange way of conducting things. I'd feel more aggrieved if I was Graham Thorpe."

Barry Richards loses out in C4 musical chairs

As the England-West Indies series reaches its climax, Channel 4 is making an unexpected change in its commentary box. Ian Smith, the former New Zealand wicketkeeper, comes in for the fourth and fifth Tests, at the expense of Barry Richards. The great South Africa opener bowed out during the weekend's NatWest semi-finals and flew home to his adopted home, Perth, Australia, yesterday.

There's no suggestion whatsoever that Richards, who has done an excellent job this summer, has been fired. He was originally only hired for the two Zimbabwe Tests, but was then retained for the first three Windies Tests and the triangular one-day series after the match-fixing scandal claimed its first commentary box victim. Wasim Akram had been contracted by C4 for all the Windies Tests and the ODIs but had to resign over the Qayyum report's damning verdict on his alleged activities.

Smith's voice will not be new to C4 viewers: an experienced broadcaster, he was part of their team for the New Zealand Tests last summer, making a reasonable impression. Why has he been recalled? "He was a big hit last summer, with an excellent reading of the game" is the official line from C4's spokesman. Another factor is that Smith, 43, had been signed on a contract of at least two years, though he was not expected to feature this season, partly because of rugby commitments back home.

Now it seems that the temptation of witnessing the last two Tests in a thrilling series has proved irresistible. "Ian suddenly found a little window in his diary," explains a fellow C4 commentator. "Barry's disappointed he can't do more, but it'll be quite nice to have a new voice on air. We all thought Ian very good - earthy, quite humorous, observant and quite lively. He'd make quite strong criticisms of players, something the rest of us haven't always done."

The world champions who couldn't find a sponsor

The West Indies' surprise victory in the final of the Under-15 Costcutter World Challenge was the more remarkable given the side's almost total lack of experience in playing as a unit. Quite a few of the schoolboys who squeezed a two-wicket win over Pakistan at Lord's last Thursday were still virtual strangers to one another. They had first taken a cricket field together less than three weeks earlier.

On paper the Windies shouldn't have been able to beat Pakistan or South Africa, or to tie with pre-tournament favourites India. Not only did West Indies completely lack international experience, but their preparation was inferior and their financial backing minimal.

"We were the paupers of the tournament," says Gus Logie, coach of the West Indies Under-15s. "Finance is extremely difficult to find in the Caribbean - we've been pleading for a sponsor for a while - and we were poorly prepared: a lot of the other sides had been together much longer. Nobody expected us to do well, even at home."

The campaign got off to a bad start when the 10-day pre-tour training camp in Trinidad was largely washed out by rain, denying the young players assembled from various islands their first chance to play as a unit.

That had to wait until their first warm-up game in England, a heavy defeat by a Surrey youth team in which West Indies mustered only 90. At this stage, Logie was still fretting over his batting order: how was he to fit in four players accustomed to batting at three for their islands?

The Windies did quite well to enter a team in the World Challenge at all. There's not as much Under-15 cricket as in some other Test countries, the general standard is described by Logie as "inadequate", and the cost of flying in players from different islands is prohibitive.

To make matters worse Carib cement, sponsors of the annual Under-15 inter-island competition, pulled out last year, leaving the cash-strapped West Indies Cricket Board with heavy bills for this spring's contest.

With expenses like those, and the tab for the training camp, the board cannot afford to send its side to the international competitions where fledgling stars from India, Pakistan and elsewhere hone their games. "For us, "says Logie, "the Costcutter World Challenge is the only opportunity for our Under-15s to play outside the Caribbean." And most of the bills for that have been picked up by Costcutter, a northern supermarket group, and the ECB.

For the moment the "ecstatic" Logie is wearing the joyful smile familiar from his days as a counter-attacking West Indies batsman. "Our players showed huge strength of character and maturity," he says. "They've grown up so much in two weeks."

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Late learners
fields.standfirst: Universities are competing to attract mature students, as Graham Wade explains
fields.trailText: Universities are competing to attract mature students, as Graham Wade explains
fields.body:
Mature students with few or no formal qualifications are in demand as universities compete to keep their undergraduate lecture halls full.

Among the most proficient at recruiting these types of adult learner are the newer universities, particularly the former polytechnics, some of which have student bodies that boast a clear majority of over-21s. Derby University is a prime example, with almost a quarter of its undergraduates over 30.

Derby runs a modular access programme designed to prepare adults returning to education for admission to a degree course.

Rob Wood, adviser for mature students, explains: "The university shares the scheme with three local FE colleges and about 500 students pass out of it every year. Perhaps around 300 eventually find their way on to a degree, the majority enrolling at Derby."

To gain a place on Derby's access course, applicants usually have to be over 21. Apart from that there are no formal entry requirements. Like most access programmes up and down the country, there are core compulsory modules covering subjects such as study skills, communication and information technology, and further options.

"Roughly two-thirds of access students are women, many of them in their 30s with children in their teens. The men tend to be younger, somewhere in their 20s. Nearly 10% of Derby's undergraduates arrive through the access route, which is a significant proportion," Wood adds.

Northumbria University operates the higher education foundation course, which is available from Carlisle to Newcastle in about 10 further education colleges and four community high schools. Participants need to complete three modules to gain their national kitemarked access certificate, which should help them gain entry into most universities.

"Access courses like ours started in the early 1980s with an emphasis on providing subjects like humanities and social sciences. Later came an expansion into more vocational areas such as engineering and business studies. Our latest additions include fashion and heritage studies," says Nick Hall, head of Northumbria's access and continuing education service.

Each module requires about three hours a week spent at college, so a full-time student could reasonably expect to finish the whole course in a year. Part-timers usually complete in two years or less.

Luton University has traditionally welcomed mature students, who make up about half its numbers. Dave Kendall, head of access and admissions, says: "We offer a level-zero course, essentially a foundation programme for mature students, which guarantees progression on to an undergraduate scheme."

This programme has been particularly successful at recruiting participants from ethnic minorities. "About 40% of those on level zero fall into that category. Many from the Luton catchment come from the Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities, while those from north Bedfordshire tend to have Punjabi backgrounds," he says.

Nationally, the number of students taking access courses has grown almost uninterrupted since the 1980s.

As well as taking new undergraduates from access programmes, many universities are accepting a whole range of qualifications apart from GCSEs and A-levels. Some mature students are admitted on evidence of their work experience alone.

But a worrying division is emerging. The more established institutions take few students who are mature or who possess alternative qualifications. So, increasingly, the newer universities are magnets for older students and those from ethnic minorities, for instance, while those at the so-called top end of the market are dominated by the children of the white, professional middle class.

It looks like a trend that is bound to continue unless attitudes change.

Will to win

Jan Southern, 36, took an access course at Northumbria University, 1995-96, then a BSc in occupational therapy, 1996-99. She got a first.

I had identified a degree in occupational therapy that appealed to me, so I visited the university adult guidance centre for advice. They told me that the course had a lot of applicants and that to be admitted I would need to prove that I had the ability to study at that level.

Because I had left school at 15 without A-levels, they suggested I took an access course studying sociology, biology and psychology.

I felt the profession of occupational therapist was in line with my personal beliefs.

I had been disabled myself after the birth of my second child, when I hadn't been able to walk for a year and afterwards had limited mobility.

Sitting and listening for five days a week on the access programme was difficult, and so was writing essays, but I was driven by my desire to achieve.

I always managed to keep my eyes on the end goal. Managing my time was very problematic, especially with two children. It was probably the most demanding thing I've ever done in my life.

When I moved on to the degree, I expected it to be at least as academically demanding, but it wasn't. That was partly because it was a very work-based course with lots of clinical practice, which I particularly enjoyed.

I was aware that I was performing well during the degree and had gained distinctions for everything I'd done on the access course.

I think the degree enabled me to rediscover myself.

After I graduated I was lucky to find a job through one of the part-time lecturers, who also practised as an occupational therapist. It was maternity cover for Newcastle City Health Trust in the field of child and adolescent mental health.

After seven months, I moved to a senior post in a community scheme. The whole experience of returning to education has revolutionised my life.

The more established institutions take few students who are mature or who possess alternative qualifications. So, increasingly, the newer universities are magnets for older students and those from ethnic minorities, for instance, while those at the so-called top end of the market are dominated by the children of the white, professional middle class. It looks like a trend that is bound to continue unless attitudes change. Will to win Jan Southern, 36, took an access course at Northumbria University, 1995-96, then a BSc in occupational therapy, 1996-99. She got a first. I had identified a degree in occupational therapy that appealed to me, so I visited the university adult guidance centre for advice. They told me that the course had a lot of applicants and that to be admitted I would need to prove that I had the ability to study at that level. Because I had left school at 15 without A-levels, they suggested I took an access course studying sociology, biology and psychology. I felt the profession of occupational therapist was in line with my personal beliefs. I had been disabled myself after the birth of my second child, when I hadn't been able to walk for a year and afterwards had limited mobility. Sitting and listening for five days a week on the access programme was difficult, and so was writing essays, but I was driven by my desire to achieve. I always managed to keep my eyes on the end goal. Managing my time was very problematic, especially with two children. It was probably the most demanding thing I've ever done in my life. When I moved on to the degree, I expected it to be at least as academically demanding, but it wasn't. That was partly because it was a very work-based course with lots of clinical practice, which I particularly enjoyed. I was aware that I was performing well during the degree and had gained distinctions for everything I'd done on the access course. I think the degree enabled me to rediscover myself. After I graduated I was lucky to find a job through one of the part-time lecturers, who also practised as an occupational therapist. It was maternity cover for Newcastle City Health Trust in the field of child and adolescent mental health. After seven months, I moved to a senior post in a community scheme. The whole experience of returning to education has revolutionised my life.

webTitle: Car bomb attack on Ulster loyalist

fields.headline: Car bomb attack on Ulster loyalist
fields.trailText:
A leading loyalist survived a murder attempt early today when a pipe bomb exploded on his car.
 
Johnny Adair, former Ulster Freedom Fighters commander, escaped with minor cuts and bruising in the attack, said John White of the
group's political wing, the Ulster Democratic Party.
fields.body:
A leading loyalist survived a murder attempt early today when a pipe bomb exploded on his car. Johnny Adair, former Ulster Freedom Fighters commander, escaped with minor cuts and bruising in the attack, said John White of the group's political wing, the Ulster Democratic Party.

The attack happened on Beechpark Street in the Protestant side of the Oldpark district in north Belfast at 12.30am.

Mr Adair had just parked his Proton car and was about to get out to talk to a group of loyalists when would-be assassins drew up in a vehicle alongside him and threw the device, shattering the windscreen.

Mr White said: "He's very, very lucky to be alive."

webTitle: EU bans pig exports from England

fields.headline: EU bans pig exports from England
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Britain's farming industry suffered another blow yesterday when the European commission banned the export of English pigs to the continent with immediate effect in response to an outbreak of classical swine fever in East Anglia.
fields.body:
Britain's farming industry suffered another blow yesterday when the European commission banned the export of English pigs to the continent with immediate effect in response to an outbreak of classical swine fever in East Anglia.

Officials in Brussels said that they had been forced to act after they had discovered that the number of farms affected by the highly contagious disease was much greater than first thought.

"There were more and more holdings being reported to have swine fever and being suspected of swine fever. We had to do it as a precautionary measure," the commission's spokeswoman, Andrea Dahmen, said.

It is satisfied, however, that the outbreak is limited for the moment to East Anglia and stresses that swine fever does not pose any threat to human health.

The Europe-wide ban was agreed in consultation with the Ministry of Agriculture and will initially last until the end of this month.

It does not apply to exports of frozen pork destined for European supermarket shelves and will be reviewed by EU veterinary experts at a meeting on August 22.

It is, however, another serious blow to UK livestock farmers who are still struggling to rebuild their shattered European export market for beef which was destroyed in the wake of the BSE crisis.

British farmers will also be aware that an outbreak of swine fever in the Netherlands in 1997 led to the slaughter of up to 10m pigs and cost the Dutch government millions of pounds in compensation.

The ban will not apply to pigs from Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland which have so far been unaffected by the disease.

The government was quick last night to say that it was doing everything in its power to stamp out the disease. It has introduced strict restrictions on the movements of animals and infected pigs are immediately being slaughtered.

Belgium, the Netherlands and Spain had already said that they would no longer accept live pigs from Britain as a precautionary measure and the Belgian and Dutch authorities were the two countries pushing hardest for some kind of EU-wide action.

This is the first time the disease has appeared in Britain for 14 years and it is capable of rapidly spreading through a region's pig population.

Thousands of pigs have been slaughtered in an attempt to stop the disease from spreading and a six-mile surveillance zone has been established around the farms affected.

fields.headline: Schröder's incredible journey
fields.standfirst: What does Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's trail around eastern Germany say about the political relationship between the country's two parts? John Hooper reports from Berlin
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 4.45pm: What does Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's trail around eastern Germany say about the political relationship between the country's two parts? John Hooper reports from Berlin.
fields.body:
Fresh from a holiday in Mallorca, Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder will on Monday embark on what is - by any standards - a remarkable journey. Imagine for a moment, Tony Blair taking an entire fortnight out of his schedule to work his way around, say, Scotland or Wales. Unthinkable.

Yet that is much the same as what Mr Schröder will be doing when he tours eastern Germany until the beginning of September. The fact that he and his advisers think it necessary to mount a sort of safari through darkest eastern Germany speaks volumes about the relationship between the two parts of Germany almost 10 years after their reunification.

The treaty bringing east and west together again was signed in Berlin at the end of August 1990. It came into force on October 3 that year, adding five new Länder (regions) to the federation: Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt and Thuringia.

Part of Mr Schrder's aim is simply to commemorate that momentous event. But there is more to his visit than that. For a start, he is after votes. His Social Democratic party (SDP) still has shallow roots in the east. The results of the most recent regional elections in the east, held between April 1998 and September 1999, make the point.

For every two votes cast for the SDP, three were cast for its main rival, the Christian Democrat Union (CDU). And that was at a time when the Social Democrats were riding high - they won a general election during that period.

One reason for the SDP's relatively poor showing is that the party's leaders at the time of reunification were, at best, lukewarm about - and, at worst, openly hostile to - the reunification which eastern Germans then so keenly wanted.

It is ironic that, even though eastern Germans' enthusiasm for the project has become tinged since with hefty doses of cynicism and disillusion, they should have remained comparatively unenthusiastic about a party which warned loudly of the dangers.

But then the SPD has had competition from another left-wing party, the Democratic Socialist Party (PDS). Having grown out of the old east German communist party, the PDS is not at all like Mr Schröder's increasingly Blairite SDP. But it has a confusingly similar name and an appeal which the Social Democrats lack. It is home-grown.

With eastern Germans feeling increasingly sensitive about the erosion of their identity, the dismissal of their culture and the devastation of their economy since reunification, that has been a powerful lure. Even easterners who are not at all left-wing will vote for the PDS just to make a statement about being eastern.

In those same regional elections mentioned earlier, more than one in five of the votes cast went to the PDS. Indeed, the former communists won almost as much support as the SDP. In the rest of the country, backing for the PDS is negligible.

That is symptomatic of another reason why Mr Schröder's advisers feel he should be investing so much time and effort in the east: it remains an idiosyncratic - and, at times, troublesome - exception from the rest of the country.

In particular, the rate of unemployment is more than double that in the west and the level of far-right violence is much higher - phenomena which many see as cause and effect.

Though neo-Nazis have been known to turn on homeless, homosexual and handicapped people, it is when they murder immigrants that they are most likely to grab the headlines. That not only damages Germany's reputation abroad, casting doubt on the extent to which it has left behind its Nazi past, but risks becoming an immense obstacle for the new Länder in an era of globalisation.

Earlier this year, Mr Schröder opened the door to 20,000 foreign computer specialists by granting them temporary work permits. Overseas expertise is much in demand in Germany whose education system is not turning out the kind of information technology workers its 'new economy' requires.

Yet, such is the degree of prejudice in eastern Germany, foreigners - and particularly Black or Asian foreigners - are reluctant to sign up for a job there. It will take more than just a two week jaunt by the Chancellor at the end of the political recess, but the sooner that new Länder are made to feel that they really are a part of the new Germany, the better it will be for everyone.

webTitle: The tragic tale of the Cambodian child prostitutes

fields.headline: The tragic tale of the Cambodian child prostitutes
fields.standfirst: In Cambodia poverty forces girls as young as 12 into the sex trade. East Asia editor John Gittings meets people at the crisis centre that is fighting the battle against one of the worst forms of human exploitation
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 12.45pm: In Cambodia poverty forces girls as young as 12 into the sex trade. East Asia editor John Gittings meets people at the crisis centre that is fighting the battle against one of the worst forms of human exploitation.
fields.body:
The refuge run by the Cambodian Women's Crisis Center (CWCC) is tucked away down a small dirt lane in Phnom Penh, past houses on stilts with hammocks slung beneath. There is no sign on the high metal gate. "The brothel owners don't know we are here," explains a staff worker. "It's not like at our office. They know where that is and sometimes they turn up with guns."

The refuge had its full complement when I visited; 33 children and 37 mothers of whom 11 had been rescued from the brothels, eight from being raped, and the rest from domestic violence. Their stories were matter-of-fact tales of misery, only partly redeemed by their current safety.

Prakso Pheara was 16, from near the Vietnamese border. "My stepfather hit me and told my mother to sell me. They left me with a neighbour and a few days later the pimp came." She was fortunate in the first brothel. A Chinese client pitied her because she was beaten and paid enough money for her release. "I went back to my mother but she sold me again." Pok Pou, also from near the border - one of the poorest parts of Cambodia - was only 12 when she was sold by her mother. "My stepfather was sick and she needed the money."

The two girls are part of a cheerful small community, learning how to operate sewing machines in an airy workshop. Pheara wore a UN sweatshirt; Pou had a shirt with the word "Golfing" on the back. "They are just like normal teenagers," said Counsellor Bunna afterwards. "But, you know, they are both already HIV positive."

Sex exploitation of the young is a serious problem in many Asian countries with poor rural populations, but it is particularly bad in Cambodia with Vietnam now becoming a close second. Unicef in Phnom Penh has a project officer designated for "children in need of special protection".

The big increase, explains Brigitte Sonnois, came in the mid-1990s. The economy was opening up, tourism was returning to Phnom Penh but the rich-poor gap was widening with population pressure on the land. "Surveys in the open brothels show perhaps one-third below the age of 18, but we cannot survey the under-15s. There is an underground hidden trade for young virgins especially in demand by older Chinese men, both locally and from the region."

It is hard to judge the proportion of those whose families connive in the traffic and those who are lured to the towns with promises of jobs. But the majority are sold through intermediaries already known to the family - a relative or a neighbour.

"The low status of women is definitely a factor," says Ms Sonnois. The only reason now why public attention is beginning to be focused on the problem is because of HIV-Aids. The rate of infection of married women, whose husbands have been to the brothels, is now very high.

Chanthol Oung, executive director of the CWCC, believes that Cambodia has a particular problem because of the breakdown of social cohesion after the horrors of the Khmer Rouge perpetrated between 1975 and 79. "Before the war," she says, "prostitution existed but was not open. People who resorted to prostitutes were thought of as bad; now clients enter without the slightest shame even when our workers are visiting the brothels. The community as a whole thinks it is fine to have sex outside marriage."

There has been some progress. The new Minister of Women's Affairs, Mua Sokha, is herself a woman. "She's great," says Ms Oung. "She helps us in dangerous cases like big night clubs with 20 to 40 girls."

The police may intervene to rescue an individual girl - and the brothel owner may let her go to avoid any fuss. But she will be replaced just as quickly by another juvenile. "These large brothels provide girls to rich and powerful people," says Ms Oung. "When the night club is owned by an army general, the police don't dare make an arrest."

Social tolerance for male oppression of women extends to wife beating - and even wife killing. There is a cultural inhibition about telling other people, and neighbours mind their own business, Ms Oung explains. Even when a husband kills his wife, he can usually avoid arrest by moving to another province.

These are tales both of helplessness and of hope. Many efforts are being made by local NGOs such as CWCC and Likadho, and by Unicef and other international organisations. But no one in the field believes that they are winning the battle against one of the worst forms of human exploitation.

webTitle: Leader: The strong pound is still claiming victims

fields.headline: Squeezed to death
fields.standfirst:
The strong pound is still claiming victims
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Thank goodness the government will not make up its mind about joining the euro on the basis of what Japanese car manufacturers are doing. One, Nissan, wants a government subsidy in order to stay in Sunderland, partly to compensate for the effects of the strong pound. A second, Toyota, wants some UK suppliers to quote in future in euros, not pounds, thereby transferring the destablising effects to them. Now a third, Honda, plans to double output at its Swindon plant irrespective of the state of the pound or whether Britain stays in or out of the single currency. And some 10,000 cars will be exported from Swindon to Japan.
fields.body:
Thank goodness the government will not make up its mind about joining the euro on the basis of what Japanese car manufacturers are doing. One, Nissan, wants a government subsidy in order to stay in Sunderland, partly to compensate for the effects of the strong pound. A second, Toyota, wants some UK suppliers to quote in future in euros, not pounds, thereby transferring the destablising effects to them. Now a third, Honda, plans to double output at its Swindon plant irrespective of the state of the pound or whether Britain stays in or out of the single currency. And some 10,000 cars will be exported from Swindon to Japan.

Both the pro- and anti-euro lobbies have been claiming victory. Honda, however, denies its decision had anything to do with the euro. It was a long-term move based on many factors, including the favourable tax and business climate in Britain and the state of all the major currencies, including the yen - which has risen more against the pound than the pound against the euro.

But behind the hype something very disturbing is happening to manufacturing industry. Faced with an overvalued currency, companies are being forced to source components abroad unless UK suppliers can cut their costs in a draconian way. When the likes of BMW and Ford issue warnings it becomes national headlines. But most of the time what is happening results from unpublicised decisions by companies switching to imports in order to survive.

Cumulatively, this is having a disastrous effect on UK manufacturing capacity. As part of the process, many companies - Toyota is merely the most visible - are deciding voluntarily to adopt the euro ahead of any government move. Individuals may start to join them in a couple of years when euro notes and coins circulate in Europe. But this does not mean that the government has no role: it does. One reason the pound is crippling industry is that the government is silently acquiescing by not saying or doing anything that might bring it down. Yet it must be far cheaper to deal with the problem "upstream", by getting the pound down, than to have to foot the bill for increased unemployment and factory closures "downstream", when the consequences of the overvaluation have seeped through. And once companies close factories and buy components from abroad, it may prove impossible ever to get them reopened.

fields.headline: Gloucestershire the masters
fields.standfirst: Mark Alleyne's side make one-day history, reports  David Hopps
fields.trailText: Mark Alleyne's side make one-day history, reports David Hopps.
fields.body:
Gloucestershire's right to the title of England's one-day champions was established beyond measure yesterday when they reached an unprecedented fourth successive Lord's final. They could not have done it more emphatically: Lancashire, whose own name resonates with glorious one-day memories, were overwhelmed at Bristol.

There was no prouder record in the 1990s than Lancashire's six Lord's finals. But if they harboured notions of left-over superiority, they were dispelled in a 98-run defeat. From 99 for seven, they were fortunate to get that close.

To be fashionable remains the superficiality of a new century, so to term Gloucestershire unfashionable is to celebrate their substance. Once again, they batted with diligence, bowled with craft and fielded with intensity.

Mark Alleyne, with an unbeaten 36 from 27 balls late in the innings, backed up by parsimonious medium-pace, encapsulated their qualities. He is chomping painkillers for a back injury and would chomp them by the truckload to play again at Lord's.

Lancashire's decision to bowl was dubious. Sunday's washout had left the outfield saturated, bowlers and fielders behaved gingerly, and Kim Barnett had set sail towards the 80, from 128 balls, that carried Gloucestershire to an unassailable 248 for seven.

"Lancashire have been a benchmark, but if we win the final we'll feel we have passed that," Alleyne said. "They remain very dangerous, but today they didn't gel. They bowled too wide in the morning and to Barnett that is criminal."

All hail then the power of the Gloucestershire chicken. Warwickshire, at Lord's on Saturday week, will be the next county to try to conquer the mystical power of the unlikeliest of sporting mascots.

Gloucestershire have never lost a cup tie in the presence of this increasingly rancid bird. After a blank Sunday, its inebriated custodians still had the presence of mind to return it overnight to the freezer, and west country incantations sounded forth again yesterday as it was waved in triumph.

Lancashire might have offered Alan Whitehead the parson's nose. webTitle: Three fishermen saved as Solway sister ship sinks

fields.headline: Three fishermen saved as Solway sister ship sinks
fields.trailText: Three fisherman were airlifted to safety when their trawler sank off the Scottish coast yesterday, seven months after the loss of its sister ship the Solway Harvester and its seven-man crew.
fields.body:
Three fisherman were airlifted to safety when their trawler sank off the Scottish coast yesterday, seven months after the loss of its sister ship the Solway Harvester and its seven-man crew.

Alex Foster, 37, Roy Aitken, 30 and Leigh Shields, 17, were rescued from a dinghy after the 60ft Karianda sank 17 miles off the coast of Stonehaven, Aberdeenshire.

Coastguards were alerted to yesterday's incident when they received a distress call from the Karianda, about 15 miles east of Stonehaven off the Aberdeenshire coast.

Aberdeen coastguard watch assistant Angela Hutchison, said the exact reason why the Karianda sank was not clear. She added: "We believe it just took on water quickly and they managed to get themselves into the lifeboat. It was a happy ending."

The crew was taken to Aberdeen royal infirmary after being flown to land by an RAF helicopter and were reported to be fine.

A spokesman for the marine accidents investigation branch said it would be carrying out an investigation.

The Karianda, registered in Ballantrae, and a sister ship, the St Keverne, both belonging to the Hull-based Jack Robinson (Trawlers) Ltd, were detained earlier this year by maritime surveyors who claimed they were unseaworthy, but were subsequently released.

The Solway Harvester, which sank in January during a storm in the Irish Sea, was owned by the same firm.

webTitle: Arts: Paul Klee, the line king

fields.headline: The line king
fields.standfirst:
For decades, artists have looked at Paul Klee's work and thought: 'I can do that.' All they have proved is Klee's distinctive genius. Adrian Searle catches the real thing

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: For decades, artists have looked at Paul Klee's work and thought: 'I can do that.' All they have proved is Klee's distinctive genius. Adrian Searle catches the real thing
fields.body:
Paul Klee was almost a symbolist, nearly an abstractionist, not quite an expressionist or a full-blown surrealist, and never wholly the Bauhaus technocrat. He made his own way around, through and between these epochal movements in modern art.

As his most famous statement had it, Klee took a line for a walk. It snaked, looped, wandered off, and turned back on itself as it made its fitful journey through the worlds of his invention. On its way it found trees and plants, fish and camels, rooftops and roads, natural and human order, angels and woodlice. A donkey discovered in a wavering musical stave, a tightrope walker camouflaged amid a flickering field of dots, querulous beings and happy leviathans populate Klee's world.

Some works are remarkably free and offhand; others have the intricacy of a Swiss watch. Klee could draw a whole city in a space smaller than the palm of your hand.

The Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art is now showing The Private Klee, more than 130 works from every stage of the artist's career, from a crayon sketch he made as a child to late, raw, pictographic drawings from 1940, the year of his death at the age of 60 from a debilitating skin disease. Almost every work, from the slightest, most rapidly executed drawing, to the most laborious, reconsidered, layered and agglutinated painting, has the capacity to command our attention for a long time.

You don't so much look at a Klee as enter into it, inhabit it, daydream your way around it. Klee can eat up your time. It was an insult to the imagination when the Nazis included him in their exhibitions of "degenerate" art and sacked him from his professorship of Dusseldorf Academy when they came to power in 1933. Klee's work was so life-affirming, so joyful. True, he could invent lowering personages, and some of his earlier symbolist figures are morbid, wracked depictions, yet you never quite sense that they are in accord with his benign temperament.

What may have looked difficult in the first half of the 20th century can fade by the beginning of the 21st. Somehow, even what passes for severity in his works wears a smile. Klee's art was made to give pleasure, to captivate, to delight in small things. It never grabs you by the throat, nor does it set out to shock. Klee's was an attitude that serious art seems almost to have lost, and it is a loss we should mourn.

But following the winding path of Klee's work does not mean leaving reservations behind. Klee was never a robust, earthy artist like Joan Miro. Never - unlike his contemporary George Grosz - tortured, world-weary or sarcastic. Rarely angry, and never as crazy as Kandinsky, nor was he monstrous, avaricious, hungry or egotistical enough to be a Picasso.

You can't be a Picasso, and those who try fail. But there are lots of passable amateur Klees around. Looking at Klee's work in Edinburgh, it is difficult not to think of the concurrent show of paintings, drawings and watercolours by Elizabeth Blackadder at the Talbot Rice Gallery. Where Klee is delicate, Blackadder is wan. Where Klee used collaged materials to great effect, Blackadder uses them to ingratiate. Of course, Klee kills Blackadder, but something of Klee, which persists in Blackadder's decorative, boring work, almost blinds us to Klee himself, or at least blunts our ability to look at him with fresh eyes.

Part of the problem, I think, is Klee's popularity as a model for aspiring artists. Klee's example, promulgated in British art schools during the 1950s and 60s via Victor Passmore and Richard Hamilton, led to innumerable, fey little notebooks filled with abstractions from nature, decorative doodles, exercises in self-regarding style. None of this was Klee's fault. For all his didacticism and his teaching, Klee was a one-off.

If he has had a continuing influence, it is to be found, writ large, in Sigmar Polke's work, and in Joseph Beuys's drawings. Even Klee's handwriting, which annotates so many of his drawings, is close to Beuys's (and both are close to Rudolph Steiner's). And, like Beuys and Polke, Klee had a liking for poor materials, fragile papers, the delicate and ephemeral, the invocation of higher beings.

The puckered, yellowing papers Klee used, the scratchy quill and pen line, the agglutinated layers of burlap and plaster, the incised drawing and thin, sprightly layers of paint and painted symbols can so easily become a kind of cookery. Even his home-made picture frames have an attraction that teeters on winsome self-regard. Klee's studio was once described as an alchemist's lair, and the exhibition includes displays of the materials and instruments that he made and kept about him - home-made brushes, whittled reed pens, dental picks and razor blades fastened to improvised handles, gesso-caked cups and bent bits of wire, which he used to scrape, incise and abrade the compounded surfaces of his paintings.

It is clear that Klee enjoyed the materiality of the creative process, creating peculiar, broken-textured surfaces on which to paint. It is as though he needed something resistant to work with, as screens for the mind to dwell on. Even the flimsy papers he used often have a veil-like quality, and a porousness that allowed ink to run and bleed, or the nib to skate and slide. I think Klee needed the resistance of his materials to surprise himself, to waylay himself with the contrivance of accidents. This may seem close to surrealist technique, with its use of frottage, paint spills and free association, but Klee was too playful, too light-hearted ever to be a true surrealist.

The works in The Private Klee come from the Bürgi collection, the most important private holding of the artist's oeuvre outside the Klee family itself. The collection was begun by Hanni Bürgi, wife of the owner of a construction company in Bern. Her patronage of Klee, which began when the artist was young and unknown, was continued by her son Rolf, who was instrumental in helping Klee and his wife Lily leave Germany in 1933. Rolf also helped administer Klee's clandestine Swiss bank account, which kept the artist afloat during the years of German hyperinflation. After Klee's death, Bürgi became involved in a bitter dispute with the artist's son, Felix, over the ownership of the estate.

The murk of money always hangs around dead artists. You might say that Klee's art chose to ignore difficulty, or to rise above it, and was in a way diminished by what it chose not to depict. We have a fascination for trauma and disaster in art, and for the squalid aspects of the lives and afterlives of artists and their circles. Klee's work reminds us that pleasure is possible, and not only allowable, but necessary.

 The Private Klee: Works by Paul Klee from the Bürgi Collection is at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art (0131-624 6200) till October 22. Elizabeth Blackadder is at the Talbot Rice Gallery, University of Edinburgh (0131-650 2211) till September 9.

webTitle: Skeletons get ready to rattle in Clinton's mausoleum

fields.headline: Skeletons get ready to rattle in Clinton's mausoleum
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The message is definitive: it covers a wall. "Goodbye Mr President. Farewell to the Commander-in-Chief".
fields.body:
The message is definitive: it covers a wall. "Goodbye Mr President. Farewell to the Commander-in-Chief". But a Proustian ambivalence haunts the marbled corridors of the mausoleum. We've come not to salute William Jefferson Clinton as his moment dies - but, in search of times past and future, to visit Richard Milhous Nixon at his final resting place amid the palm trees of suburban Los Angeles.

Wallowing in LA money, soft and hard, these past few days, President Bill has raised $40m for would-be President Al - but also $10m or so towards the Clinton memorial library. Presidencies, as they pass, are entombed like pharaohs in the burial chambers of artefacts, papers and slavish tribute. When power ends, so the Little Rock temple of pyramid selling - all $120m of it - must rise. What will it be like, this Clinton edifice? Consider the Nixon reality of Yorba Linda: a stretch of colonnades and vibrant flowers, a hushed entrance hall, servile flunkeys - and the first exhibition hall. "Two American icons - the First Lady and Barbie together". Yes, here are all the Presidents' wives of history wearing their inauguration dresses as Barbie dolls. Do you like Barbie Bush in pearls and blue velvet? Or Barbie Hillary in turquoise, blonde hair piled like an ice cream cone? I cherish Barbie Mamie Eisenhower in truly shocking pink. How did you enjoy the show, Mrs Lincoln?

So to the memorabilia. Some is standard. The poster that reads "Ike and Dick, Sure to Click". The sanitised story of Alger Hiss. A TV rerun of the Kennedy debates which somehow doesn't let JFK get a word in. Bulbous yellow campaign Chevrolets and tank-like presidential Cadillacs. Yet we're only warming up. In a vaulted room, life-size statues of history's greats consort. Mao, de Gaulle, Kruschev, Churchill - and Dicky. (Whatever happened to Mrs T? Or, indeed, Spiro Agnew?) "Please", it says round the corner, "Do Not Touch the Berlin Wall". And there's an eight-foot lump of concrete covered in joyful graffiti as though our hero - out of time - had borne it back from the east in person. Next door the "gifts of the people" sit in sombre cabinets. A wooden clockwork elephant - "donor anonymous". Hand-knitted portraits of Nixon's dogs. A Colt 45 semi-automatic presented by a Mr Elvis Presley of Memphis, Tennessee.

Beyond, a long, dark tunnel tells the "story" of Watergate, mostly concentrating on those who spoke out for truth and justice. "I'll be damned if we're going to let this ugliness obscure the positive record of the President" (George Bush, 1973). Then, suddenly, the great dissembler lives. "Ask President Nixon a question" by pressing computer screens and a video in a little chapel of resurrection brings you his answer. "Did you ever feel unfairly treated by the press?" "Is it true that you only ate Milky Way for breakfast?" "What was your greatest poker hand?" And the oracle of Yorba Linda responds at length. "There will be a 17-minute time delay on your question" the computer reports. Bizarre!

Outside, on a lushly watered, grassy plot, Richard and Patricia Nixon lie side by side. Inside the justifications never end. Far outside, the Republican party - pledging to restore "dignity and honour" to the Oval Office - continues on its pious way. Do you feel under-appreciated Mr President? Answer in 36 minutes. Will it be like this, too, in Little Rock? The Paula Jones room with muzak from Gennifer Flowers, the Monica salon where the oracle Bill repeats that he never had sex with that woman, not ever, and broods through eternity on the meaning of "is"? Will his party, too, turn its back in forgetfulness once the final orations, the testaments to prosperity and 22m new jobs, have faded? Probably.

History is a half-eaten hamburger at Camp David. Kitsch comes naturally in the valley of the pharaohs. But, for the moment, watching him joshing, grinning, raising the spirits and the boodle, it's hard to believe. After 1960, Richard Nixon wrote: "The campaign had an intensity of spirit at once exhausting and uplifting." Campaigns are Clinton's adrenalin, his life. And now, in life, there is death.

Will his party, too, turn its back in forgetfulness once the final orations, the testaments to prosperity and 22m new jobs, have faded? Probably. History is a half-eaten hamburger at Camp David. Kitsch comes naturally in the valley of the pharaohs. But, for the moment, watching him joshing, grinning, raising the spirits and the boodle, it's hard to believe. After 1960, Richard Nixon wrote: "The campaign had an intensity of spirit at once exhausting and uplifting." Campaigns are Clinton's adrenalin, his life. And now, in life, there is death.

fields.headline: Infection worries hurt PPL
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Britain's leading animal cloning company, PPL Therapeutics, yesterday insisted it would continue working on the development of human organs in pigs, despite a slump in its shares caused by growing alarm about health risks.
fields.body:
Britain's leading animal cloning company, PPL Therapeutics, yesterday insisted it would continue working on the development of human organs in pigs, despite a slump in its shares caused by growing alarm about health risks.

Critics of the xenotransplantation technique are concerned that it could lead to the transfer of infection from animals into human beings. Their fears were aggravated over the weekend when the Roslin In stitute was reported to have ended research on the subject.

The Roslin Institute yesterday insisted its decision was triggered by funding priorities rather than by health risks. It said it wanted to fall into line with the priorities of the US biotech group Geron, with which it recently agreed a financing deal.

However, PPL's shares dived 14p to 151p yesterday, as investors' confidence in cloning technology took a knock. PPL was the first company to produce cloned pigs - earlier this year, it unveiled five genetically altered piglets, called Milla, Christie, Alexis, Carrel and Dotcom.

PPL's chief executive, Ron James, admitted there were many health issues to overcome before hearts, lungs and livers suitable for human beings could be grown in pigs. But he said: "For transplant patients, it's a small price to pay for not being dead."

It will be at least four years before PPL can begin clinical trials of xenotransplantation. Mr James said that if there were still concerns about infection at that point, patients could be asked to remain in isolation for as long as a year following their operations. "Being in an isolation room is better than being in a coffin."

Xenotransplantation is seen as a solution to the shortage of human organs donated for operations. Mr James said that volunteers in initial trials were most likely to be older people - who would usually get low priority on waiting lists for organs.

The government has formed a working party to consider the ethical questions raised by xenotransplantation. In draft guidelines earlier this year, it suggested that patients receiving organs from animals should be told not to have children, and not to have unprotected sex. Mr James believes the chances of humans catching animal diseases are remote. He said a more realistic concern was that pigs may pass on fragments of viruses such as HIV, which are present but not dangerous in animals.

In the City, analysts attach little value to PPL's involvement in xenotransplantation. Eva Haas of Old Mutual Securities said: "I think it's going to be an ethical minefield, and any commercial application is a very long way off."

The Roslin Institute stressed that although it had worked with PPL on other projects, its research into pigs was unconnected with the cloning firm's efforts. The institute wants to concentrate on researching the way cells change as they reproduce, and on genetically altering sheep and mice.

webTitle: UN to crack down as pirate boats threaten to drive fish to extinction

fields.headline: UN to crack down as pirate boats threaten to drive fish to extinction
fields.standfirst: Special report: global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: A quarter of the world's fish catch now comes from pirate boats, flying flags of convenience and flouting international law to hunt down valuable but endangered species such as tuna.
fields.body:
A quarter of the world's fish catch now comes from pirate boats, flying flags of convenience and flouting international law to hunt down valuable but endangered species such as tuna.

Pirate fishing has doubled in the last 10 years, threatening to drive some fish to extinction. Fearing the collapse of world fisheries, the UN is to crack down on the illegal business at a meeting in Rome in October to agree international controls.

The UN refers to the practice as IUU fishing - illegal, unregulated and unreported. Draft rules due to be agreed by 180 countries would close all ports to IUU fishermen to prevent them refuelling, taking on fresh crews or landing catches. The rules would also demand the closure of companies that own and control the illegal ships.

Pirate ships are regularly registered in countries such as Panama, Honduras, Belize and Cyprus to avoid fishing regulations but are owned by companies in Europe, the United States and Japan.

These boats, often large factory-style trawlers roam the Atlantic and Southern Ocean catching tuna and the Patagonian toothfish. Toothfish, sold as Antarctic or Southern ocean sea bass in Britain, is known as white gold to the pirate fishermen because of its high value.

In 1997, according to UN estimates, the illegal catch of Patagonian toothfish was around 100,000 tonnes with a value of more than £300m. Illegal fishing is expected to cause extinction of the toothfish in two to three years.

Although an international fishing agreement is in operation in the Antarctic to try to save the toothfish, the commission for the conservation of Antarctic marine resources has no method of enforcing its rules, and illegal vessels outnumber legal ones three to one.

One boat suspected of carrying illegally-caught bigeye tuna worth up to £1m is being held in the Japanese port of Shimizu while officials investigate the origins of the catch. Greenpeace tracked the Japanese owned and crewed freezer vessel flying the Panamanian flag from the Atlantic where it was filmed loading the tuna from two other vessels, one flying the Belize flag and the second a Cambodia flag.

All three were acting illegally under international law, because in the Atlantic only countries that are members of the international commission for the conservation of Atlantic tunas can legally fish.

In 1999, the governments of Japan and the US tabled evidence identifying 345 flag-of-convenience vessels fishing for tuna in the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. They flew flags from 17 countries, notably Honduras (103), Belize (83), Equatorial Guinea (51) and St Vincent and the Grenadines (50). Most are owned and managed by Taiwanese enterprises.

Simon Reddy of Greenpeace said: "Ultimately, it is the lure of big money paid for high-quality tuna, especially on the Japanese market, that provides the incentive for the activities of the pirate fleet.

"In recent years, the wholesale price paid at landing for top sashimi-quality tuna has reached more than £70 a pound, with some of the largest, high quality individual tuna fetching up to £30,000 each."

fields.headline: Way of life lost as treasure trove empties
fields.standfirst:
On the second day of our series, Guardian reporters look at problems in Cornwall and assess a change in eating and dietary habits
Special report: global fishing in crisis
fields.trailText: Robert George is a member of a dying breed. He bought his first fishing boat when he was still a teenager. Lining for mackerel underneath the cliff tops and in the coves and inlets along the coast near Land's End, he paid off the £500 he borrowed from the bank manager within the year.
fields.body:
Robert George is a member of a dying breed. He bought his first fishing boat when he was still a teenager. Lining for mackerel underneath the cliff tops and in the coves and inlets along the coast near Land's End, he paid off the £500 he borrowed from the bank manager within the year.

He had the grades to go to university but the lure and rewards of the sea kept him going back.

The work has always been hard: weeks away from his family, living with five other men in cramped and grubby conditions; enduring the mountainous seas in the fabled ground of the Irish Box, or following the shoals north into the icy winds off the Shetland Islands. Days begin at first light and end when the sun finally sets over the endless horizon.

But for most of Robert George's 35 years at sea the rewards have been worth the hardship. A hold full of cod or haddock could fetch its weight in silver in Newlyn harbour. Every voyage was a treasure hunt for the men on the Dew-Gen-Ny (God with us). Each member of the crew got a share, so even the lowliest deck hand could earn a small fortune after a successful week. Three trips in a row Mr George broke the port record for a catch into Newlyn.

"It is not a job, it is a way of life, 365 days a year," said Gordon, the engineering officer on the Dew-Gen-Ny. "I'm a dying breed but I love fishing. Maybe it's the sunrises at sea, I don't really know; maybe its the fact that when you're out there that's all there is. You leave everything else behind and just concentrate on the fishing. I don't want to do anything else."

But now the Dew-Gen-Ny is up for sale and Mr George wants out of the industry. Sitting in his local pub after 12 gruelling days at sea, he said the excitement has gone out of the business. What used to be a treasure hunt has had its heart ripped out by dreaded EU quotas and overfished waters.

No longer can hard work and a good trip guarantee a healthy bank balance. More often than not half the catch has been thrown back because the fish are too small or because the boat has reached its quota.

Not that the nets are full anymore. The seas around the UK have been trawled out, and while more and more boats work the grounds the pot of gold on the ocean floor is now little more than a thimble.

"There are too many boats trying to make a living out of not enough fish. The efficient will survive but the inefficient won't," he said.

According to the other fishermen in Newlyn Mr George is one of the most efficient there is, and when he decides to get out it really is time to start worrying about their industry.

He is not an isolated case. An atmosphere of doom and gloom pervades the quays and streets of Newlyn. Nearly every inhabitant is linked with the industry, from the men who make the nets to the landlord in the Dolphin pub.

The fleet has been in steady decline for the past 10 years. The boats are ageing beyond repair and when the government offered generous terms for decommissioning in the early 1990s, more than 40 owners jumped at the chance.

"That is more than 120 jobs lost," said Nathan de Rozarieux, chief executive of the Cornish Fish Producers Organisation. "If they offered the same terms again a lot more skippers would take them up on it."

According to Mr de Rozarieux, the quotas, brought in to protect falling stocks, have been a disaster, as well as a source of antagonism against the Spanish and the French. The fishermen of Cornwall claim their waters have been plundered by the foreigners with their bigger, more efficient boats and bigger quotas.

They want no-fishing zones, areas of the sea bed where the fish can replenish their dwindling numbers. But they have little faith in the government and even less in the EU to do what they see as the right thing.

"We are fast becoming just a cottage industry," said one of the local fish merchants. "There will still be fishermen, but the industry won't support the jobs it does now. We have managed to keep things going so far, but if there is not a change soon we will have to start laying people off."

But the Cornish fishing industry is not just suffering from an acute lack of fish, there is also an acute lack of men. A sign above one of the merchants reads "Save our fish". But perhaps it should also read "save our fishermen". The older fishermen and merchants remember when the quay would be full of boys helping to unload the fish, bunking off school to wash down the boxes.

Justin, whose father and grandfather were fishermen, was one of those boys. From the age of 12 his teachers were lucky if they saw him more than one day a week when the trawlers were unloading.

He began his first job as a deck hand on his 16th birthday and he has been at sea 250 days of every year ever since. He is now 25 and works on the Dew-Gen-Ny, but although he says he loves the life, he would not advise any teenager to go into the industry now.

"Where is the future in it? Its just not viable. It would be all right if we were whales or seals or something like that. The country would be up in arms to save us. We're an endangered species," he said.

Even the experienced skippers and mates are leaving the industry in their droves. They are working the supply ships that feed the rigs in the North sea for a steady wage.

W Stevenson and Sons is the biggest fishing company in Newlyn. It runs 36 boats, many of them named after long deceased family members who have built up the business over the past 150 years. The company employs a further 100 people on shore.

But only 19 boats are working at the moment. Half a dozen are having re-fits, but they can't find crews for the rest. "There is a real shortage of experienced skippers; they seem to have just disappeared into thin air," said Elizabeth Stevenson.

"Its partly all the forms and things they need to fill in, all the rules and regulations that have had imposed. Suddenly from just having a good knowledge of the sea and of fishing they need to be a bloody mathematician as well. If he makes an honest mistake he can be up in court for thousands of pounds."

And the state of the industry? "It's really quite grim. If things don't start changing soon I suppose redundancies are a possibility."

Robin Turner, whose family have been fish merchants since 1760, said it was hardly surprising the young were turning away from fishing.

"They go down to the quay and they see these old rust bucket vessels and it must frighten them to death. They look and think to themselves that they don't want to be working on those boats for the next 40 years, and you can't blame them. It is their necks they are putting on the line. The sea does not take any prisoners; I attend enough bloody funerals to know that."

Fishing is acknowledged to be one of the most dangerous industries to work in, on a par with mining. During his 10 years in the industry the number of people Justin knows who have been killed is well into double figures.

He counts off the names of people and boats on one of his hands. "There was a friend of mine swept overboard while he was shooting the line ... there was a boat that was hit by a cargo ship ... they didn't even realise until they found the mast on the deck the next morning ... they never found his body...."

According to Justin the shortage of men is making the problem worse. Skippers are having to take whatever crew they can to get to sea.
