webTitle: Few seconds that led to anguish

fields.headline: Few seconds that led to anguish
fields.trailText: The distraction lasted just a few seconds. But in the deceptively calm shallows of Norfolk's Brancaster beach, that was all the time it took to sweep Jake Parker away.
fields.body:
The distraction lasted just a few seconds. But in the deceptively calm shallows of Norfolk's Brancaster beach, that was all the time it took to sweep Jake Parker away.

Yesterday as the search for the five-year-old continued, police revealed that his aunt had turned away for only an instant as they paddled together at the packed shoreline.

But Brancaster's strong current and hidden channels make it one of Britain's most dangerous beaches. Spring tide currents are capable of knocking an adult off their feet, let alone a child.

Last night police revealed that an 11-year-old girl and seven-year-old boy reported seeing what they thought was a body floating in the water just 15 to 20 yards from where Jake was last seen paddling. "We have no reason to doubt what the children are telling us and this is an extremely worrying development," said Chief Superintendent Mike McCormick of Norfolk police.

He said the children told their parents about what they had seen only several hours after the family returned to their Cambridgeshire home.

Chief Supt McCormick added that the chances of finding Jake alive were growing remote. "He was only paddling in water that was literally ankle deep. Understandably his aunt is extremely distressed."

PC John Butters, a colleague, said: "The sooner he is found, the better it is for his whole family. Of course they are still clinging on to hope that he might still be alive."

Jake, who cannot swim, was last seen at 12.15pm on Sunday as the tide had started to come in. His parents, Kevin and Debbie, saw him paddling with his aunt and gave their son a final wave before he vanished from sight.

Seconds after she lost sight of Jake, his aunt raised the alarm and was joined by Jake's parents and sister who searched the beach for 25 minutes before calling for help. They stayed on the sand until 5.30pm before being driven away by the police to be given counselling.

Jake was on a day trip with his family from their home in Wellingborough, Northamptonshire. His grandfather Derek Geater said the family were sitting by the telephone desperate for news.

Last night the search was temporarily called off because of the dangers of an incoming tide. It will be resumed today on a reduced scale.

Colin Tomlinson, of the coastguards, confirmed there was no lifeguard service at the beach but stressed holidaymakers were warned by signs of the perils of taking children on to the beach.

"This beach is more dangerous than most of Britain's holiday beaches. Because it is so flat people don't realise how deadly it is," he said.

"The sea in this area is extremely dangerous. The beach has lots of creaks and gulleys and there is a channel running along the beach which travels like a fast running river.

Vast reaches of golden sands which make the beaches so tempting at the end of a car journey also form lethal stretches of coastline. Sandbanks, peat and clay shells suddenly drop away with spring tide channels reaching speeds of up to 3.5 knots.

Lifeguard Peter Dukes said: "I was amazed that just 24 hours after this little boy was apparently swept away, I heard parents telling children as young as six not to wade out too far. I was in no doubt they were quite happy to let their children go off and play in the water alone.

"We are constantly urging parents not let their children wander off or go into the water by themselves. But sadly some of them never listen."

It will be resumed today on a reduced scale. Colin Tomlinson, of the coastguards, confirmed there was no lifeguard service at the beach but stressed holidaymakers were warned by signs of the perils of taking children on to the beach. "This beach is more dangerous than most of Britain's holiday beaches. Because it is so flat people don't realise how deadly it is," he said. "The sea in this area is extremely dangerous. The beach has lots of creaks and gulleys and there is a channel running along the beach which travels like a fast running river. Vast reaches of golden sands which make the beaches so tempting at the end of a car journey also form lethal stretches of coastline. Sandbanks, peat and clay shells suddenly drop away with spring tide channels reaching speeds of up to 3.5 knots. Lifeguard Peter Dukes said: "I was amazed that just 24 hours after this little boy was apparently swept away, I heard parents telling children as young as six not to wade out too far. I was in no doubt they were quite happy to let their children go off and play in the water alone. "We are constantly urging parents not let their children wander off or go into the water by themselves. But sadly some of them never listen."

webTitle: Teen killers of woman, 87, face long jail terms

fields.headline: Teen killers of woman, 87, face long jail terms
fields.standfirst: Warning by judge to sisters who attacked family friend
fields.trailText: Two teenage sisters who fatally attacked and robbed an 87-year-old family friend and neighbour were yesterday warned they would face long jail sentences.
fields.body:
Two teenage sisters who fatally attacked and robbed an 87-year-old family friend and neighbour were yesterday warned they would face long jail sentences.

Jean Lyons, 19, and her sister Kellie, 17, kicked and beat Lillian MacKenzie at her second floor flat on the Woodberry Down estate in Manor House, north London, before leaving with about £800 of her savings in January. Mrs MacKenzie died in hospital a week later after suffering seven broken ribs and severe bruising to her back and chest.

The sisters had lived with their mother two floors below Mrs MacKenzie and had received money, birthday cards and advice from the widow, known as Rose, who had taken an interest in their lives.

A jury at the Old Bailey yesterday cleared the sisters of murder but convicted them of Mrs MacKenzie's manslaughter. Kellie was also convicted of robbing Mrs MacKenzie, a charge Jean had previously admitted.

Judge Michael Combe warned the sisters that they would face a long time in jail after they were sentenced on September 4. "These crimes cry out for and must have substantial sentences in order to deter others," he told them.

He also lifted the ban on identifying the teenagers, saying the "very serious crime and the circumstances of it" meant such a ban was not in the public interest.

Ann Curnow QC, prosecuting, told the court that Mrs MacKenzie, who was 4ft 10in tall and suffered from chronic heart disease, had been expecting a visit from a hairdresser when the sisters, who were wearing black clothes and balaclavas, called at her door.

"It was a fearsome attack," Ms Curnow said. "They later bragged to friends that they had 'done an old lady'. They were in a 'hyper' mood as they described how they knocked on her door, hit her, turned out the light, kicked her when she fell and stamped on her.

"She was screaming for mercy but received none."

Jean, a cocaine and heroin user, had later demonstrated to friends how she had wielded an iron bar which had since been thrown into a canal, Ms Curnow said.

The sisters took about £800 and Mrs MacKenzie's bank and pension books from behind some tiles in her bathroom. The widow, who lived alone, had previously confided to the teenagers where she kept her valuables.

The court heard that Jean and Kellie Lyons had been inseparable before they were arrested and had both been training to sell perfume door-to-door. They had been arrested after they boasted of what they had done and friends went to the police.

Jean admitted robbery but said it was her younger sister who had kicked Mrs MacKenzie. Kellie had told police she had not been involved in the attack but had been ill in bed at the time.

She said she had loved Mrs MacKenzie "like a nan".

"I was really close to her," she said. "I enjoyed her company and she enjoyed mine. I went to the shops with her on occasions and we sometimes ate fish and chips together. I miss her. I wish she was not dead."

Outside court, Mrs MacKenzie's great-nephew, Jeff Bennett, said: "She was an elderly lady who would not do anyone any harm. She trusted these girls. If she had survived, she would have been even more shocked to know it was them. I am quite grateful that she never knew."

Her sister-in-law, Wynn Smith, said: "She was a perfect person who never harmed a soul. She should have been able to end her days in peace rather than having her life shattered and dying in agony."

Mrs MacKenzie had lived in the flat for 40 years and was popular on the estate. The first person she had asked for after the attack was Bridget Kinsella, the sisters' mother.

Detective Chief Inspector Patricia Gallan said: "They were both young girls who liked to have a good time. We have never discovered the motive for the attack."

She added that neither sister had shown any real remorse over the attack.

fields.headline: The death of hope
fields.standfirst:
Peace in Kashmir appeared less impossible. And then Hizbul Mojahedin broke the ceasefire

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: Peace in Kashmir appeared less impossible. And then Hizbul Mojahedin broke the ceasefire
fields.body:
For a brief moment things looked hopeful in the unhappy valley of Kashmir. But after a weekend of attacks on Indian security forces, the recent ceasefire by Hizbul Mojahedin is taking on the musty smell of ancient history. On July 24 Hizbul Mojahedin declared a ceasefire. The group is one of the oldest and most powerful of those fighting the Indian army. Expectations for a new beginning ran high, and seemed to be justified as India first suspended its offensive against Hizbul and then officially met its representatives.

However, the talks soon broke off. India refused to accept the involvement of Pakistan. Hope lingered until Thursday. But Hizbul's attacks have put paid to any negotiations in the near future. None the less, the whole episode gives an insight into the movement of the greatest fault line in south Asian politics.

Kashmir has been the flashpoint for two wars since 1947. Pakistan's claim to the territory rests on its Muslim population and its border with Muslim Pakistan. India's claim rests on the decision of Hari Singh, the last maharajah of Kashmir, to join the Indian Union in 1947, and on the fact that his kingdom, which became the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, was home to many Hindus and some Buddhists, as well as Muslims.

It was not until 1989 that guerrilla movements sprang up among the easygoing Kashmiris. The Afghans' success against the Soviet army inspired similar tactics. And some of the western weapons and money that were flowing through Pakistan were easily diverted towards Kashmir. Soon, foreigners (Pakistanis, Afghans and even Arabs) became involved.

The insurgency developed a season. Fighters cross the mountains dividing the Indian and Pakistani parts of Kashmir as they become passable in late spring. The insurgents operate through the summer against the 125,000 Indian soldiers stationed in the valley. They are supplied with food, shelter, weapons and medicine via Pakistan. As the autumn snows fall in the mountains the guerrillas retreat across the porous "line of control" separating the combatants.

Last year witnessed a twist to this pattern. By early spring, fighters had already crossed the mountains and seized the region of Kargil. Battle was joined with India shelling the insurgents' salient and the United States pressing Pakistan to have its clients withdraw. The insurgents' eventual retreat was seen as a defeat for Pakistan. It led swiftly to the overthrow of the civilian government of Nawaz Sharif and the resumption of military rule.

Pakistan's fingerprints are all over the recent ceasefire. Officially, the government was neutral. Pakistan only gives what it describes curiously as political, diplomatic and moral support to the insurgent groups. General Musharraf, who seized power in the coup, refused either to praise or criticise the ceasefire. However, it is no coincidence that the ceasefire was offered by one of the few groups of Kashmiris who support union with Pakistan. Musharraf himself called the ceasefire "an opportunity for dialogue with India". That it broke down over the issue of just such a dialogue confirms Pakistan's involvement.

In the eyes of the world the ceasefire has left Pakistan looking relatively moderate over Kashmir. India, on the other hand, triumphant last summer, now appears unwilling to go the extra mile. General Musharraf's peaceful noises will have pleased the Americans, which is vital if he is to drag his country out of its economic and political morass. Meanwhile he has lost nothing. No one in his army can say he took the pressure off India. The insurgency went on throughout Hizbul's ceasefire with, for example, the murder of 90 Hindu pilgrims.

Yet Pakistan's position remains weak. The insurgents are a doubtful weapon. They pin down Indian troops and goad them into acts of oppression, no doubt. But meanwhile the fighters encourage the spread of Islamism in the Pakistani army. They also let the Taliban blackmail Pakistan over the presence of its paramilitary camps in Afghanistan.

The support of foreign states also has its pitfalls. CIA revelations that China helped Pakistan develop ballistic missile technology will serve only to frighten the west. China already occupies part of northern Kashmir. It would be happy for the Tibetan people of Ladakh to fall under its control. It is willing to help Pakistan compete in an expensive and time-consuming large arms race. But China will be less keen to sell small arms that could find their way to its own Muslim insurgents in Xinjiang.

With the prospect of mutually assured destruction hanging above south Asia, peace in Kashmir is not a luxury but a necessity. The west must invest in economic and political stability in Pakistan. Then all the peoples of Kashmir should be asked what future they want: status quo, union with Pakistan or independence. This question, however, cannot be posed until fair elections are possible. The fighting must stop and paramilitary weapons must be silenced. Hizbul Mojahedin's short ceasefire has at least set a precedent for that silence.

fields.headline: Gore identifies new rogue state
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Gore won a standing ovation as the Democratic convention kicked off by telling a delighted audience that the United States had become "the greatest terrorist and the largest rogue state" in the world. He was also applauded loudly after announcing that today "only corporate America enjoys representation".
fields.body:
Gore won a standing ovation as the Democratic convention kicked off by telling a delighted audience that the United States had become "the greatest terrorist and the largest rogue state" in the world. He was also applauded loudly after announcing that today "only corporate America enjoys representation".

This was Gore Vidal, it should be said, former Democratic politician, novelist, playwright, historian, mischief-maker and cousin of young Al. He was addressing a full house at the Leo Baeck temple just opposite that symbol of corporate authority, the Getty Centre, as the delegates assembled for the first day of the convention.

Vidal lamented that "50 years ago I used to be the only Gore" and used his presentation to a "town hall" meeting organised by the magazine the Nation to urge whoever was the next president to use his entire first term of office to "tame the American military". He attacked the Pentagon as a major reason for the collapse of the democratic system in the United States and for the waste of public money.

"Congress has been hijacked by corporate America and its enforcers," Vidal said. "Our empire is now the greatest terrorist of all."

He said that since the Soviet Union "unsportingly disbanded", the world's 1bn Muslims have been demonised as wild fanatics in order to justify the continuation of military spending.

Since 1946, he said, $7.1 trillion had been spent on defence while national debts totalled $3.6 trillion.

Vidal also attacked the American drug laws saying that "we started the damn country" to get away from such restrictions and suggested that the founding fathers had included many laudanum addicts. "Anything taken for joy is against God's will," had become the justification for the drugs laws, he said.

People had forgotten the effects of prohibition, he said: "We have become the United States of Amnesia." He accused the US of "swaggering round the world smashing countries like Colombia" and finished his address to a standing ovation and cries of "run, Gore, run!" from the audience.

Tom Hayden, now a Californian senator but arrested at the 1968 Democratic convention in Chicago during the anti-war demonstrations, voiced his support for the thousands who have already taken to the streets of Los Angeles in some of the rolling demonstrations taking place during the week.

"The Democratic party should not try and stigmatise the people who raised hell in Seattle and gave birth to a new generation of radicalism," said Mr Hayden.

"More and more people are feeling that there is no other way than to get out on the streets. It is a great blessing instead of a danger to the city of Los Angeles. Everyone in this room was someone real and vibrant before they became middle-aged."

Jesse Jackson Jr, 35, congressman and delegate at the convention, said that people now believed that they had a right to a gun but not a right to a proper education. A few miles away his father addressed a rally outside Loews hotel in Santa Monica to call for union rights for the hotel workers there.

The gatherings were just two of dozens due to be held this week by those who suggest that the real issues are not being addressed by the convention. The first of the major demonstrations, in support of the journalist and former Black Panther Mumia Abu-Jamal who has been on death row in Pennsylvania since 1981, took place on Sunday as did a large picket of Gap. There were protests yesterday to support abortion rights and highlight "corporate shame".

webTitle: Court told of nun's cruelty to girls in children's home

fields.headline: Court told of nun's cruelty to girls in children's home
fields.trailText: A Roman Catholic nun forced girls in her care at a children's home to cover their heads with urine-soaked bed linen as a punishment for wetting the bed, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A Roman Catholic nun forced girls in her care at a children's home to cover their heads with urine-soaked bed linen as a punishment for wetting the bed, a court heard yesterday.

Marie Docherty, 58, also known as Sister Alphonso, is accused of cruelly treating girls at Nazareth House children's homes in Scotland over a 15-year period.

On the first day of her trial at Aberdeen sheriff court, Docherty was accused of forcing a girl who suffered from epilepsy into a freezing cold bath during a fit. It was alleged that she would beat girls with a stick and rosary beads, deprive them of sleep, pull them by the hair along corridors and force them to wear soiled bed linen on their heads.

Helen Cruister, 43, told the court that when she, her two sisters and three brothers arrived at Nazareth House in Aberdeen in 1967, Sister Alphonso had given them a bath in water laced with disinfectant.

Mrs Cruister, who lived at Nazareth House between the ages of 10 and 14, shared a room with her younger sisters who would wet the bed each night. She said Sister Alphonso would force her sisters to stand with urine soaked sheets on their heads. When she asked her to stop, the court heard, the nun would hit her on the head with her fists.

Docherty denies charges of cruel and unnatural treatment towards the girls in her care at Nazareth House children's homes in Aberdeen and Midlothian between 1965 and 1980. The trial continues.

webTitle: Legal bid by pair on run from forced marriage

fields.headline: Legal bid by pair on run from forced marriage
fields.trailText: A couple who have been on the run for seven years after defying the forced marriage system are to use the Human Rights Act to try to win greater protection from vindictive relatives.
fields.body:
A couple who have been on the run for seven years after defying the forced marriage system are to use the Human Rights Act to try to win greater protection from vindictive relatives.

Jack and Zena Briggs have been forced to move home 27 times since their secret wedding in 1994, because of fears that their false identity package is too thin to deceive Zena's family, who had previously planned her marriage to a cousin in Pakistan.

The pair, who courted in Bradford after meeting in one of the city's parks, say that they are suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and cannot get jobs, because the protection package includes no employment history or references and the Home Office has refused to issue birth and marriage certificates to go with their new names and passports.

"The police, local authorities and even senior government ministers have chosen to ignore our problems. Now we want justice. We want them to admit they got it wrong," said Jack, 39.

"We were hunted like animals, and when we turned to the authorities for help we were treated like animals. They have lied to us, passed us over, betrayed us and abandoned us.

"We set out so full of hope of starting a new life together, but those hopes have come to nothing. We are worse off than when we started out."

Zena Briggs, 28, who came from a prosperous Muslim background in contrast to her husband's lack of qualifications and succession of manual jobs, said that she had thought about suicide because of the "dreary and friendless" regime of being holed up for 23 hours a day.

She said: "All we did was get married and we have been punished for it, not only by my family, but by a system that has chosen to ignore us."

The couple plan to bring a case when the Human Rights Act becomes law in October, suing for the complete new identities offered to police "supergrasses" and former terrorists. They say that the case has implications for other victims of attempts at forced marriages - an illegal perversion of the arranged marriage system used by some Asian-origin families with prospective partners' consent.

The Briggses have highlighted the issue in a book published three years ago, and they lobbied the junior Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, last year, with Ann Cryer, the Labour MP for Keighley, who has been prominent in attacking forced marriages.

But Mr Briggs said that they now felt they had been "used" in order to spotlight the issue, but had subsequently been left to founder.

The Home Office said that the issue could be tested when the Human Rights Act became law, but denied that the couple had been short-changed on protection.

A spokesman said: "At Mr O'Brien's meeting with Jack and Zena Briggs, he made it clear that the handling of the case was an operational matter for police and that ministers had no authority to intervene.

"The police acted properly and the couple are now adjudged not to be at risk," the spokesman said.

The Home Office added that police had offered the couple suitable safe accommodation at one stage, but this had been rejected.

However, Mr Briggs said that the offer had been too risky, because it was in a town with a large number of asylum seekers and a recent history of racist attacks.

The couple say that they do not feel out of danger, because one of Zena's relatives had told her that the family would bide its time.

Mr Briggs added: "If we had been given the full new identity package, we could have started a new life. We believe that our civil and human rights have been breached."

She said: "All we did was get married and we have been punished for it, not only by my family, but by a system that has chosen to ignore us." The couple plan to bring a case when the Human Rights Act becomes law in October, suing for the complete new identities offered to police "supergrasses" and former terrorists. They say that the case has implications for other victims of attempts at forced marriages - an illegal perversion of the arranged marriage system used by some Asian-origin families with prospective partners' consent. The Briggses have highlighted the issue in a book published three years ago, and they lobbied the junior Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, last year, with Ann Cryer, the Labour MP for Keighley, who has been prominent in attacking forced marriages. But Mr Briggs said that they now felt they had been "used" in order to spotlight the issue, but had subsequently been left to founder. The Home Office said that the issue could be tested when the Human Rights Act became law, but denied that the couple had been short-changed on protection. A spokesman said: "At Mr O'Brien's meeting with Jack and Zena Briggs, he made it clear that the handling of the case was an operational matter for police and that ministers had no authority to intervene. "The police acted properly and the couple are now adjudged not to be at risk," the spokesman said. The Home Office added that police had offered the couple suitable safe accommodation at one stage, but this had been rejected. However, Mr Briggs said that the offer had been too risky, because it was in a town with a large number of asylum seekers and a recent history of racist attacks. The couple say that they do not feel out of danger, because one of Zena's relatives had told her that the family would bide its time. Mr Briggs added: "If we had been given the full new identity package, we could have started a new life. We believe that our civil and human rights have been breached."

fields.headline: Benefit loan refusals rocket to 362,000
fields.trailText: The tightening of government rules for loans to deprived families to buy clothing and furniture has seen rejected applications soar from less than 5,000 a year to 362,000 since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
The tightening of government rules for loans to deprived families to buy clothing and furniture has seen rejected applications soar from less than 5,000 a year to 362,000 since Labour came to power.

The interest-free "budgeting loans" from the benefit agency's social fund are seen as a lifeline for many people living on the poverty line who use the cash to purchase necessities like shoes, clothing, cookers and beds.

But a new computerised system for allocating the loans introduced in April 1999 has seen the number of applications refused on the grounds of inability to repay increase dramatically.

According to the social security secretary Alistair Darling's annual report on the social fund, the number of applications for loans refused on that basis doubled from 4,856 in 1997-98 to 11,102 the following year but, after the new rules were brought in, refusals soared to 362,000 in 1999-2000.

Opposition MPs blamed the rigid rules for awarding the loans, which has significantly reduced the personal discretion of social fund officers to hand out cash to the people most in need rather than those judged able to repay the debt.

Under the new rules, families with outstanding budgeting loans are refused further help until they have paid off at least half their debt.

Steve Webb, the Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, described the figures as shocking and called on the government to reinstate grants based on need to help the poorest families purchase essential items.

He said: "The government is slamming the door in the face of some of Britain's neediest families. They are refusing loans to people who are already paying off debts from their weekly benefits. But you don't get this money for trivial things like computer games. This is essential money for essential things like fridges and children's shoes and the government is clearly failing the very poorest in society."

He pointed to a recent report by the Citizens Advice Bureau which claimed that a number of the people, particularly the disabled and those with special needs, had "suffered decisions that result in stress and hardship" as a result of the changes in the decision-making process.

But a spokesman for the social security department defended the new system, saying the process had brought an end to "intrusive and paternalistic" questioning by benefits agency staff, who previously required applicants to justify why they needed the loan, and allowed them to continuously top up their loans to the maximum of £1,000 in a long-running cycle of debt.

The loans have a standard repayment period of 18 months. Debtors repay an average of £9.32 a week, usually from benefits payments.

The spokesman added that the total amount loaned to destitute families from the social fund over the past two years had increased by 15% from £344m in 1998-99 to £396m in the last financial year.

The number of rejections had risen in line with the number of applications, the spokesman added, with many of those being turned down already in receipt of the maximum loan.

fields.headline: Going cheap ... 50,000 books
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Foyle's, until recently the world's most eccentric bookshop, has discovered - a little late in the day - that it is bursting at the seams with unwanted paper.
fields.body:
Foyle's, until recently the world's most eccentric bookshop, has discovered - a little late in the day - that it is bursting at the seams with unwanted paper.

Yesterday it launched its first ever book sale, a vulgarity unthinkable in the era of the bookloving autocrat Christina Foyle, who ran the company for almost 70 years until she died last June.

A tenth of the stock in the enormous shop in Charing Cross Road, central London, has been reduced in price, at least 50,000 volumes and music sheets, many of which have languished unsold for up to 30 years.

These are the fruit of decades of "bad stock management and over-zealous buying", according to Anthony Foyle, a director and nephew of Christina.

The fiction sale offers Irma Kurtz's 1993 novel Jinx for £2. In fact, many books in the sale date from 1993, the year Foyle's unwisely opted to buy from wholesalers instead of publishers. This meant publishers stopped buying back works which proved unsaleable.

In the music section, Davidoff's Romance sans Paroles is going for a song at £1.30. Astronomy tomes once costing £80 to £90 are reduced to a few pounds.

Browsing among the bargains is a reminder of the awesome comprehensiveness which has made Foyle's internationally admired. The Latin section still stocks a school crib to Julius Caesar's De Bello Civili, as it did 50 years ago.

For specialists, it remains the supreme bookshop. Even so, "We have got to bring Foyles fully into the 21st century," acting manager Robert Palmer said.

In October the store will get its first electronic stock control system so customers can check if a book is in stock without searching a labyrinth of shelves. Soon - even more unthinkably to Christina Foyle - it will start selling volumes on a website.

webTitle: Wind in the Willows inspiration under threat

fields.headline: Storm in the Willows
fields.standfirst: Ratty response to car park proposal
fields.trailText: A rural oasis on the banks of the river Thames, which was the inspiration for Kenneth Grahame's The Wind in the Willows and for the artist Sir Stanley Spencer, is under threat.
fields.body:
A rural oasis on the banks of the river Thames, which was the inspiration for Kenneth Grahame's The Wind in the Willows and for the artist Sir Stanley Spencer, is under threat.

A proposal is being considered to build a car park on the tranquil Marsh Meadow in Cookham, Berkshire. Council planners say it is desperately needed - but many villagers argue it would spoil the area.

Grahame created his enduringly popular characters Badger, Mole, Ratty and Toad while walking along the riverbank near Cookham, an area he described as "heaven on the Thames".

David Ricardo, of the Marsh Meadow Protection Group, has collected the signatures of 1,170 people opposed to the car park.

Mr Ricardo, whose relative, Colonel Francis Ricardo, inspired the character of Toad, said the meadow was a national attraction because of its artistic and literary connections.

"People say that it has the most unsurpassed view in the whole Thames valley," he said. "This view will be destroyed if a car park is built on the Marsh Meadow. Even though Cookham is only 45 minutes from the centre of London what makes it attractive is how rural it is. We don't need a car park - there is adequate parking here already."

Cookham attracts tens of thousands of visitors every year; last year 16,000 people visited the Stanley Spencer gallery in the village.

The meadow, on green belt land, is virtually unchanged since Spencer painted it in 1934 in The Scarecrow.

The National Trust, which has a small car park on Cookham Moor, has not yet decided whether it will support the scheme. If it were to go ahead, access would be required across the trust's land.

Windsor and Maidenhead council, which is considering the plan, says the proposed car park would have a rural appearance with extensive planting and gravel surfaces. It would offer easy access to the village and river and would be landscaped to screen it from important views across the river and moor, said a spokeswoman.

webTitle: Comment: The Tories are taking this opposition thing too far

fields.headline: The Tories are taking this opposition thing too far
fields.standfirst:
Ian Aitken offers William Hague advice on staffing, catchphrases and alcohol consumption

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Ian Aitken  offers William Hague advice on staffing, catchphrases and alcohol consumption
fields.body:
Marx had a phrase for it. I don't remember which of his early movies contained the relevant scene - Duck Soup maybe, or perhaps Horse Feathers - but the great man sang a song in which the refrain was: "whatever it is, I'm against it."

When I say Marx, I am of course referring to Groucho rather than Karl. True, the distinction is becoming increasingly blurred with the passage of time, since both men were engaged in wholesale subversion, and both are now dead. But, with the collapse of Soviet communism, it is Groucho's version of Marxism which seems to have survived. He is still undermining the capitalist establishment every time one of his films gets shown. For the time being, at least, Karl isn't.

Oddly, however, Groucho's declaration of blanket hostility to pretty well everything seems to have become the guiding principle underlying William Hague's leadership of the official opposition to the Labour government. No one has actually said it to John Humphrys yet, but an endless succession of Tory spokesmen and spokeswomen make it clear on the Today programme and similar shows that whatever the government is currently saying, they are against it.

Ann Widdecombe is probably the most practised exponent of this technique of wholesale oppositionism, as she routinely blasts Jack Straw for being about 2mm to the left of her on whatever is the issue of the morning. Even when an eager-to-please government lurches to the right to accommodate the Conservative position - as with the current imbroglio over child molesters - she still manages to find grounds for condemning him.

But assorted junior spokesmen in fields like trade, aviation and defence are almost equally kneejerk in their reaction to government pronouncements within their remit. The latest example came from a very junior, virtually anonymous agriculture spokesman, who somehow managed to find the government more or less responsible for the current outbreak of swine fever in East Anglia.

Yes, the government had acted pretty robustly, he conceded to Mr Humphrys. But they hadn't acted quickly enough. This must have seemed pretty rich to those who have been following the unfolding evidence of the last government's dereliction of duty in the BSE crisis. But it is par for the course among Tory shadow ministers. Whatever it is, they're against it.

Given our essentially adversarial system of government - and, like it or not, the adversarial Today programme is now almost as much a part of our system of government as parliament itself - it is at least arguable that an opposition has very little alternative but to biff the government at every opportunity. The only other course would seem to be total silence - an option to which neither Ms Widdecombe nor Mr Hague seem naturally drawn. But whether constant complaint is tactically advisable is a different question.

The stark reality is that Mr Hague and his team look increasingly like serial whingers, and that is a profoundly unattractive image in anyone. But it is all the more unattractive in a group of politicians representing a party which held office for 18 years and somehow contrived to leave most of the problems they complain about unsolved. It isn't just a matter of asking "what would you do?" - a question which all out-of-office politicians are bound to face. It is a matter of asking "what did you do?" And the answer is not persuasive.

So what is poor William to do? Even if he wanted to, he can hardly shut up entirely. There is, after all, an election in the offing, and it is probably only nine or 10 months ahead. He must keep himself and his party in the newspapers and on the television screens. To vanish from the media at this stage would invite not just defeat but electoral obliteration.

If I am right, however, it will be only slightly less damaging for Hague if he keeps up his campaign of endless, Widdecombe-style complaint. Even dyed-in-the-wool Tory voters must have noticed by now that unemployment has fallen to pre-Thatcher levels, that prices remain relatively steady in the shops and that no one is predicting a run on the pound. So long as they don't live in the north or work for Barclays Bank, their world looks more secure than it has for decades. They are bound to ask, even if only sotto voce: "What's the point of complaining about everything when the government must be getting some things right?"

Inappropriate though it may seem for a Guardian columnist to offer advice to a Conservative leader, I feel so sorry for young William that I am moved to make some, I hope, helpful suggestions to assist him in his predicament. The first of these is that he should move the dreaded Widdecombe to a less high-profile job - something boring like foreign affairs, say, or maybe defence.

Oh yes, I'm well aware that she gets pop-star treatment at the Tory conference. But getting a shrieking ovation from the blue-rinse brigade is not going to win any votes - quite the reverse. The reaction of normal people to Widdecombe is either straightforward alarm or patronising mirth, neither of which plays well at the hustings. Worse still, Jack Straw sees her off with the greatest of ease. Whenever she demands some draconian measure, he caps it with an even more draconian alternative.

But a more serious suggestion is that Mr Hague should embark, and soon, on a programme of portentous speeches outside parliament, dealing with various major areas of policy. They will be boring events, to be sure, and I wouldn't want to be in the audience. But even if no one is listening, a little judicious hype will ensure that they generate the kind of intellectual aura which most party leaders try to acquire before stepping into office.

Wilson did it with "the white-hot heat of the technological revolution", Heath did it with Selsdon Man, Thatcher did it with the Right Approach and Blair did it with "New" Labour and the third way. And even if it was a fake in some of these examples, they all helped to fill the box of intellectual tricks which aspiring prime ministers are supposed to possess before they are judged ready for office.

Oh, and one final point. For goodness sake stay away from magazines like the repellent GQ. They aren't in the business of doing you any good, and will always ask damn fool questions like the one about your teenage beer drinking.

But don't lose sleep over those 14 make-believe pints. Remember John Major's O levels? Or Harold Wilson's barefoot journeys to school? Or Tony Blair's exploits as a stowaway? People don't really care, because most of them have bullshitted at some time in their lives. It's just a laugh, really.

webTitle: Excuse for drink driving that takes the cake

fields.headline: Excuse for drink driving that takes the cake
fields.trailText: A woman caught driving while over the alcohol limit escaped a ban yesterday after she claimed she had eaten Christmas cake laced with whisky.
fields.body:
A woman caught driving while over the alcohol limit escaped a ban yesterday after she claimed she had eaten Christmas cake laced with whisky.

Julie Wynne, 42, of Bulwell, Nottingham, was stopped by police on January 3 and gave a positive breath test, Nottingham magistrates heard.

Although she pleaded guilty, the court accepted her request not to be disqualified. She was granted an absolute discharge.

But the Campaign Against Drinking and Driving (Cadd) criticised the decision, insisting "over the limit is over the limit".

The AA said it hoped the defence would not be used by other drivers.

Wynne told the court how she had visited a friend and had some fruit cake. She later went to the pub with her partner, where she drank only two lagers.

But after police stopped her at just after midnight, a blood sample showed she had 86 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood. The legal limit is 80.

Wynne told the court she was baffled as to why she was over the limit until she studied the recipe for the cake.

Press Association

Zionists 'left Jews to die'

Israel's founding fathers did not lift a finger to help religious Jews in eastern Europe to escape the Holocaust, an MP of the ultra-orthodox Shas party said yesterday.

Shlomo Ben-Izri said leaders of the mainly secular Zionist movement did nothing to bring devout Jews into what was then Palestine.

AP, Jerusalem

Opposition to win in Paraguay

The opposition candidate, Julio Cesar, is likely to have taken the vice-presidency of Paraguay from the Colorado party, which has ruled for 53 years, in Sunday's poll.

With 90% of the vote counted, he was almost one percentage point ahead of Felix Argana, son of the murdered vice-president Luis Maria Argana.

Alex Bellos

Football fan decapitated

A Danish soccer fan who stuck his head out of the roof window of a bus was decapitated when it passed under a bridge, it was reported yesterday.

Reuters, Copenhagen

fields.headline: Sensitive boy kills neighbours
fields.trailText: Japanese fears of a wave of "Jekyll and Hyde" juvenile violence intensified yesterday when a "well-behaved and sensitive" schoolboy fatally stabbed three neighbours because the family had accused him of being a peeping tom.
fields.body:
Japanese fears of a wave of "Jekyll and Hyde" juvenile violence intensified yesterday when a "well-behaved and sensitive" schoolboy fatally stabbed three neighbours because the family had accused him of being a peeping tom.

The killing spree by the 15-year-old, who seriously injured three others, comes amid a sharp rise in murders by Japanese teenagers, many of whom appear to have snapped without warning.

According to police, the suspect broke into the farmhouse of the Iwasaki family at around 3am yesterday in Otsu in south western Japan. He then went from room to room stabbing the six occupants as they slept with a 10-inch survival knife.

Sumiko Iwasaki, 66, her daughter, Tomoko, 41, and her grandson, Junya, 13, died of their wounds. Kazumasa Iwasaki, Sumiko's 65-year-old husband, is in a critical condition, while two other children, Mai, 16, who attends the same school as the suspect, and 11-year-old Seiya, are in hospital with neck and back wounds.

"I did it out of anger because they wrongly accused me of peeping into their bathroom," the suspect, who cannot be named for legal reasons, told police. "I intended to kill the entire family and burn down their house because I felt I was being ignored by them all."

The triple murder is the latest and most brutal in a series of teenage crimes that threatens Japan's reputation as one of the safest countries in the world.

According to the national police agency, the number of murders by juveniles jumped from 27 to 53 in the first six months of this year.

The killings are certain to prompt more agonised soul-searching among politicians and media commentators about the state of a society in which frustration builds up in young people to the point where they explode.

Psychologists have blamed the phenomenon on exam stress, school bullying and the violence in video games, comics and television shows.

The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has called for a reform of the education system to promote more morality and respect for life.

Hiroko Mizushima, an MP who is also a psychiatrist, says the main problem is that Japanese children are not taught how to express their feelings.

Yesterday, the headmaster of the suspect's school described the teenager as "a well behaved, sensitive boy, who had trouble making friends. He was not the sort to share his worries with others."

fields.headline: Mind that child
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: We are very good at collective emotion when it comes to children. This was demonstrated recently by the nationwide response to Sarah Payne's abduction and death and, in a darker, more distorted way, by the paedophile witch-hunts being conducted on housing estates where locals claim child abusers are living.
fields.body:
We are very good at collective emotion when it comes to children. This was demonstrated recently by the nationwide response to Sarah Payne's abduction and death and, in a darker, more distorted way, by the paedophile witch-hunts being conducted on housing estates where locals claim child abusers are living.

Both are responses to the unbearable awfulness of what happened to a small girl and proof positive, surely, that we care passionately about what happens to all children not just our own. I, as much as anyone, was caught up in the sense of anguish and impotence. And like many others I longed for a way to do something to make the situation better. But if we step back from the emotion centred on Sarah and the irresponsible fanning of hatred against alleged paedophiles, spuriously justified as a response to public feeling, there is an important question to be addressed. How far are we prepared to go to try to protect children before something goes wrong, to act to prevent the small-scale abuses as well as the ones that enthral us with their horror?

This is not an idle question. Every day thousands of children are subjected to abuses of one kind or another, whether it is being emotionally neglected, humiliated, hit, sexually exploited by someone known or, far more rarely, abducted. And often enough it is happening where we can see, hear or know it if we care to do so, behind Designer's Guild curtains as well as on grim housing estates, by men and women who look unimpeachable as well as those who fit our stereotypes of men with shifty eyes, unkempt bodies and impenetrable lives.

Yet it is possible that much of this could be prevented or stopped if we reacted when we saw things that were worrying, disturbing or which seemed downright cruel. But to do so means burying our fears of interfering, of making a fool of ourselves, of getting it wrong. Easier to laugh and say we're being silly, that what we saw didn't mean what we feared it might. I know because I was confronted with just this a while back. I was in the carpark of a large supermarket one hot Sunday afternoon when the place was more or less empty. I saw two well-dressed men manoeuvring a small boy into the back seat of a smart saloon car. The child was protesting, although not very loudly. But I glimpsed his face. He looked scared and the men didn't seem to have much rapport with him.

It didn't feel right, but even so my first impulse was to reassure myself - two dads out shopping together, a tired child who was being troublesome. They were keen to get home for tea and had had enough. But what if it wasn't like that? What if next day I read in the paper that a small boy had been abducted from this supermarket... I took the number of the car before it drove off. Even then I hesitated before phoning the police, fearing that they would think me interfering, stupidly anxious. Instead when I phoned, apologising for troubling them, they told me it was the right thing to do, they would much rather get the call than not, they would check out the car and ring me back if they found anything worrying.

I am not alone. Some 750 people a week phone the NSPCC helpline to report anxieties about things to do with children, whether it's a slap in a shop or a succession of men visiting a house where a small girl lives. The charity talks it through with them then decides whether to ask social services or the police to act further. But an awful lot of people including, I suspect, some of those who are quickest to make a fuss or join demonstrations in a self-righteous way, do not see that protecting children means each of us taking responsibility for acting if we are worried.

Of course the flipside of this is that we must not mind if, as presumably happened with the two men I reported, we are stopped and questioned by police, visited in our homes by social workers and so on, uncomfortable and intrusive though this may be. If nothing is wrong it should be a short-lived interference. Isn't it worth putting up with if it is a result of someone trying to ensure that a child is safe and well?

At last, long after the passing of the Children's Act and the adoption of the UN Convention on Children's Rights, there does seem to be a growing awareness that children are society's responsibility as well as their parents'. But acting on this has to be more than the collective, and often symbolic, emotional catharsis that may make us feel good but may actually do little to protect children who are victims of the daily suffering which does not make the newspapers but goes on in our streets, our car parks, our society all the time.

fields.headline: President-elect 'employs children'
fields.trailText: Children under the age of 14 are working on the ranch of the Mexican president-elect, Vicente Fox, sowing onions and potatoes in contravention of laws banning child labour, a newspaper reported at the weekend.
fields.body:
Children under the age of 14 are working on the ranch of the Mexican president-elect, Vicente Fox, sowing onions and potatoes in contravention of laws banning child labour, a newspaper reported at the weekend.

The Mexico City daily Reforma said on Saturday that it had found at least 30 minors and teenagers being taken by truck into the Fox family ranch, San Cristobal, in the central state of Guanajuato, to work in the fields for about 65 pesos (about £4) a day.

The Mexican constitution bans children younger than 14 from working. Children between 14 and 16 are only allowed to work six hours a day, and the country recently ratified an International Labour Organisation convention against some of the worst forms of abuse of children as workers.

Nevertheless, child labour, especially in the impoverished countryside, is common.

Mr Fox, who recently returned from a tour of South America in his first foreign trip before taking office on December 1, spent the weekend at the ranch. His aides could not be reached for comment.

Reforma said that among the more than 30 youngsters picked up at 5.30am on Saturday were 12-year-old Jose, 13-year-old Juan and 11-year-old Sanjuana.

It said the children showed its reporter their 390-peso (£28) weekly paycheck. Reforma said that since the children were hired as seasonal workers, they received no other benefits.

Many of the children had left school to help earn money for their families. They worked from 7am to around 4pm, taking an hour lunch break.

A young man who appeared to be taking care of them, Mario, aged 20, complained about the hard work and low pay. "It barely pays for food and they don't pay you for every day you work," Mario said.

On July 2 Mr Fox broke the Institutional Revolutional party's 71-year grip on the presidency. Running for the conservative National Action party, he promised to battle against corruption and a widespread disregard for the law.

fields.headline: No one wants a he-man
fields.standfirst: On the political handicap of masculinity  Male-free holidays  Sex and Question Time
fields.trailText: Cristina Odone on the political handicap of masculinity  Male-free holidays  Sex and Question Time
fields.body:
If you were living in Oxford in 1981, chances were that sooner or later you'd open your front door to a floppy-haired undergraduate trying to sell silk-screen prints of furry animals. One of these door-to-door salesmen was none other than our own dear William Hague, trying to top up his student grant by selling the atrocious prints for his friend Guy Hands. Hague, who earned £10 per picture sold, has gone on to win glittering prizes - as indeed has Hands, who made millions in the City and is now in charge of the Millennium Dome.

This episode from the student days of the dynamic duo reveals young William's admirable spirit of enterprise and determination to improve his lot. Indeed, in wooing the electorate, Hague would have been better off revisiting his days as a student salesman than boasting about the 14 pints of beer he once downed. Hague the prints peddler would have inspired more confidence than Hague the beer-swilling lad.

I blame Amanda Platell. Hague's Australian-born spin doctor obviously thought that her charge needed to beef up his image. She was wrong. He-men win votes in Australia - Paul Keating - and in the States - JFK, LBJ, Bill Clinton. But in Britain, voters see red-blooded masculinity as a handicap in politics.

This is not based on a post-Monicagate suspicion that a Real Male politico is a skirt-chaser first, a policy-maker second. Even before la Lewinsky, the British could never elect an Übermensch to No 10: they are comfortable with wit, moral rectitude, and even the odd flash of cleverness, but maleness, like any element of foreignness, must be tempered. The Real Man candidate should learn from Disraeli, who hid his Jewishness behind a dandy's taste for flamboyance and a wit's talent for the bon mot; and Michael Portillo, who is trying to dilute his Spanish origins with confessions of having dabbled in le vice Anglais . In the same way, the all-male man should conceal his red-blooded instincts, swap the caveman bellowing for the softly-softly tones of wonk-speak, the manly strides for the cautious steps of the MP in fear for his marginal seat.

A he-man's high-testosterone levels and killer instinct make for an exciting character and a dramatic career - but how can they accommodate the dreary business of governing?

The androgynous Edward Heath would be quite happy to plod through the reports of his special advisers and discuss their merits with the minions. But specimens of unabashed malehood like Michael Heseltine or Paddy Ashdown would have shunned the wonks and stormed about No 10 listening only to No 1. Heseltine's nostril-flaring passion and Ashdown's action-man drive were great for rabble-raising, but you couldn't help thinking, as they pounded their chests and roared their mission statements, that in their eyes consultation, representation and collaboration were the stuff of ninnies. Real men heed gut feelings, not focus groups; they bark orders, and don't wait for consent.

Paragons of raw masculinity stir our suspicion that they'd find life in No 10 confining and not a little boring. After three years at the post, Tony Blair - new man, not he-man - looks thoroughly exhausted and as if he has been sucked dry by the office. But he-men feed off High Noon dramas, and no sooner would Alastair Campbell be settled in at Downing Street, familiar with the dispatch box, at home with cabinet debriefings, than he'd spend every waking moment plotting to turn up the national temperature with a lovely little war, a small invasion - anything, really, to prove his mettle and get the juices going.

In middle England, especially, raw masculinity in a politician stirs unease. This is not because the folk behind the chintz curtains and privet hedges fear a return to the primitive gender roles of caveman society. I'm sure there are a million bored housewives who nightly dream of playing Jane to some grunting Tarzan. But voters in the shires view virility as something alarmingly foreign that hints at the violence they associate with Latin, Caribbean and African males. In this light even the diminutive Robin Cook looks threatening - a man of lusty appetites who packs all kinds of unspeakable and unpredictable dangers in his gnomish figure. Foreign secretary is as far as this swordsman can go because the British prefer the cosy, thin-blooded niceties of the home-grown gentleman.

They used to tell women who wanted to go into politics to rein in their femininity; it seems only fair then to warn men with political ambitions that they should rein in their masculinity. Amanda Platell needs to tell Will to give another interview in which he lays off the booze but waxes lyrical about those furry animal prints he used to sell. Outside the colonies, this is how to win votes.

Women are flying solo

The list of reasons to have a man in your life is shrinking daily. You still need them to avoid having to ask the taxi driver to help you pull up the zipper on your dress that's stuck halfway up your back. But apparently more and more women are dispensing with men in the only other role I see for them - as travel companions. According to the travel industry, British women are increasingly going on solo holidays - 67% of them said they took their last holiday to get away from their husbands.

These are not Shirley Valentine wannabes looking for romance in the hairy arms of Pedro or Pierre. They're hedonists looking for luxury spas in Bali, Indian Ayurvedic massage and the ultimate shopping experience (Dubai, apparently). Men would just cramp their style. But who oh who do these women get to fan them as they recline in the tropical heat, who swishes the flies away in India and who keeps the sheikhs at bay in Dubai?

Sex and Question Time

The Fawcett society, which campaigns for equality between the sexes, is up in arms. Members watched one Question Time and found that three times as many men as women were asking questions of the panellists. Well, that's not great, but things have improved a lot since I was first asked to take part in the programme in the early 80s, when I was editor of the Catholic Herald.

The then producer, Sue Ayling, came to the Herald offices to quiz me about my stand on the issues of the day - old chestnuts like the republic, abortion and numbers of students in a classroom. At the end of our one-hour session, she asked if I would appear on the show. Chuffed that I'd passed the test, I readily agreed. Sue punctured my little balloon of hubris almost immediately: she confided that she was having a terribly hard time finding women who were ready to come on as panellists. Out of 10 women she asked, only one would agree to appear, whereas among 10 men, she'd find nine takers.

These days, instead, her successor in the job, Justina Plank, is being deluged by phone calls and faxes from women MPs desperately seeking their 15 minutes of fame. And having been on panels with Harriet Harman, Clare Short and Ann Widdecombe, I can tell you that even David Dimbleby had to fight to get a word in when these women were on a roll.

 Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman.

 Charlotte Raven is away.

These days, instead, her successor in the job, Justina Plank, is being deluged by phone calls and faxes from women MPs desperately seeking their 15 minutes of fame. And having been on panels with Harriet Harman, Clare Short and Ann Widdecombe, I can tell you that even David Dimbleby had to fight to get a word in when these women were on a roll.  Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman.  Charlotte Raven is away.

fields.headline: Stock market
fields.standfirst: Inverness
fields.trailText: Beef as it used to be, herb-enriched muesli, venison liver, wild rabbit and carrots and potatoes with soil on them! Needless to say this produce was not from the several supermarkets in the town but from a new venture, the Farmers Market, made up of several open air stalls in the central pedestrian precinct. You were spoilt for choice at one stall where there were cuts of red, roe and sika deer venison which is the only place I know in the Highlands where all three meats are on offer with sika being by far the best with its taste of goose.
fields.body:
Beef as it used to be, herb-enriched muesli, venison liver, wild rabbit and carrots and potatoes with soil on them! Needless to say this produce was not from the several supermarkets in the town but from a new venture, the Farmers Market, made up of several open air stalls in the central pedestrian precinct. You were spoilt for choice at one stall where there were cuts of red, roe and sika deer venison which is the only place I know in the Highlands where all three meats are on offer with sika being by far the best with its taste of goose.

This stall had other mouth watering cuts such as hare saddles, pheasant and mallard breast and wild rabbits. Already having sika meat in the deep freeze we bought some red deer liver and three whole rabbits with the latter working out at £1.50 each. One rabbit was later marinated in cider, rosemary, thyme and a bay leaf and was delicious. The beef stall was outstanding. It had lean beef from the Orkney Islands where the cattle are reared in the non-intensive way and, as the leaflet said, the islands were: "washed by the wild Atlantic Ocean storms of winter and bathed by the long hours of sunlight of the summer solstice".

As at Moy Fair the day before, there was a Black Isle Brewery stand with the light summer beer Goldeneye, the smooth bitter Red Kite and the dark, tangy porter, Thornbush. The contents of the seafood stall had come down from Helmsdale on the east coast of Sutherland and it was one of the few to have leaflets and in this case devoted solely to cooking prawns with illustrations of the different types in the centre pages. Salmon, shellfish and whitefish were on sale with the promise in the near future of a new smokery so that smoked fish will be on the stall.

Other stalls had fresh local strawberries and raspberries with another stall having less traditional meat in the form of ostrich fillet steaks, burgers or sausages although I understand the ostrich farms are on the decrease in the Highlands. The Farmers Market brought a taste and smell of the countryside into the middle of town, and judging by the numbers of people there its future is assured.

fields.headline: A vote for cloning
fields.standfirst:
Already battle lines are being drawn in the stem cell debate. I'm on the side of reason and progress

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The seminal 19th-century debate between the evolutionists and those who believed in divine intervention has many parallels in today's debates.
fields.body:
The seminal 19th-century debate between the evolutionists and those who believed in divine intervention has many parallels in today's debates. Science and anti-science lobbies recently collided in the controversy over genetically modified food although no one was quite as anti-science as the then Bishop of Oxford, Samuel Wilberforce, who led the attack on Darwin in the 19th-century debate on evolution. To this day, anti-evolutionist opinions hold sway in parts of the United States. There as here, then as now, "unnatural" is often raised as a reason for not proceeding with new science or technology.

No one should expect new technologies to be introduced without a wide-ranging public debate in or outside the media. The public will not be duped by technological language or arrogance based on being told what is best for them. They have a right to know the benefits or otherwise of new developments, be they telecommunication masts, mobile phones, genetically engineered food or new medical applications.

Indeed the government has, in the last three years, moved significantly towards setting up inquiries, commissions and reports to assess the science behind new developments and to pronounce on such issues, as well as to consider the precautionary principle as a mechanism for deciding to ban something or to allow it to operate within certain restrictions.

Different governments often interpret this science in different ways. Science should not be the final arbiter but it ought to give honest appraisal - to say what we know, what we do not know and how we should interpret current scientific knowledge.

And so it is with therapeutic cloning, the latest development that threatens to provoke these arguments once more and perhaps with as much intensity as the genetic modification debate.

Stem cells are often categorised according to the extent to which they are differentiated or, in other words, committed to develop into a particular cellular type (for example, blood cell, brain cell, liver cell). As a general rule, the earlier the stage of development of the tissues from which the stem cell is taken, the greater the range of cell types it can give rise to.

Embryonic stem cells, also called pluripotent, have the capability to turn into all of the cell types found in an adult animal. More highly differentiated stem cells, also called multipotent cells, may be derived from foetuses and adult tissues, although their capacity to produce different cell types is more limited than pluripotent cells.

Stem cells derived from early human embryos may, as has been shown in animal experiments, be induced to develop into more specialised cells making up organs and tissues like liver and kidneys, or even brain tissue. Embryos and foetuses are commonly used in mice and it is claimed that cells from human embryos and foetal tissue can be cultured in the laboratory as stable cell cultures. As tissues develop, some retain stem cells (such as skin, intestine and blood) while other lose these capabilities (such as heart tissue).

The term therapeutic cloning is confusing since it is associated with reproductive cloning. A term more favoured by scientists is "directed cell culture" or "specialised cell culture". The process involves the potential, for example, of injecting heart cells generated in the laboratory to repair heart damage in the individual. Degenerative diseases like Parkinson's, cystic fibrosis, hepatitis, diabetes, leukaemia and other blood disorders have great potential for stem cell therapy. At the same time there is the possibility of treating burns and fractures. We have still to carry out much research to develop the process from stem cell to tissue.

Rejection of tissue is another problem yet to be fully explored. Here a nucleus taken from the potential host is introduced into a human egg cell, previously emptied of all its nuclear content, and grown in a uterus. This reproductive cloning technique produced Dolly the sheep. However, therapeutic cloning prevents implantation into the uterus and the egg is allowed to develop to a stage where embryonic cells are produced. Such cells (less than 14 days old) could be reimplanted after growth in vitro into the nuclear parental donor without fear of rejection. No one has argued for reproductive cloning.

Here then is a technique with a great potential for human medicine over the next two decades. So why the objections? Why is the anti-abortion pressure group Life suspicious?

Part of the suspicion stems from the argument of when does life begin. Life scientists argue it is a continuum - eggs and sperm are alive, fertilised eggs die or are destroyed by nature, and the embryo has only potential for human life. Research on tissue derived from human embryos is regulated under the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 1990 by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority. This act allows the licensing of certain types of research involving human embryos up to the 14th day of development. At present, the act only allows the licensing of such research for specific purposes concerned mainly with studies on infertility, miscarriage and congenital disease.

The opposition to this new technology stated "the traditional belief that life is a gift from God to be treated with reverence and accorded profound and deep respect" (Lord Alton MP, parliamentary and scientific committee meeting, December 1999). This, they say, contrasts with treating embryos as a means to an end.

The questions posed are: is the deliberate creation of a human embryo for use in therapies permissible? Is it necessary? Are there alternatives - using stem cells from the patient's own body, for example? Can we learn from other sources than humans? Can any benefits outweigh the dangers posed by manipulation of the human species?

There is clearly a debate to be had to identify ethical considerations and to make choices clear. The battle lines are drawn and tempers look like getting frayed.

It does not seem too far from biological explanations of evolutionary process opposed by more religious ideology. Tampering with nature is an anathema to many but the history of scientific progress shows we do gain from scientific knowledge, but it must be divulged in an open participative society which is not centred in just one or two nations.

This is a global debate, which is necessary to ensure benefits extend across the planet on an equal basis, and that multinational corporations do not engineer the debate to reap financial profits. We must find time in parliament to debate the issues openly and thoroughly.

Dr Ian Gibson, MP for Norwich North, is chairman of the parliamentary office of science and technology, chairman of the parliamentary and scientific committee and a member of the House of Commons science and technology select committee.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •While Mr Tony Blair enjoys his Italian holiday, his enormous, rock-solid lead in the polls suggests a long and secure political future. Suppose, however, that as in Nigel Farndale's compelling new novel A Suitable Hanging, an assassin took Mr T out. Who would take over?
fields.body:
While Mr Tony Blair enjoys his Italian holiday, his enormous, rock-solid lead in the polls suggests a long and secure political future. Suppose, however, that as in Nigel Farndale's compelling new novel A Suitable Hanging, an assassin took Mr T out. Who would take over?

This is what West Highland terrier Steptoe, conqueror of TV's Thommo (45) in the 1995 Great Tipster Stakes, has been considering. After Gordon Brown's wedding the dog has revised his market as follows. Gordon Brown is now the 4-6 odds-on favourite, with current Blairite preference David Blunkett second best at 13-2. Jack Straw, John Prescott and Mo Mowlam are all 12-1, while O'Mandy Mandelson is 14-1. At 18-1, with Ken Livingstone and Sir Alex Ferguson, is public health minister Yvette Cooper. That's with a proper haircut. While she still looks like a swotty 14-year-old boy, Steptoe quotes her at 50-1. Bunched at 100-1, meanwhile, are Alan Milburn, Stephen Byers, Keith Harris, Orville, Margaret Beckett, Caroline from Big Brother, Robin Cook, Bruno Brookes and Geoff Hoon. Clare "Bomber" Short is 250-1. And so to our favourite UK tourist attraction: the Yelverton Paperweight Centre in Dartmouth. "Both the casual visitor and the serious collector," says the leaflet, "are fascinated by the range of beautifully handcrafted millefiori and abstract designs." I certainly was on Friday when I nipped in to what is "reputed to be the largest private collection open to the public in Europe." Indeed. The centre is only three miles from Drake's home, and some scholars may wish, in the light of this, to reassess what he originally had in mind for the potato. Admission is free, but parties of 25 or more should ring before a visit on 01822 854250.

Brace yourselves for some truly shocking news. Gerald Kaufman, who arrived last week on loan from Spitting Image producer Roger Law to prepare for his tour to Leeds in the Rolls-Royce Corniche RR1, has vanished. He was last seen in the office on Friday reading his Guardian and playing solitaire, but yesterday morning he was gone. Rumours that a party of Finnish tourists saw him in the West End negotiating with a tout outside Abba musical Mamma Mia are being investigated, but the police are taking the matter extremely seriously.

In the down-market Daily Telegraph, the Peterborough column impertinently tries to tease Steven Berkoff over an Observer article about the Edinburgh festival. "Yes there is in this festival an element of the preacher, the divulger of valued thoughts; the dissenter; lamentations on the state of man; burning issues; contentious views, passionate beliefs. We are gathered together," he goes on, "to bound our values, to weave a giant tapestry of beliefs." Wonderfully acute - and how dare my so-called rival seek to ridicule Steven over this. Frankly, I'm too angry to go on.

In the Spectator, meanwhile, my old friend Andrew Neil contributes his diary, taking as his main topic his own wealth, which runs to a home and a satellite dish in France. It's never easy writing in what is not one's natural tongue, and the boulevardier (Repton, Balliol and the Pamella Bordes Finishing School) is most brave to withstand the temptation to make any attempt, however vague, at humour. Well done!

From Dorset emerges a contender for August's PC Brains. One recent evening, the unnamed officer nipped home to pick up his sandwiches, and on a country lane between Weymouth and Dorchester he noticed in the rear-view mirror of his patrol van a menacingly stationary man. Affecting unconcern, he casually turned the van around and headed to the station for help. Only when the van was lit by street lighting did he realise who the stranger was: his own reflection in the perspex sheet between the cab at the front and the prisoners' cage at the back. Helmets off, PC Brains!

fields.headline: Shipping market bonanza
fields.trailText: Shipping markets are at their strongest for nearly 30 years, bringing a surge in business for owners such as P&O and London-stocklisted brokers, H Clarkson and Seascope Shipping Holdings.
fields.body:
Shipping markets are at their strongest for nearly 30 years, bringing a surge in business for owners such as P&O and London-stocklisted brokers, H Clarkson and Seascope Shipping Holdings.

But Shell might partly miss out on the bonanza because cracks have been discovered in two of its supertankers. The vessels could be out of service for refits just as hiring rates hit $50,000 a day.

However, Clarkson managing director Martin Stopford warns that shipowners have a habit of ruining their market prospects by over-ordering new vessels at the top of a cycle. The shipbroker's basket of indexes covering tankers, dry bulk carriers, containerships and gas carriers has hit $19,948 a day, $300 a day higher than its previous peak in February 1990.

P&O confirms that business is booming, ironically just weeks after it was forced to pull an initial public offering for its bulk shipping arm, ABC, due to lack of investor interest. The 21 bulk carriers of around 100,000 deadweight tonnes are now earning $18,000 a day compared with less than half this amount 12 months previously.

The container shipping arm P&O Neddloyd is expected to announce vastly better financial results on Thursday; the ferry division is also tipped to produce strong results next week.

P&O cruise ships are full and, despite wobbles on the New York stock market for cruise ship shares, P&O is set to press ahead with its separate listing for P&O Princess Cruises in America this October.
