fields.headline: Car sector drives currency debate
fields.standfirst: Japanese fight it out in Britain
fields.trailText: Followers of recent events in the car industry could be forgiven a degree of confusion. First there was Nissan dropping heavy hints that it might not pick its Sunderland plant as the venue for production of the new Micra because of the strength of the pound against the euro.
fields.body:
Followers of recent events in the car industry could be forgiven a degree of confusion. First there was Nissan dropping heavy hints that it might not pick its Sunderland plant as the venue for production of the new Micra because of the strength of the pound against the euro.

Next it was Toyota, again concerned about the exchange rate between the pound and the single currency, revealing that it was asking suppliers to invoice for new business in euros.

At the weekend, however, another Japanese car maker appeared to shrug off the currency worries of its two rivals with plans - warmly welcomed by Downing Street yesterday - to build a new factory and double its British output - much of it for export. So what price the strong pound (or weak euro) now?

Honda argues, as others including the likes of BMW have before it, that decisions over investment in the car industry should not be influenced by prevailing currency levels. Investment is a long-term commitment, currencies can fluctuate in short order - though sterling's strength against the euro has been rather longer lasting than many expected. A few years into the life of a new plant the currency rates which made it seem competitive or otherwise can have been completely reversed.

That said, it will be interesting to see the percentage of components orders which will go to suppliers in the euro-zone. It is worth noting, too, that though Honda is aiming a large proportion of the export production from the new plant into Europe some of it at least - up to 10,000 vehicles a year according to Japanese press reports, will go to Japan. Interesting, then, to look at the pound-yen exchange rate. Two years ago £1 bought ¥238 yen. Now it buys ¥163. In crude terms (and not counting transport costs and the like) a Japanese buyer of a car costing £10,000 had to pay ¥2.38m two years ago. Now it would cost ¥1.63m - quite a saving.

Such considerations may not have driven the decision to expand in Britain but Honda's planners are unlikely to have overlooked the possibility that what the company loses on the swings it might gain on the roundabouts. Meanwhile it is hard to avoid the feeling that the various interventions, overt or otherwise, by Japanese car makers into the euro debate in Britain are adding rather more heat than light.

As good as gilts

Britain's pensions industry has a problem. The minimum funding requirement has made long-dated and index-linked gilts popular with defined-benefit pension funds - to the point where some argue funds are effectively forced to buy them.

But while demand has increased supply has not. The government finances are in a healthy state. As a result liquidity in important areas of the gilts market has lessened with a consequent knock on effect on prices.

The MFR system is under review and the gilts market is awaiting the outcome with interest. Among the suggestions being canvassed are the establishment of central discontinuance fund which would be used to make good shortfalls in the pension schemes of companies that go bust and solvency insurance which, as its name suggests, would use insurance to guarantee benefit levels.

As usual there are snags. Insurance would be an additional cost. So too would be the central discontinuance fund - which was rejected in favour of MFR in the first place - though the safety net provided might make funds readier to invest in more diverse (and almost inevitably riskier) assets.

One possibility being looked at is Fred20, a proposal to change the accounting rules governing pensions in firms' accounts - which would open the way for funds to buy high rated corporate bonds. But as Ciaran Barr, the chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank, pointed out the supply of corporate bonds likely to be eligible is unlikely to be sufficient to solve the problem of the gilts market - though the Fred20 should provide a useful incentive to corporate bond issuers in the sterling non-government bond market.

German victory

Pessimists said it would never happen, that the German auction of third generation mobile phone licences would not reach the £22.5bn clocked up by the British auction.

They were wrong. The German auction has already topped the British total and is still rising.

That does not dispel the doubts about how the companies which get the licences will get a return on the money they have had to spend.

It is by no means certain that because the new generation phones will be able to offer more services, customers will be prepared to pay. What is does show is that the big players will pay almost anything to ensure a place in Europe's key market and that forecasting what will happen in the mobile phone market is a mug's game.

First there was Nissan dropping heavy hints that it might not pick its Sunderland plant as the venue for production of the new Micra because of the strength of the pound against the euro. Next it was Toyota, again concerned about the exchange rate between the pound and the single currency, revealing that it was asking suppliers to invoice for new business in euros. At the weekend, however, another Japanese car maker appeared to shrug off the currency worries of its two rivals with plans - warmly welcomed by Downing Street yesterday - to build a new factory and double its British output - much of it for export. So what price the strong pound (or weak euro) now? Honda argues, as others including the likes of BMW have before it, that decisions over investment in the car industry should not be influenced by prevailing currency levels. Investment is a long-term commitment, currencies can fluctuate in short order - though sterling's strength against the euro has been rather longer lasting than many expected. A few years into the life of a new plant the currency rates which made it seem competitive or otherwise can have been completely reversed. That said, it will be interesting to see the percentage of components orders which will go to suppliers in the euro-zone. It is worth noting, too, that though Honda is aiming a large proportion of the export production from the new plant into Europe some of it at least - up to 10,000 vehicles a year according to Japanese press reports, will go to Japan. Interesting, then, to look at the pound-yen exchange rate. Two years ago £1 bought ¥238 yen. Now it buys ¥163. In crude terms (and not counting transport costs and the like) a Japanese buyer of a car costing £10,000 had to pay ¥2.38m two years ago. Now it would cost ¥1.63m - quite a saving. Such considerations may not have driven the decision to expand in Britain but Honda's planners are unlikely to have overlooked the possibility that what the company loses on the swings it might gain on the roundabouts. Meanwhile it is hard to avoid the feeling that the various interventions, overt or otherwise, by Japanese car makers into the euro debate in Britain are adding rather more heat than light. As good as gilts Britain's pensions industry has a problem. The minimum funding requirement has made long-dated and index-linked gilts popular with defined-benefit pension funds - to the point where some argue funds are effectively forced to buy them. But while demand has increased supply has not. The government finances are in a healthy state. As a result liquidity in important areas of the gilts market has lessened with a consequent knock on effect on prices. The MFR system is under review and the gilts market is awaiting the outcome with interest. Among the suggestions being canvassed are the establishment of central discontinuance fund which would be used to make good shortfalls in the pension schemes of companies that go bust and solvency insurance which, as its name suggests, would use insurance to guarantee benefit levels. As usual there are snags. Insurance would be an additional cost. So too would be the central discontinuance fund - which was rejected in favour of MFR in the first place - though the safety net provided might make funds readier to invest in more diverse (and almost inevitably riskier) assets. One possibility being looked at is Fred20, a proposal to change the accounting rules governing pensions in firms' accounts - which would open the way for funds to buy high rated corporate bonds. But as Ciaran Barr, the chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank, pointed out the supply of corporate bonds likely to be eligible is unlikely to be sufficient to solve the problem of the gilts market - though the Fred20 should provide a useful incentive to corporate bond issuers in the sterling non-government bond market. German victory Pessimists said it would never happen, that the German auction of third generation mobile phone licences would not reach the £22.5bn clocked up by the British auction. They were wrong. The German auction has already topped the British total and is still rising. That does not dispel the doubts about how the companies which get the licences will get a return on the money they have had to spend. It is by no means certain that because the new generation phones will be able to offer more services, customers will be prepared to pay. What is does show is that the big players will pay almost anything to ensure a place in Europe's key market and that forecasting what will happen in the mobile phone market is a mug's game.

fields.headline: Hyder dilemma for takeover panel
fields.trailText: The takeover panel was seeking yesterday to preserve its authority as the City's arbiter on bids and mergers by finding a way to prevent the bidding war for Hyder, the Welsh utility group, ending up in the courts.
fields.body:
The takeover panel was seeking yesterday to preserve its authority as the City's arbiter on bids and mergers by finding a way to prevent the bidding war for Hyder, the Welsh utility group, ending up in the courts.

The full panel meets today to decide whether the panel executive was right to uphold a 365p-a-share offer made on Friday by Western Power Distribution, a US-owned energy company.

Rival bidder, the Japanese investment bank Nomura, has appealed against the executive's decision on the grounds that WPD did not follow procedure for flushing out the highest offer by Friday's deadline.

The uncertainty about the outcome of the bidding yesterday unsettled Hyder's shares, which ended the day 16p down at 367.5p. The Hyder board urged shareholders to take no action until the outcome of the panel's deliberations.

The panel, a self-regulating body which relies upon the co-operation of City institutions, is now faced with resolving the issue in a way which satisfies both WPD and Nomura.

City sources said that if it upholds the executive's decision in favour of the WPD bid, Nomura would probably seek a judicial review of the panel's handling of the affair. Such a move would weaken the panel's authority over the conduct of takeovers and mergers.

Three previous panel rulings in the late 1980s and early 1990s, have been subject to judicial review, involving Datafin, Guinness and the Fayeds.

If the panel decides to rerun the final bid process for Hyder, it will break one of the basic rules of the takeover code - that competing bidders may not increase their offers 46 days after the first counterbid is made.

Nomura, which had been leading the bid battle with a 360p offer, chose not to take part in the sealed bid procedure which the panel executive imposed on Thursday to ensure an orderly end to the bidding by Friday's deadline.

It is understood to have argued that WPD's higher offer was invalid since the US company failed to submit its sealed bid or announce its success by the deadlines set by the executive. However it said it was prepared to match the WPD offer price so that shareholders would not lose out.

WPD, on the other hand, is thought to have argued that its bid, valuing Hyder at about £565m, was submitted on time but that there were valid reasons for missing the deadline for the announcement for reasons which were accepted by the executive.

The panel, when it meets today, will have already seen written arguments by both bidders, and a written summary and position statement by the executive. They will then hear the financial advisers for both sides.

webTitle: Orange in regulator's line of fire

fields.headline: Orange in regulator's line of fire
fields.trailText: Mobile telecoms groups Orange and Sonera were in hot water with the German phone regulator yesterday after it emerged that the two companies may have had informal merger talks.
fields.body:
Mobile telecoms groups Orange and Sonera were in hot water with the German phone regulator yesterday after it emerged that the two companies may have had informal merger talks.

Both are members of rival consortiums in Germany's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences.

The rules of the auction forbid negotiations between rivals during the auction, which yesterday saw total bids for the four to six licences on offer at £24.9bn, topping the £22.5bn raised in the UK's third generation licence sale.

The auction only allows one licence for each company, and the penalty for any collusion is expulsion from the process.

Sonera yesterday said it had "strictly adhered to rules" in the auction, which banned such discussions.

Hans Snook, the Orange chief executive, confirmed during the weekend that both telecoms operators had talked to each other. But Mr Snook dismissed the possibility of a merger or takeover of Sonera as "pure speculation".

But his comments did prompt clarification from the German regulator's office, which later said it would not pursue a formal inquiry.

"Our need for information is not quite satisfied, but following talks it looks like there is no need for further investigation," said the regulator's president, Klaus-Dieter Scheurle.

A takeover of Sonera could be worth as much as $30bn.

However, Mr Snook has said that could be expensive, with Sonera's mobile business fairly priced but the fixed-line operations overvalued.

Sonera also has a wireless net portal, Zed, and software encryption system, SmartTrust, and minority holdings in other mobile operators.

Mr Snook said if Orange were to bid for Sonera it would have to wait until after the German auction of third-generation mobile licences.

He said Orange had not submitted a bid and would not comment on whether it planned to do so.

Orange, Britain's third biggest mobile phone operator, is planning a listing on the stock market, with the latest possible date being the end of the first quarter in 2001.

It is understood that Orange would prefer to make a share-based acquisition. However, the delay in its listing might mean that France Telecom, its parent, could issue shares to Sonera which could later be converted to Orange shares.

Sonera is 52.9% owned by Finland's government, which earlier this year was granted parliamentary approval to reduce that stake to zero.

In June, the Finnish government said it was seeking strategic partners for Sonera and the group has confirmed it has held "exploratory talks" with several unnamed parties.

 Orange launched a high-speed mobile net service for portable computers yesterday and said it would be the first UK mobile operator to offer fast access via mobile phones.

fields.headline: Xenova deal shapes up
fields.trailText: Xenova is close to signing up a development partner for its most advanced product, a drug for ovarian cancer.
fields.body:
Xenova is close to signing up a development partner for its most advanced product, a drug for ovarian cancer.

The Slough-based firm is in talks with several big pharmaceuticals companies to secure funds to take XR9576 into the final phase of trials this year.

XR9576 restores the susceptibility of cells to chemotherapy - to which some patients become resistant. In phase two trials during the spring, six out of 12 patients saw tumours shrink. Some analysts have suggested the drug could eventually have sales of more than £500m.

Xenova cut its half-year losses by 37% to £3.59m, largely due to the sale of two loss-making businesses - a discovery operation, which sought out plants and natural oils for medicines, and a Californian subsidiary, MetaXen, which developed computer models to show drugs' progress through the body.

Xenova's shares rose 2p to 88.5p.

fields.headline: Vodafone rises above inertia
fields.body:
Vodafone yesterday saw its improving prospects in the German UMTS mobile phone licence battle feed through to its shares, which added almost all of the 17 points provided by the telecom stocks on the FTSE.

According to analysts a reasonable price for the licences was in prospect after a rival German bidder pulled out. Vodafone closed at 276.5p, or 6.5p higher.

Colt Telecom shot up 55p to £19.35, helped by a Sunday newspaper tip that the firm's recent falls looked overdone.

Telecoms joined with pharmaceuticals to boost the FTSE 100, but despite a vigorous start the main market slipped back from its early highs. It closed up 0.6% at 6,419.9 points. Gainers outnumbered losers by about seven to three, though a mere 965m shares were traded.

The pharmaceuticals sector delivered 10 points of the FTSE gains, led by Glaxo Wellcome , up 22p to £19.48.

Smithkline Beecham and AstraZeneca were also both up 1.5% or more. Analysts suggested this sector, which is fundamentally strong, was still springing back from last week's dip, prompted by a patent setback for a US drugs firm.

However, not all branches of pharmaceuticals were up yesterday. PPL Therapeutics fell 10%, shaving about £10m off the company's market value.

The drop occurred after reports that the Roslin Institute, which cloned Dolly the sheep with PPL, will stop researching the use of pigs for human transplants due to concerns that it may pass diseases to humans.

PPL has had a bad time recently. Unsuccessful talks with potential partners for AAT, a treatment for cystic fibrosis, have been followed by analysts stating the company needs to raise more money.

Bioglan Pharma also dropped almost 4% yesterday. Analysts said that it was due to reports that the company was in the market to acquire parts of the Glaxo dermatological business.

WPP's company report saw its share price go up to 930p, driven by its first-half profits, which were up nearly 24%, beating analysts expectations.

The company is due to merge with US advertising firm Young & Rubicam, adding to its holdings of J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, transforming it into the world's largest advertising organisation.

Chief executive officer, Sir Martin Sorrell, cited strong revenue growth across their global operations.

The group predicted a buoyant second half boosted by the Olympics and US elections.

There has been strong growth in advertising revenues in the past year due to millennium celebrations, dot.com advertising and favourable economic conditions.

However, WPPs' closing price was 907p, down 1p.

Former shell firm Rodime surged 35% yesterday at the end of almost two months of suspension.

Rodime has now acquired Littlewoods football pools and gaming arm.

The company, owned by Trevor Hemmings, said underlying growth was exceeding internal forecasts.

The firm's shares were 6p higher to 23p.

Reuters saw its stock rise 19p to £12.78, following reports that 1,700 jobs could be cut as part of a two year restructuring plan to improve margins.

Oil and gas firms countered telecoms and drug firms, wiping 15 points off the FTSE 100. Shell fell 7.5p to 558.5p and BP went down 12p to 589p.

Analysts believed the falls were more about profit taking following a strong performance last week than any change in the sector's fundamentals.

Summing up the markets, one analyst concluded: "Investors are looking a little more constructive at the moment but there is still no tremendous risk appetite.

"There is not a lot of investment going on, something exacerbated by the summer holidays."

webTitle: Waterstone finds backers to help buy back chain

fields.headline: Waterstone finds backers to help buy back chain
fields.trailText: Tim Waterstone, the book retailing entrepreneur, has secured venture capital backing from Prudential Portfolio Managers in a bid to win back the high street chain that still bears his name.
fields.body:
Tim Waterstone, the book retailing entrepreneur, has secured venture capital backing from Prudential Portfolio Managers in a bid to win back the high street chain that still bears his name.

PPM is understood to have approached the advisers to HMV Media Group, the music retailer which at present owns Waterstone's, in the hope of opening negotiations. The chain has been valued at between £250m and £300m.

HMV Media is saddled with debt and under pressure to rid itself of Waterstone's before it can proceed with its planned float. The book retailing business has been suffering from increased competition and saw a 34% drop in profits last year to £37.2m at a time when book sales were booming.

HMV Media employed two investment banks earlier this year to review its options for Waterstone's and held discussions with at least two prospective buyers during the early summer.

Bertelsmann, the German media concern, and Borders, the US book store group which recently arrived on British shores, both made bids.

Bertelsmann owns online book retailing business BOL, while Borders owns the Books, etc chain and own-branded outlets for books and music.

Mr Waterstone had previously made an informal approach and had been temporarily suspended from the board of HMV Media - where he is chairman - in order to pursue a bid.

If Mr Waterstone buys back the chain it will be an extraordinary twist in the history of the company.

Since he founded the chain in 1982, the business has been sold to WH Smith and subsequently merged with Dillons and the HMV music chain.

Mr Waterstone is known to be unhappy with the way in which HMV Media has managed the bookshop business, and has accused the executive of dumbing down the chain.

He opened his first shop in the Old Brompton Road in west London and sold the then 20-strong chain of loss-making shops to WH Smith for £42m, making himself £10m in the process. Mr Waterstone also founded children's retailer Daisy & Tom.

Waterstone's, which includes the rebranded Dillons, has expanded to 300 outlets.

HMV Media is owned by music group EMI and Advent, the American venture capital firm.

fields.headline: Venture capital record
fields.trailText: Venture capitalists continued investing at record levels during the last three months despite market gyrations wiping out the value of newly listed corporations, according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Venture capitalists continued investing at record levels during the last three months despite market gyrations wiping out the value of newly listed corporations, according to a survey published yesterday.

PwC, the accountancy firm, found that the capital invested more than doubled to $19.58bn (£13bn) in the quarter to the end of June compared with a year ago; $18.7bn, or 95%, was directed towards technology-based companies.

Tracy Lefteroff, managing partner of the firm's venture capital practice, said: "If it's not tech, it's not happening."

This enthusiasm came immediately after the April sell-off of net-related shares in the US. Venture capital firms usually hope to recoup their initial investment in a company once it lists on the stock market.

Ms Lefteroff said the record funding reflected the long-term nature of investments as well as the cash raised by venture firms themselves.

Investments in the first half of this year, at $36.7bn, already top the $35.6bn invested in the whole of 1999. Both the number of companies invested in and the average amount invested had increased.

Although enthusiasm for the internet seemed intact there was a shift of sentiment. Most of the money was directed at services or infrastructure companies rather than pure commerce sites, Ms Lefteroff said.

"Investments are concentrating on the business of the internet itself, not the latest hot sites." Silicon Valley still attracted more capital than any other region.

fields.headline: At this price?  Abbey National
fields.trailText: The City was piling into Abbey National shares yesterday. The heavy buying was the result of the inevitable bid speculation in the aftermath of last week's move by Barclays to buy Woolwich.
fields.body:
The City was piling into Abbey National shares yesterday. The heavy buying was the result of the inevitable bid speculation in the aftermath of last week's move by Barclays to buy Woolwich.

That Abbey's sickly shares should have gained 10% since news of the deal broke last week could be interpreted as a little backwards, however. For months now Barclays has been considered the bank's most persistent predator and many in the City believe it was only after being rebuffed by Abbey that Barclays turned its sights on the smaller morsel Woolwich.

With such an obvious stalking horse out the way, it could be easy to believe that Abbey's chief executive, Ian Harley, could now breathe a little more easily. The City believes Mr Harley has already turned away Lloyds TSB but appears to remain convinced that Abbey will see some corporate action despite Mr Harley's apparent determination to retain the bank's independence.

The problem Mr Harley appears to face is that in a sector which is already out of favour with investors, Abbey is particularly unloved. This is despite his attempts to show the City that the bank is increasingly diversified away from its roots in the mortgage market, with more than half its profits being generated from other activities such as trading in the treasury markets and selling life and pensions policies.

Hawking his strategy, including his stand-alone internet bank Cahoot about the City, does not appear to be having the desired effect. While the few friends the bank has kept might believe the share buying spree is merely investors taking advantage of its share price weakness, the more cynical view is that the bank needs a partner. The battle Mr Harley faces is that Abbey is starting to be spoken of in the same terms as NatWest, which became so unloved that it received an unprecedented two hostile bids.

It is this underlying mood that Abbey needs to shake off. The stock is a "no brainer" in the words of one analyst. Even with the gains already made it is still worth piling into.

The City believes Mr Harley has already turned away Lloyds TSB but appears to remain convinced that Abbey will see some corporate action despite Mr Harley's apparent determination to retain the bank's independence. The problem Mr Harley appears to face is that in a sector which is already out of favour with investors, Abbey is particularly unloved. This is despite his attempts to show the City that the bank is increasingly diversified away from its roots in the mortgage market, with more than half its profits being generated from other activities such as trading in the treasury markets and selling life and pensions policies. Hawking his strategy, including his stand-alone internet bank Cahoot about the City, does not appear to be having the desired effect. While the few friends the bank has kept might believe the share buying spree is merely investors taking advantage of its share price weakness, the more cynical view is that the bank needs a partner. The battle Mr Harley faces is that Abbey is starting to be spoken of in the same terms as NatWest, which became so unloved that it received an unprecedented two hostile bids. It is this underlying mood that Abbey needs to shake off. The stock is a "no brainer" in the words of one analyst. Even with the gains already made it is still worth piling into.

fields.headline: Takeover threat to 100-year old brewery
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries' 110-year history as an independent public company is under threat from a firm of venture capitalists, Botts & Company, which last night revealed it was preparing a takeover bid.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries' 110-year history as an independent public company is under threat from a firm of venture capitalists, Botts & Company, which last night revealed it was preparing a takeover bid.

In an unexpected statement to the stock exchange, Botts said it was working on an offer with Robert Breare, who was recently responsible for closing down Ushers of Trowbridge's Wiltshire brewery.

The announcement was in response to a 20p rise in Wolves & Dudley's shares to 375p, valuing the business at £270m. Botts' director, Robin Black, said his firm had tried to contact directors of Wolves prior to issuing its statement but had been unsuccessful: "We would like to speak to their board and engage in constructive discussions."

Wolves & Dudley is Britain's biggest regional beer company, with four breweries and more than 1,700 pubs. Its biggest sellers are Banks' and Pedigree bitter, and its retail estate includes the Pitcher & Piano chain of bars.

Wolves' chief executive, David Thompson, would only say: "I have no comment to make at all."

Mr Thompson is likely to fight any offer vigorously - he is a descendant of the west Midlands family of maltsters who founded the business in the last century.

Wolves & Dudley is becoming used to takeover battles - during the last two years it has made unsolicited bids for three competitors.

fields.headline: Manufacturers squeezed
fields.trailText: Manufacturers are struggling to increase the prices they charge for goods at the factory in the face of rising fuel and material costs, new figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Manufacturers are struggling to increase the prices they charge for goods at the factory in the face of rising fuel and material costs, new figures showed yesterday.

While input prices rose by 0.4% in June, according to the office for national statistics, factory gate prices rose by 0.2% over the month.

"Output prices once again rose only modestly in July, suggesting that firms are either unwilling or unable to pass higher costs along the inflation pipeline despite recent hints of stronger demand for their products," said Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics.

Inflation in fuel and material costs has been running at more than 10% for most of the last nine months, according to the ONS, while outprice inflation has been less than 3%.

Jeremy Hawkins at Bank of America said the fact that input prices were rising rapidly could cause concern at the Bank of England.

"That's at least one reason to expect them to look at the pound... In the main they have got to be pretty happy that general domestically generated inflation pressures within manufacturing continue to be fairly subdued."

Although factory gate prices have not kept pace with increased costs, they have crept up steadily. The annual rate for core goods, which excludes volatile components like food and petrol, is now at a four-year high of 1.2%.

Despite creeping factory gate prices, analysts believe that the inflation watchers at the Bank of England are more concerned about price pressures in the services sector. Today's retail prices data are likely to show that inflationary pressures in this sector are still a problem.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Murdoch buys Chris-Craft

News Corp announced it has bought Chris-Craft Industries and its two main subsidiaries BHC Communications and United Television for $5.35bn (£3.6bn) in cash and shares.

The deal, which is expected to be immediately earnings enhancing, will boost News Corp's television presence in the US, leaving it with 13 stations in the top 10 markets and 20 in the top 20 markets, subject to any divestitures which may be required by regulators. The businesses will be integrated into News Corp's Fox Entertainment Group.

Under the terms of the deal $2.13bn will be paid in cash, with the remainder in News Corp ADRs. Fox will issue 122.2m new shares to finance the deal.

DTI defers Gannett deal

The DTI said it has referred to the competition commission the proposed acquisition by Gannett UK, a unit of Gannett Co, of Regional Independent Media Holdings' newspaper title Blackpool Now, together with related assets.

De Beers wins Winspear gem

The directors of Canada's Winspear Diamonds agreed yesterday to a sale to De Beers for five Canadian dollars a share after a vigorous fight to fend off the South African company's earlier hostile bid. De Beers, targeting Winspear's promising diamond project in northern Canada, raised its bid for Winspear from C$4.25 a share. Winspear said in a joint statement that its board unanimously supported the deal and that directors would deposit shares amounting to about 15.4% of the company's total share float for the De Beers offer.

AMD's PC chip beats Intel

Chip manufacturer Advanced Micro Devices yesterday began shipping 1.1-gigahertz processors for personal computers to major computer manufacturers, and said it expected to meet its goals for shipments in the coming quarters. Advanced Micro Devices has been in a seesaw battle with competitor Intel to produce the fastest processors. Earlier this year it just beat its rival with a chip running at one GHz, or one billion cycles a second.

Kingston sells software stake

Kingston Communications yesterday offloaded its remaining stake in software firm KSCL as it tightened its focus on telecoms. Edinburgh-based KSCL, which is majority-owned by venture capitalist 3i Group, provides customer care and billing software for mobile phone firms. Telesens, planning to change its name to TelesensKSCL, said it planned to develop billing services for the third generation mobile phone market. Kingston will receive £26m for its 24.9% stake in KSCL - which was taken over by Kingston in 1991 and sold to its own management in 1999 with backing from venture capital group 3i and Royal Bank Development Capital.

fields.headline: Weblines
fields.body:
Taking a trip? Internet service provider World Online UK has set up a mini site to prepare women for holidaying abroad. In addition to practical advice on how to recognise potentially dangerous situations, the site includes an interactive quiz to test whether you're savvy about safety. Users can also enter their destination to generate and download a credit card-sized print-out of local police and consulate phone numbers. The Travelsafe site is in the travel section of www.worldonline.co.uk.

 If cycling's your thing, log on to www.bikemagic.com to find other women cyclists in your area. Just enter your postcode, then search the site's database for local clubs and cyclists, as well as routes and bike merchandise outlets.

 With parliament in recess and the silly season upon us, what better time to pay a visit to alternative Westminster website http://members.tripod.co.uk/commonswatch? The tongue-in-cheek site offers "an entirely honest, hugely biased" guide to the more notable personalities in the present House of Commons. Politicians covered include Mo "saucy gags" Mowlam, Gordon "Heathcliff" Brown and Michael "the Castilian hunk" Portillo. If you can't wait until autumn for an MP fix, this is the next best thing.

 Brassy Brummie Caroline may finally have been kicked out of the Big Brother house, but fans of the tousled, pouty one can soon read her post-eviction account of the show online. Channel 4's www.bigbrother.terra.com already includes soul-searching interviews with recently-evicted housemates Sada and Andy, and mini biogs of all 10 participants give the lowdown on their intimate secrets. Want to know who can't live without a vibrator or who has a phobia about chickens? This site is for you.

 If voting on which Big Brother housemate goes has left you hungry for more DIY entertainment, log on to www.itsyourmovie.com. Billed as the world's first interactive internet movie site, it asks viewers to help write the script and decide the fate of the characters involved in its online films. Currently showing is Running Time, described as "an edgy thriller set in London", which revolves around the fortunes of "feisty bike courier" KJ. Fans of 80s band T'Pau (remember China in Your Hand?) may spot the striking resemblance between Running Time's heartless business tycoon Sinead Weare and T'Pau lead singer Carol Decker. Log on now and put her fate in your hands.

webTitle: Standup comedian Shappi Khorsandi shows no fear

fields.headline: 'Get off, you're ugly!'
fields.standfirst: With heckling like this, who'd want to do stand-up? The secret is to show no fear, says Shappi Khorsandi
fields.trailText: With heckling like this, who'd want to do stand-up? The secret is to show no fear, says Shappi Khorsandi
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher started it - I was impersonating her at the age of six! That gave me a taste for making people laugh and I was encouraged by my father - he's a satirist and has been doing stand-up for five years. After I moved to London in my early 20s, I spent every night in comedy clubs, desperately wanting to perform. But it takes a huge amount of confidence to admit to yourself that this is what you want to do because comedy doesn't have a job plan. I was a confirmed comedy groupie long before I ever plucked up the courage to give it a go.

Most people spend a year or two as a comedy circuit "try-out", traipsing around London doing open spots in clubs and five-minute sets in rooms above pubs, often to an audience of no more than 10. You spend a lot of time on the phone trying to grab gigs and sell yourself to bookers who get a million calls like that each day.

Much is made of the fact that there aren't many women in stand-up and it's during this initial period that more women than men are likely to give up. It's the same old story as in so many professions - to get noticed, women have to be better.

Often, the audience sees you as a woman first and a comic second, whereas when a man walks out on stage, he is first and foremost a comic. My mother always said a man's idea of a woman with a sense of humour is someone who laughs at his jokes and I see that sometimes with the rowdier guys in the audience. I tend to be heckled more by men than by women and often their jeering focuses on my appearance. One guy shouted "Get off, you're ugly!" and I've had "Show us your tits!" and "You've got fat thighs!" before now - my typical audience comprises intellectuals, as you can see. But if I show the slightest sign of fear, the audience will lose confidence in me far more quickly than they would in a man.

Female comedians are often compared with one another when really what we do on stage isn't any different from what the boys are doing. We're comics, just like them - I certainly don't categorise myself as a "female" comedian. I'm Iranian and I talk a lot about that - I see that as the thing that sets me apart from other acts.

In some ways I feel I am flying the flag for women in comedy because the more women get into the business, the less our material will be analysed. At the moment we are in the minority, so if one woman goes on and does atrocious, stereotypical gags, then it reflects badly on the rest of us - many new women comics refrain from "tampon gags" because it is such a step backwards.

I rarely sit down with the intention of creating new material. I'll write down funny things I hear during the day and before a gig I'll focus on the topics I want to explore. I try new jokes on stage first, then work out the structure at home. The ability to improvise comes with experience - try it when you're new and you risk opening a can of worms.

Comedy, for both men and women, has become increasingly competitive in the past 10 years. I entered the BBC New Comedy Awards this year and won the London semi-final, which takes me to today's grand final at the Edinburgh Festival. The festival is a crazy playground and there are a lot of excellent new female comics being showcased. If I win, it will give my parents something to gloat about to all their friends, but the best thing for me is that the event is televised - that kind of exposure is invaluable.

There is one other woman in the final and the two of us have been joking about "handbags at dawn" on the day. Whatever happens, we are determined to give the guys a run for their money.

 The BBC New Comedy Awards final is at the Edinburgh Festival today; it will be on BBC Choice on August 31, BBC 1 on September 2.

fields.headline: Twisted sisters
fields.standfirst: Last week, a teenage girl was charged with rape. A shocking lone incident or a sign of rising woman-on-woman violence?
fields.trailText: Last week, a teenage girl was charged with rape. A shocking lone incident or a sign of rising woman-on-woman violence?
fields.body:
Girl, 18, Faces Rape Charge." As headlines go, it is as chilling as it is unusual. On Friday, Claire Marsh, accused of cheering on an alleged sex assault on a canal towpath, was charged with rape. She was also charged with indecent assault and conspiracy to rob. Scotland Yard claimed the young woman had been charged because she allegedly acted as a "principal" with three boys suspected of carrying out the attack. Two other girls, aged 14 and 16, are among four teenagers who have been arrested and charged with intimidating a witness.

Angela Carter wrote In the Company of Wolves: "If there's a beast in man, it meets its match in woman." Her words appear prescient now. Whatever the outcome of this case, the very idea that a woman could be capable of involvement in another woman's rape is hard to stomach.

Reported incidents of rape by women are extremely rare but not unheard of. In 1977, there was the infamous case of Joyce McKinney, an American drama student who followed ex-boyfriend Kirk Anderson to Esher, Surrey, where he was working as a Mormon missionary. With an accomplice, she kidnapped him at gunpoint and drove him to a cottage where she chained him to the bed and, he claimed, forced him to have sex. She was arrested and the case brought to court, but she escaped British justice by fleeing the country while on bail, using a false passport, and disappearing into the wilderness of America's Appalachian mountains. Tracked down last year, she told an interviewer: "Everywhere I go, people always remember me as a woman who did the unthinkable - raped a man."

Women becoming involved in sexual assaults is a phenomenon more prevalent in the US, where young women are deeply entrenched in the tribal initiation rituals of gang culture. Anne Campbell, a psychologist at the University of Durham, has studied the behaviour of girls in gangs, both in the UK and in New York. "I first heard about women getting involved in rapes when I was working with gangs in America," she says. "The girls would procure other girls for the guys - girls outside the gang - and would be involved in holding them down while the men raped them. Sometimes they'd go even further than that. But those would be extreme situations, perhaps where one woman had a grudge against another."

In her book, The Girls in the Gang, Campbell asserts a Darwinian influence on the escalation of violent behaviour among women towards women. "If you look at evolutionary theory, it tells us men use aggression to gain status and dominance, and thus preferential access to the most desirable women in their community. It used to be that all a woman had to do to get the most desirable man was to look good. That's changing now, so we're seeing more aggressive behaviour in women towards other women."

There has been an increase in Britain in the number of violent crimes among girls under 18. In 1981, 65 girls were convicted of such crimes per 100,000 of the population; by 1997, that figure had reached 135. Last year, a survey by Loughborough University revealed that 80% of respondents, aged 14-18, had been involved in at least one physical fight; 15% of those claimed to have felt a high after the event. A larger study, by Demos, of 2,000 women aged 18-24, indicated that 13% thought it was acceptable to use physical violence to get what they wanted.

In recent years, there have been several high-profile cases to reflect this upswing in female violence. Some of the stories were hyped to a frenzy, most notably Liz Hurley being held at knifepoint by a girl gang. These girls turned out not to be London's answer to Tank Girl or Lara Croft but three homeless teenagers looking for money to buy a burger - a fact that went largely unreported. More seriously, last November, a judge was prompted to "name and shame" a gang of 14-year-old girls who carried out knifepoint robberies on other girls.

Another case, in south London, involved a 14-year-old being set upon by a gang of girls aged between 11 and 14. She was stripped, beaten, her skin drawn on, her hair pulled out and it was claimed she was offered to a gang of boys as a rape victim. Greenock teenager Barbara Gillen was tortured and abused for two days by a gang of five teenage girls, while Louise Allen, 13, was kicked to death by two female members of the Canada Square Gang in Northamptonshire back in 1996.

Women may be seeking power by imitating male behaviour but there are other reasons for the rise in violent crime among young women. "Girls used to be segregated off a lot more in terms of their activities and leisure time. Now they tend to join in with their male peers, so you get cases of them being involved in traditionally male crimes," says Rachel Lipscomb, deputy director of the Magistrates Association, who has worked with youth courts since 1985. "In addition, girls are drinking far more than they used to. You can't overestimate the impact that that has on triggering aggressive behaviour. Latest figures suggest alcohol is a factor in between 78 and 87% of all violent crimes."

Drugs are another factor. According to Maggie Hall, project director of Women In Prison, a large proportion of the young women they see are addicted to crack. "You can come up with all the theories you like about why a girl would behave violently, but if she's puffing on a crack pipe and drinking a lot, logic doesn't prevail."

Hall also advises that we look more closely at the statistics. "OK, so you see there's a big increase in violent assaults. But then, when you ask a few questions, you build a different picture. Assault can mean pushing a store detective away or spitting at a policeman. I'm not saying those actions are right - they are not - but do they really constitute violent assault?"

There are others who say women's propensity towards violent behaviour is nothing new. "Throughout history, there have been certain issues that have triggered violent behaviour in women. Look at how women behaved in the French Revolution and again during the suffragette movement," Lipscomb says. "I'm not sure that what we're seeing is anything new."

"If you look at evolutionary theory, it tells us men use aggression to gain status and dominance, and thus preferential access to the most desirable women in their community. It used to be that all a woman had to do to get the most desirable man was to look good. That's changing now, so we're seeing more aggressive behaviour in women towards other women." There has been an increase in Britain in the number of violent crimes among girls under 18. In 1981, 65 girls were convicted of such crimes per 100,000 of the population; by 1997, that figure had reached 135. Last year, a survey by Loughborough University revealed that 80% of respondents, aged 14-18, had been involved in at least one physical fight; 15% of those claimed to have felt a high after the event. A larger study, by Demos, of 2,000 women aged 18-24, indicated that 13% thought it was acceptable to use physical violence to get what they wanted. In recent years, there have been several high-profile cases to reflect this upswing in female violence. Some of the stories were hyped to a frenzy, most notably Liz Hurley being held at knifepoint by a girl gang. These girls turned out not to be London's answer to Tank Girl or Lara Croft but three homeless teenagers looking for money to buy a burger - a fact that went largely unreported. More seriously, last November, a judge was prompted to "name and shame" a gang of 14-year-old girls who carried out knifepoint robberies on other girls. Another case, in south London, involved a 14-year-old being set upon by a gang of girls aged between 11 and 14. She was stripped, beaten, her skin drawn on, her hair pulled out and it was claimed she was offered to a gang of boys as a rape victim. Greenock teenager Barbara Gillen was tortured and abused for two days by a gang of five teenage girls, while Louise Allen, 13, was kicked to death by two female members of the Canada Square Gang in Northamptonshire back in 1996. Women may be seeking power by imitating male behaviour but there are other reasons for the rise in violent crime among young women. "Girls used to be segregated off a lot more in terms of their activities and leisure time. Now they tend to join in with their male peers, so you get cases of them being involved in traditionally male crimes," says Rachel Lipscomb, deputy director of the Magistrates Association, who has worked with youth courts since 1985. "In addition, girls are drinking far more than they used to. You can't overestimate the impact that that has on triggering aggressive behaviour. Latest figures suggest alcohol is a factor in between 78 and 87% of all violent crimes." Drugs are another factor. According to Maggie Hall, project director of Women In Prison, a large proportion of the young women they see are addicted to crack. "You can come up with all the theories you like about why a girl would behave violently, but if she's puffing on a crack pipe and drinking a lot, logic doesn't prevail." Hall also advises that we look more closely at the statistics. "OK, so you see there's a big increase in violent assaults. But then, when you ask a few questions, you build a different picture. Assault can mean pushing a store detective away or spitting at a policeman. I'm not saying those actions are right - they are not - but do they really constitute violent assault?" There are others who say women's propensity towards violent behaviour is nothing new. "Throughout history, there have been certain issues that have triggered violent behaviour in women. Look at how women behaved in the French Revolution and again during the suffragette movement," Lipscomb says. "I'm not sure that what we're seeing is anything new."

webTitle: Business: Investment banks go for gold in the world of sport

fields.headline: Players cash in when the cheering stops
fields.standfirst: Investment banks go for gold in the world of sport
fields.trailText: Investment banks go for gold in the world of sport
fields.body:
It is the issue that has been dominating the back pages of the tabloids all summer. David Beckham, Manchester United's star player, has reportedly fallen out with his boss Sir Alex Ferguson and could be moving overseas for a world record transfer fee.

Offers of £40m are said to have been tabled by foreign clubs. Mr Beckham is reputedly being offered a £2m signing on fee and £120,000 per week to forsake Manchester for Milan. Mrs Beckham could even get her own TV show as part of the deal.

While football transfer fees and players wages have seemingly spiralled out of control this summer, big City institutions have started to set up wealth management divisions aimed at sports' huge earners. If David and Spice Girl wife Victoria do decide to pack their bags for Italy it would be little surprise to see advisers from Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse Group and UBS Warburg jostling with the paparazzi on their villa doorstep.

Merrills is the latest Wall Street group to start providing asset management services for athletes and "celebrity net-worth individuals".

Unrivalled roster

Last month it announced a joint venture with sports agency IMG's Investment Advisers International to form McCormack Advisers International. IMG was founded in the 1960s by Mark McCormack, the grandfather of sports agents. Driven by the success of his first client, the golfer Arnold Palmer, he now boasts an unrivalled roster of clients, including the Williams sisters in tennis, US basketball player Vince Carter and golf's Tiger Woods.

According to Merrill Lynch vice chairman John L. Steffens, the entity will offer wealth-management strategies and advisory services, including financial planning, tax preparation, cash and investment management and income collecting. They will be competing with Swiss banks UBS Warburg and CSFB which have both launched financial management services tailored to sports players.

Previously private banking was the preserve of wealthy, long-established families but twenty-something athletes on Hollywood-style wages are now just as exciting a proposition.

UBS's team is based in London and headed by Neil Grainger, who previously spent 20 years working at IMG, and Paul Miller, a Uefa cup winner with Tottenham Hotspur, who has been working in private banking for the past seven years. While the company says it has advised sports stars on their finances for several years, spiralling players wages have encouraged it to expand operations.

"We want to offer athletes cradle to grave financial advice," Mr Miller says. "We're not just about asset management, we will help with ISAs, pensions, insurance against injury, property, estate management, the lot.

He says footballers go through three five-year stages in their career. Between 16-21 they are at the apprentice stage and need to be helped with the basics of financial management. In their mid-to-late 20's they are at peak earnings stage and then they enter winding down time. Footballers need to take a different financial approach to each of those stages.

Even today many footballers think that investing for the future means buying the local pub. Although sports stars have a potential for rapid escalation of earnings while they are playing sport, they rarely have a second chance to recreate any "lost" wealth, UBS says.

"When I was playing we got little advice on financial planning and much of it was not brilliant," adds Mr Miller. "I've been down the same road as today's players, played in cup finals, moved club and had to renegotiate contracts, so they can relate to me." UBS is targeting the richest sports: football, tennis, golf and motor sport. On the purer entertainment side it is also building up a client list from the worlds of media, pop and classical music.

The bank plans to extend its presence to Germany, Italy and the United States. "If a young man is transferred from London to Barcelona, UBS in Barcelona can take charge of his affairs," says Mr Miller. Rival Swiss bank Credit Suisse offers a service in partnership with Interbroke, a British-based sports insurer, providing coverage for things like loss of sponsorship contracts, or injury and similar risks as well as financial advice. It has 100 clients, aims for 1,000 by 2003 and is run by Olivier Jaquet, who was a silver medallist at the 1994 World Fencing Championship. Both banks work closely with leading accountancy and legal firms because of the complex financial and tax issues that high-earning sports stars face.

Dodgy knees

Extended family members often need to be provided for and pensions that kick in when the knees give up at 35 need to be arranged. Chicago Bulls basketball player Ron Artest reportedly employs a security consultant, a clothier and a barber, as well as supporting several family members.

Many of the world's top tennis players and motor racing drivers have started to manage their tax liabilities by basing themselves in havens like Monaco (David Coulthard) and Bermuda (Pat Rafter) when they are not on tour.

Yet not even some of the world's leading entrepreneurs and oldest dynasties can compete with the allure of British Open golf winner Tiger Woods. The 24-year-old's career earnings could reach $6bn, according to ESPN magazine. Suddenly the odds on Merrill Lynch or UBS opening a branch at St Andrews don't seem so fanciful.

Top earners per year

Britain

1. Lennox Lewis, Boxing, £16.6m

2. Nasseem Hamed, Boxing, £ 8.7m

3. Damon Hill, Motor racing, £5.6m

4. Steve McManaman, Football, £4.75m

5. Eddie Irvine, Motor racing, £4.1m

International

1. Michael Schumacher, Motor racing, £30.6m

2. Tiger Woods, Golf, £29.38m

3. Oscar de la Hoya, Boxing, £27.19m

 Source: Forbes/BBC Radio 5 Live Sports Yearbook

fields.headline: News from the fringe
fields.standfirst: Arthur Smith's daily dose Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Arthur Smith's daily dose
fields.body:
This festival, I fear, is going to be a disaster for me. Arriving at Waverley station, I stepped off the train and fell and twisted my knee. Then I spent two miserable hours sitting outside my Edinburgh flat waiting for someone to turn up with the key. I put a hat down - got no money.

During this dismal interlude I read an article by Steven Berkoff: "Here can at last be revealed the actor. Stripped down. Bare. Unadorned. Unshackled. Hercules unchained. You have nothing to lose but your chains_" How purple can prose be? Normally this guff would make me laugh, but somehow the knee and the absence of anywhere to live made it depressing.

Later I bumped into Alan Smith, whose wife Janet had bought him a trip to Edinburgh and booked him tickets for virtually every comic I've ever heard of. It was his 40th birthday present. "I'm in comedy heaven," he sighed. My cynicism evaporated and I found myself dancing badly to a Bonzo Dog tribute band. Well, I think I did.

You can contact Arthur Smith via arts@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Legends are made of this
fields.standfirst:
Lyn Gardner rejoices at the return of Hopeless Games, one of last year's most startling - and under-attended - fringe hits

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner rejoices at the return of Hopeless Games, one of last year's most startling - and under-attended - fringe hits
fields.body:
The Edinburgh festival fringe is probably the only place in the world where you can become a legend in three weeks. Nowhere else are theatrical myths forged so quickly: Tom Stoppard was discovered through Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, Manfred Karge's Conquest of the South Pole appeared during Jenny Killick's golden age of the Traverse in the mid-80s, and Theatre de Complicite won - of all things - the Perrier award in 1985.

Last year it was the turn of Do/Fabrik, a Russian-German company whose physical theatre piece Hopeless Games stole into Edinburgh and played a handful of performances. Most of those were half-empty. By the time word got round that Hopeless Games was the real McCoy, the company had melted into the night.

The good news is that the show is back for an extended run this year and more than lives up to its own legend. It is an extraordinary hour of distinctly European theatre that integrates live action with video and an eerie soundscape to take the audience on a playful journey into the heart of darkness.

Perhaps the reason its potent images speak so eloquently is that they were created out of a failure of words. When Potsdam's Fabrik Theatre decided to join forces with St Petersburg's Do Theatre, a company known in the late 80s and early 90s for its extremist body theatre, the two companies had no common language. The difficulties of communicating with each other made for a tense and often frustrating rehearsal period, but led to an impressive level of cooperation on stage. Those who dream of creating British ensembles should see Hopeless Games and weep.

It could be about the Holocaust and it could be about Kosovo. It could be about the desperate asylum seekers who die in the attempt to reach these shores. It could just be about the world's losers, the failed would-be suicides and all our broken hearts. The beauty of Hopeless Games is that it is sufficiently open-ended that audiences can interpret it as they like. But it is not in any way imprecise. The company is well aware that there is a thin line between ambiguity and bullshit in this kind of dance theatre.

In fact, it was the idea of fallen angels, a frequent image in Russian literature and art, that provided the inspiration for the show. It's set on an apparently deserted railway station. Out of the darkness appear headless clown-like figures who waddle about like tiny solemn children, balloons rising above their heads while a haunting soundtrack wafts across the auditorium like a memory of voices and music you once heard but had long forgotten.

Gradually it becomes apparent that these ghostly figures, with their battered suitcases and endlessly tramping feet, are a queue of refugees stretching back through history, always on the march, looking for a place to rest. In the railway tracks of Europe, they find a route to a destination that is too terrible to contemplate. In one of the most devastating passages lacing live action and video I've ever seen, a train roars out of the video screen on the back wall and appears to thunder over the stage and into the audience. You duck, and when you look again the carriages rumble over the actors' prone bodies, the light wrapping their limbs in the embrace of death.

Yet they refuse to lie down to die. Even when they dice with death, they do it with laughter, playing Russian roulette, giggling at the prospect of oblivion. They dance and stamp their feet in defiance at what history has in store for them, their witty, whirling feet full of a kind of desperate joy.

For all its echoes of the catastrophes of history and its portrayal of the fact that nothing ever really changes, Hopeless Games is ultimately optimistic, raising the ghosts of the faceless millions who have trudged into oblivion down the centuries. At the end the stage is suddenly ablaze with fireworks. The tiny, lonesome figures walk jauntily towards the fire, forever smiling, their clothes apparently ablaze. Out of the darkness and into the light. What are they walking towards? Heaven or hell? Who knows? Long after the show has ended, its sizzling white energy still sears the retina. Such purity is hard to find and even harder to forget.

Hopeless Games is at Komedia @ Southside till Thursday, then on August 21, 23-27. Box office: 0131-667 2212.

fields.headline: No: 1699
fields.standfirst: The beaver
fields.trailText: The beaver
fields.body:
Appearance:
Three feet long, short legs, webbed hind feet, flat scaly tail, prominent incisors, could weigh up to 70lbs.

Sounds nasty and foreign. Aren't beavers American?
This is the European beaver. It once roamed the waterways of Norway, France, Poland, Scandinavia and Siberia, chewing aspen trees and munching myrtle roots.

But not Britain?
Yes, beaver fossils litter Britain. Beverley in the East Riding of Yorkshire derives its name from Beoferlic or Beverlac, because of the beavers that lived there.

Why and when did they go?
Sometime before 1600. It's tough being a continent's biggest rodent, especially one with a nice pelt and an anal musk gland sought for perfumes. And there's not much nourishment in wood. You have to chew your way through a fifth of your own body weight a day just to keep the wolf from the door.

Wolves?
Oh yes, naturalists dream of reintroducing wolves too, but the beaver is the first mammal to be formally reintroduced to Britain. Scotland only. Secret location, naturally.

So, another dam burden on the state?
Spot on. The beaver chews through trunks and builds silt-covered lodges which act as little weirs to create useful niches for other creatures.

This lot supplied by Brussels?
Warsaw, actually. Eurobeavers clung on in a few places. Poland reintroduced them 20 years ago. Beavers now also keep watch on the upper Rhine.

Have they been quarantined?
You bet. The trio were kept near Canterbury, Kent, for six months before release into a "secure wetland area".

So, all is well then?
No. Landowners are making their usual fuss. Scottish Natural Heritage calls it a "reversible pilot project". If the herbivorous little horrors harm the salmon, they'll be smoked out and extinguished all over again.

Don't say:
"Beaver, isn't that slang for something rude?"

Do say:
"Which is your lodge, brother?"

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Tales From The Back Of Beyond | Belgium On Trial
fields.body:
Oliver Steeds first heard of Kubla Khan when his father read him Coleridge's poem. That eventually inspired him to lead an expedition on horseback to Xanadu but, as he confesses in Tales From The Back Of Beyond (11.0am, Radio 4), stately pleasure domes are now in short supply. Stark reality dawned with the team's first Mongolian feast - a bowl of livers, kidneys, hearts, stomachs and intestines enticingly steeped in blood and fat.

The alarm about paedophilia in Britain is mild compared with the stunned shock of the Belgians five years ago. That was when the police discovered the bodies of four girls who had been caged, sexually abused, and starved to death by an out- of-work electrician, Marc Dutroux. Yet, to the bewilderment of the children's families, the case against him has still to be heard. In Belgium On Trial (8.0pm, Radio 4) John Egan investigates the allegations of a massive cover-up by senior politicians.

fields.headline: Aiming off over Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
The success they claimed did not happen
Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: If this were not a deadly serious, indeed a seriously deadly issue, the Ministry of Defence's latest statements over Britain's bombing performance during the Kosovo war would be worthy of a Yes, Minister script. We now know from the leak of a confidential Whitehall report that, far from scoring a resounding success, the RAF's "dumb" bombs hit their targets only 2% of the time.
fields.body:
If this were not a deadly serious, indeed a seriously deadly issue, the Ministry of Defence's latest statements over Britain's bombing performance during the Kosovo war would be worthy of a Yes, Minister script. We now know from the leak of a confidential Whitehall report that, far from scoring a resounding success, the RAF's "dumb" bombs hit their targets only 2% of the time. The guided bombs were better but, overall, the RAF had a worse performance than in Bosnia or Iraq. Faced with this embarrassing disclosure, the MoD now says its earlier statement that the Kosovo campaign was the "most accurate ever conducted" was "relative". The boast was true "relative to the operational environment" - ie taking account of the facts that the weather over Kosovo was cloudy much of the time, the RAF had run out of "smart bombs", and pilots were told to fly so high that they could not easily see what they were trying to hit. In other words, the RAF won the race relative to the fact that all the other runners got to the finishing line before it.

The MoD's nonsense is not unique. The US secretary of defense, William Cohen, claimed last September that "of the thousands of bombs that were dropped and the missiles that were fired, nearly all of them hit the intended target". Presumably, it all depends what you mean by a "target". If it is a general target zone with a centre and an enormous circumference, perhaps you can justify that comment. General Wesley Clark, commander of Nato forces during the Yugoslav campaign, tried a different tack. He purred last October: "I just want to emphasise the incredible precision of the bombing: the fact that on 78 days with over 23,000 weapons dropped or fired, there were only 20 incidents of collateral damage." Decoded, that means Nato was extremely lucky. The bombs mostly failed to hit anything military. Fortunately, they also missed civilians - at least some of the time. The independent agency, Human Rights Watch, has calculated that Nato bombs killed about 200 people in Serbia and 300 (mostly Albanians) in Kosovo. The killing has not yet stopped, as unsuspecting people unexpectedly trigger hidden cluster bombs.

Perhaps because it took place in Europe, but certainly because it was Nato's first shooting war, public opinion throughout the alliance's member nations was engaged as never before. The propaganda battle was vital. But it is now clear that the authorities deceived the public about the effectiveness of the air strikes, not only while the conflict was under way, but even after it ended. The leaked report about inaccuracies was given to a closed conference of defence analysts in February, a day after the same officials who heard it had been sitting with journalists for a much more triumphant public presentation. This was classic Whitehall whitewash - one story for the public, the truth for the experts. When the magazine Flight International bravely prepared to reveal this, it was served with a D notice.

Nato prides itself on being an alliance of democracies, but the Kosovo war showed a disturbing lack of public accountability. The overwhelming message which emerges from this latest "lesson from Kosovo" is that an independent inquiry into Nato's targeting policy is needed. Parliamentary select committees have already looked at many aspects of the war, but yesterday's revelations hint at further crucial answers still waiting to be given.

webTitle: Leader: ICM poll reveals British to be pro-children

fields.headline: Not so bad after all
fields.standfirst:
The Kevins exist, but are hardly typical
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Perhaps it might have been different at the end of the summer holidays rather than the beginning, but in our latest ICM poll published today, the British seem much more pro-children than might have been expected. Asked to think about other people's children whom they know, almost two-thirds thought them well-behaved and polite
fields.body:
Perhaps it might have been different at the end of the summer holidays rather than the beginning, but in our latest ICM poll published today, the British seem much more pro-children than might have been expected. Asked to think about other people's children whom they know, almost two-thirds thought them well-behaved and polite. Kevin, Harry Enfield's dreadful teenager, is not unknown: roughly a third are described as surly, badly behaved or rude. But there is understanding too of the pressures to which modern children are subjected: 48% believe that children are being put under pressure to succeed.

There is also a widespread belief that parents are encouraging their children to grow up too quickly. Ironically, this is clearly untrue with respect to children under 10, who have far less independence than they once had: only 30% of 10-year-olds leaving for the school bus say goodbye to their parents on the doorstep, compared to 80% three decades ago. Given the current concern over paedophiles, there will be little surprise that a clear majority believe children are now more at risk of being sexually abused than they used to be (57% to 31%). But this view too is almost certainly wrong. The fact that the public is much more aware of sex abuse does not mean it is more prevalent. Indeed, it should make it less likely. Moreover, the protective procedures now in place have never been tighter; the help lines which children can use have never been more easily accessible; and the cooperation between agencies (police, social work, teachers) has never been better.

Political parties have sought to be rated the "most family friendly". Among the 43% who had a view, Labour was far ahead. Perhaps the Conservatives remain too wedded to "traditional values": two-thirds now believe unhappy parents should separate. Employers too are also seen as out of touch and less "family friendly" than they ought to be.

webTitle: Obituary: Thomas Foran - leading Chicago lawyer

fields.headline: Thomas Foran
fields.standfirst: Lawyer who prosecuted the Chicago 7 radicals in America's most notorious Vietnam-era show trial
fields.trailText: Three decades after playing a starring role in one of the 20th century's most notorious American trials, the leading Chicago lawyer, Thomas Foran, has died at the age of 76.
fields.body:
Three decades after playing a starring role in one of the 20th century's most notorious American trials, the leading Chicago lawyer, Thomas Foran, has died at the age of 76.

Foran was the abrasive federal prosecutor in the 1969-70 case brought against the radical protesters, known as the Chicago 7, for allegedly conspiring to cross state lines to incite the riot that wrecked the 1968 Democratic party convention in Chicago. In fact, eight people were originally charged, but the Black Panther leader Bobby Seale clashed so vehemently with the bench that Judge Julius Hoffman had him bound and gagged in the dock, and later jailed him for four years for contempt - thus removing him from the case.

This, however, was only the most dramatic episode in a four-month trial in which the defendants ostentatiously read newspapers in court, pulled faces at Hoffman, passed sweets and marijuana to one another, and barracked the judge and prosecution lawyers with obscene comments.

The charges had been filed under provisions in President Lyndon Johnson's 1968 Civil Rights Act designed to curb the spreading protests against the Vietnam war. Since many observers assessed the mayhem in the streets surrounding the convention hall as a police riot, the US attorney general, Ramsey Clark, was extremely reluctant to act against any demonstrators.

That infuriated Chicago's mayor, Richard Daley, who wanted someone's head on a charger for the slur on his city's reputation. With the encouragement of the newly installed Nixon administration, he persuaded a crony on the federal bench to convene a grand jury to rule whether the law had been breached. In March 1969, the jury issued indictments against eight demonstrators and eight police officers. Foran, who owed Mayor Daley his previous year's appointment as US attorney for northern Illinois (a regional office of the federal government), presented the initial case to the grand jury and, 13 months after the riots, took charge of the prosecution.

In later years, he described his daily conflicts with the defence team and its clients as "root canal work all day long." The battle opened with jury selection. The defence wanted to probe the 300 candidates' attitudes through a list of 54 questions, including "Do you know who Janis Joplin and Jimi Hendrix are?" Judge Hoffman only allowed one; whether or not prospective jurors had relatives or friends connected with law enforcement.

Day after day, Foran, relying in part on the evidence of government agents who had penetrated the protesters' organisations, relentlessly questioned them about their inflammatory speeches in the months before the convention. His case was greatly helped when Judge Hoffman refused to allow the defence to cite other speeches which emphasised the defendants' intention to demonstrate peaceably.

The case proceeded amid growing chaos in the courtroom, with the defendants verbally attacking the judge and covering the floor with rubbish. They denied ever meeting as a group and one of their witnesses, Norman Mailer, said that the left was incapable of conspiracy "because they're all egomaniacs".

No sooner had the jury retired than Hoffman gave all the defendants, and their lawyers, long prison terms on 159 counts of criminal contempt.

The jury eventually acquitted all defendants of conspiracy, but convicted five of crossing state lines to incite a riot. Each was given five years' imprisonment and a $5,000 fine. All the sentences were quashed on appeal, and Hoffman's conduct was condemned, particularly his refusal to allow full questioning of potential jurors. All the policemen were acquitted.

The lesson that Foran, a lifelong Democrat, drew from the experience was entirely political. "The worst thing about the convention," he mused much later, "was that it gave us Richard Nixon. And because of that, the Vietnam war continued for another four or five years".

The case certainly did not blight Foran's career. He had taken to the law after serving as a torpedo bomber pilot in the second world war. Having qualified in 1950, he opened his own partnership in Chicago in 1957. During Mayor Daley's frenzied redevelopment of the city centre, Foran frequently acted for the municipality in major projects, including its vast water reclamation scheme, one of the most expensive construction projects in the world - with commensurate legal fees.

In his role as a US attorney, Foran spent the years after the Chicago 7 case mounting a highly successful campaign against the mid-west's many prominent Mafia figures. Among the 150 he managed to haul before the courts over a two-year period were such local bigwigs as Felix Alderisio, Jackie Cerone, Fifi Buccieri, Richard Cain and William Daddano.

Foran is survived by his wife, Jean, and their six children.

 Thomas Aquinas Foran, lawyer, born January 11 1924; died August 6 2000
