fields.headline: Carol Johnson
fields.standfirst: Keeping postwar Labour on the right track
fields.trailText: Carol Johnson, who has died aged 97, was a long-serving general secretary of the Parliamentary Labour party, from 1943-59, who then inherited the safe Lewisham South seat from his political master, Herbert Morrison, and was its MP from 1959 until 1974.
fields.body:
Carol Johnson, who has died aged 97, was a long-serving general secretary of the Parliamentary Labour party, from 1943-59, who then inherited the safe Lewisham South seat from his political master, Herbert Morrison, and was its MP from 1959 until 1974.

During Labour's years in power - as part of the wartime coalition government, and after its 1945 election victory - he was the instrument of rightwing party disciplinarians like chief whip William Whitely and Morrison himself, then lord president of the council. Their main aim, in which Johnson was the intermediary, was to curb the left, particularly the supporters of Aneurin Bevan, such as Richard Crossman.

Plump, with a bald head and fixed half-smile, Johnson resembled a china egg on which an upturned half-moon had been stencilled. His high-pitched, whining voice prevented his becoming an effective political speaker. He had earlier served as leader of Lambeth borough council and, during the early years of the war, as assistant town clerk of Southall.

He was rewarded for his loyalty in 1959, when Morrison, having been worsted by Hugh Gaitskell for Labour's leadership, became a life peer, and managed to get his old constituency to pick Johnson as his successor. On being elected, Johnson contrasted "pragmatists" - such as himself - with leftwing "fundamentalists", who defied the electorate.

Given his disciplinarian past, it was curious that, as an MP, he then became something of a rebel. In 1965, he wrote a report urging links between the six countries of the EEC and the Western European Union. He became secretary to the British Council of the European Movement and vice president of the Labour Committee for Europe. In 1974, he chastised the Economist for its "partisan" reporting of the Arab-Israeli war, and attacked Israeli intransigence in a letter to the Guardian.

Such views, his age (then 70), plus his low profile in the Commons, where he preferred to serve as chairman of committees, did not make his survival likely when local constituency boundaries were redrawn before the February 1974 general election; nor did his running war with his neighbour, James Dickens, the leftwing MP for Lewisham West. So he withdrew from the contest and retired to East Sussex.

Even so, Johnson's career had been a high climb for someone from a modest London family, who attended only local council schools. He became a solicitor in 1933, often serving as poor man's lawyer and adviser to housing associations. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Edna.

 Carol Alfred Johnson, politician, born 1903; died July 30 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Jaap Marais - apartheid party leader

fields.headline: Jaap Marais
fields.standfirst: Diehard Afrikaner who clung to pure apartheid as white South Africa compromised
fields.trailText: Diehard Afrikaner who clung to pure apartheid as white South Africa compromised
fields.body:
Jaap Marais, who has died aged 77, was an anglophobe diehard who led the Herstigte National party (HNP) in South Africa, which continued to fight for "pure" apartheid even after mainstream Afrikaner nationalism had begun to compromise.

The HNP (its title herstigte means reconstituted) attracted a powerful minority in the paranoid world of Afrikaner politics after the assassination in 1966 of Hendrik Verwoerd, the ideologist of apartheid. But the first-past-the-post system in the all-white elections of the old regime (aided by dirty tricks) saw to it that the HNP never won a poll.

The splinter party was formed in 1969 after its three original leaders, all South African MPs, were expelled from the mainstream National party (NP). They were Albert Hertzog, a political lightweight and son of General JDM Hertzog, the creator of the NP and a prewar prime minister, Louis Stofberg and Marais, who was always the group's principal driving force and propagandist.

It is hard to imagine a political grouping to the right of the NP, certainly as it was under John Vorster, the hardline former justice minister chosen to succeed Verwoerd. But even Vorster found it necessary to try for an accommodation with South Africa's independent black neighbours as apartheid became an increasing economic and diplomatic liability. In 1970, for example, he held secret talks with President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia; later, he persuaded President Hastings Banda, of Malawi, to open diplomatic relations in exchange for financial aid.

These small steps were too much for diehards like Marais and his colleagues. They accused Vorster of being a closet liberal, a grotesque allegation which nevertheless unleashed charges and counter-charges of treason amid a new epidemic of broedertwis (brotherly hate), a staple of Afrikaner politics. Aware that the NP had come to power in 1948 by overtaking the United Party (UP) on the right, an alarmed NP launched a vicious campaign of vilification against the three rebels, who were subsequently ousted in the all-white election of 1970.

Marais showed considerable courage in his initial role as deputy leader and principal ideological driving force of the fledgling HNP. He resembled the Nazi leader Joseph Goebbels not only in his rhetoric, and his surprising intellectual and cultural strengths (and personal charm when he chose), but also in his physical disability; both his feet were painfully deformed.

When I interviewed Marais for my then employers, the Times, I was treated with elaborate courtesy by my subject, but as a blatant subversive by the NP and the Afrikaans press, which took up the vilification of the HNP with gusto. One paper observed that the Times was "a traditional enemy of the Afrikaner volk", and Marais was pilloried in unsubtle cartoons for dealing with "the English."

This, too, was a wild distortion for Marais, who succeeded Hertzog as party leader in 1977, as the HNP struggled on in the twilight of apartheid. To the end, he never forgave the British for the Boer war, during which both his politically-active parents were interned.

Born in Vryburg, in the northern Cape province, Jaap Marais was one of eight children raised on the family farm. After a basic rural education, he joined the NP youth movement and studied in his spare time for a degree at Pretoria University. He won a seat in the Cape Town parliament at a byelection in the Transvaal in 1958. He remained a backbencher, but worked hard in committees and, now and again, delivered a great diatribe against the liberalism and communism he believed was sweeping the country.

Away from the bear-pit of Afrikaner politics, he took pride in his command of the language and verse of the hated English, and even translated some Shakespeare into Afrikaans, a coarse tongue surprisingly amenable to poetry. His other gentle interests included the fine wines of South Africa and breeding prizewinning budgerigars.

He clung to his racist beliefs to the last, even after the ultra-rightist standard had been snatched away by Andries Treurnicht in the 1980s, Nelson Mandela had been released in 1990 and the African National Congress had won power in South Africa's first election under universal suffrage in 1994.

He is survived by his wife, Maria, a son and a daughter.

 Jacob Albertus 'Jaap' Marais, politician, born November 2 1922; died August 8 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Joan Trimble - pianist and composer

fields.headline: Joan Trimble
fields.standfirst: Pianist and composer echoing her Irish roots
fields.trailText: Joan Trimble, who has died aged 85, was the doyenne of Irish composers and, with her late sister Valerie, the senior of the two-piano team who were household names in the 1940s and 1950s.
fields.body:
Joan Trimble, who has died aged 85, was the doyenne of Irish composers and, with her late sister Valerie, the senior of the two-piano team who were household names in the 1940s and 1950s.

Born into an intensely musical family in Dublin, her father was a fine bass-baritone and a distinguished collector of folksong, who also owned the Impartial Reporter newspaper in Enniskillen. Her mother, Marie Dowse, came from a famous Dublin family of musicians, and was a fine violinist and teacher.

In 1930, Joan entered the Royal Irish Academy of Music and later Dublin University, where she took degrees in arts and music. In 1936, John McCormack chose her to play piano solos during one of his tours, as a result of which she went to the Royal College of Music, where her mentor was the Australian composer and pianist Arthur Benjamin. He encouraged Joan and Valerie, whose principal instrument was the cello, to play piano together and wrote the immensely popular Jamaican Rumba for them.

Joan also studied composition with Howells and Vaughan Williams. At the latter's suggestion, she wrote her Phantasy For Piano Trio, with which she won the 1940 Cobbett competition. Among her many compositions from that period were her Sonatina For Two Pianos, a Suite For Strings and many settings of Irish folksong.

During the second world war, in which Joan worked fulltime for the Red Cross, the sisters were regular performers on the BBC and at Myra Hess's famous National Gallery lunch-time concerts. Their first of many Prom appearances was in 1943. Their repertoire was very wide, including Arnold Cooke, Dallapiccola and Stravinsky. They premièred the two-piano concertos of Arthur Bliss and Lennox Berkeley.

From 1959, Joan was professor of accompaniment and general musicianship at the Royal College of Music, from which she retired in 1977 to edit the family newspaper in Enniskillen. She represented the fourth generation in direct succession, and remained its proprietor until her death; her daughter followed her as editor.

Joan was honoured by the RCM in 1960, by Queen's University, Belfast, in 1983 and received the rarely bestowed fellowship of the Royal Irish Academy of Music in 1985. From 1981 to 1985, she was on the board of Ulster Television, and from 1983 to 1988 a member of the advisory committee of the Arts Council of Northern Ireland (ACNI).

With her very busy lives, not to mention marriage to Dr John Greenwood Gant and bringing up their three children, she accurately described herself as an "occasional" composer, writing for the occasion of a BBC commission her television opera, Blind Raftery (1957). She wrote almost nothing after that until the ACNI commissioned the delicious wind quintet for her 75th birthday in 1990, and a choral work commissioned for the National Chamber Choir of Ireland for her 80th birthday in 1995.

Her output may have been small, but it was always extremely well crafted. Except in specific arrangements, she never used a known Irish tune, and always wrote extremely personally, saying "I am free to be myself, regardless of fashion." Nonetheless, there was invariably an innate Irish quality to her writing. She was interested in a deep and scholarly way in Irish traditional music, and knowledgeable about it. She has left her mark in every field she entered, especially that of her elegant compositions.

She leaves her husband, son Nicholas, daughters Joanna and Caroline, three granddaughters, two grandsons and a great-grandaughter.

 Joan Trimble, pianist, composer and newspaper proprietor, born June 18 1915; died August 6 2000

fields.headline: Saving the water vole
fields.trailText: Christopher Hart is right to highlight the threat facing the rural working classes (All farmed out, August 12). However, pitting town against country and villainising "townies" will not serve us in the quest for a solution to a problem which will ultimately affect us all. Now is the time to look for some common ground.
fields.body:
Christopher Hart is right to highlight the threat facing the rural working classes (All farmed out, August 12). However, pitting town against country and villainising "townies" will not serve us in the quest for a solution to a problem which will ultimately affect us all. Now is the time to look for some common ground.

Many of the forces threatening the future of the countryside's people, landscape and wildlife are neither town nor rural, but commercial. The countryside as it appears today is the result of hundreds of years of management - some of it good and some of it bad. Can we all agree that 1,000-acre agribusinesses growing GM crops for supermarkets with the power to destroy local livelihoods is the worst kind of management and most definitely what we all do not want?

If we can win enough mutual understanding and respect, maybe we can go on to sort out the other issues before it's too late. The vested interests of different lobby groups, when combined with the media, can be divisive and while we stand apart and cat-call, the real villains are doing their worst for us all.

Simon Forrester
Bredwardine, Herefordshire

If Christopher Hart wishes to preserve the rural working class and undermine the relentless progress of agribusiness, he should stop railing at migrating townies and direct his energies towards Westminster and Brussels. If he campaigned in favour of removing the subsidies on agricultural diesel, he would be doing much in helping to keep the countryside populated by working people and their families. The rural working class has been largely dispossessed by mechanisation and this process has been accelerated by the supply of cheap fuel for farm equipment.

While he's about it, he could also campaign for the taxation of herbicide, pesticide and fertiliser inputs - that should help the water voles, bluebell woods and downland butterflies.

Of course he could continue to rail at the townies occupying the empty housing vacated by workers who have moved in the hope of finding jobs in the towns.

Steven Twigg
Cholmondeston, Cheshire
stevetwigg@netcentral.co.uk

 Christopher Hart's pessimistic view of the future need not be realised. Two not very radical changes could make a huge difference. First, introduce high council tax rates on second homes. Not only would this free up more existing properties for local people and avoid the need for a massive house building programme, it would also generate additional revenue for rural areas and help redress the negative impact of second homes on rural economies.

Second, give a greater proportion of subsidies to organic and small livestock producers. This would increase rural employment, reduce our heavy reliance on imported produce and maintain a diverse countryside.

Robin Taylor
Chagford, Devon

 A decision has been made, apparently, that advertising hoardings should be allowed throughout the countryside, as a means of encouraging farmers to diversify - an amazing proposal to destroy, at a stroke, the aspect of the countryside, protected for more than 50 years.

Increasing incomes for farmers with land alongside heavily used roads seems at best a lottery and, in any case, least likely to help hill and sheep farmers in remote areas. If there is a case for help for worst-hit farmers, let it be transparent and focused: a means which will enhance the countryside, such as the support for wildlife verges, hedges and woodlands, rather than one which would destroy all view of it.

Francis Tasker
Newcastle upon Tyne

fields.headline: The FA isn't playing ball
fields.trailText: "They cannot be responsible for what happened a long time ago when there was much more ignorance." This could have been another attempt to excuse past dumping of nuclear waste, or the government's failure to act on BSE. It could equally have been the comment of a future apologist for GM crop trials. But this time it was the FA, without even a hint of deja vu, concluding that football clubs cannot be held responsible to ex-players who are now disabled as a consequence of being injected with cortisone to keep them on the field. (Football's forgotten victims, August 12).
fields.body:
"They cannot be responsible for what happened a long time ago when there was much more ignorance." This could have been another attempt to excuse past dumping of nuclear waste, or the government's failure to act on BSE. It could equally have been the comment of a future apologist for GM crop trials. But this time it was the FA, without even a hint of deja vu, concluding that football clubs cannot be held responsible to ex-players who are now disabled as a consequence of being injected with cortisone to keep them on the field. (Football's forgotten victims, August 12).

What levels of compensation do we have to reach, and what levels of personal responsibility have to be placed on managers, before organisations such as the FA recognise the dangerous mix of science, profit, ego and uncertainty, and become less dismissive of the fundamental principle of caution?

Dr Simon Pardoe
Lancaster University
s.pardoe@lancaster.ac.uk

Like all Guardian-reading football fans, I looked forward to my copy of The Season yesterday. However, your assumption that the season starts with the Premiership fixtures is insulting to fans who, like me, follow non-Premiership teams. For us the season started on August 12 - and we are as numerous as those who can't see beyond the 20 overpaid, over-rated and overexposed "top" teams.

Jerry Page
Newport Pagnell, Bucks

webTitle: Why we've got our eye on Big Brother

fields.headline: Why we've got our eye on Big Brother
fields.trailText: Liz Moloney (Letters, August 12) dislikes Big Brother because she is over 50, has lived abroad a lot, has interesting and original friends and a lot of interests. I fit all these categories but find Big Brother compulsive, as do my husband and my best friend. Mind you, they have not lived abroad a lot (presumably holidays don't count?) Are there more of us out there? Perhaps we could form a support group.
fields.body:
Liz Moloney (Letters, August 12) dislikes Big Brother because she is over 50, has lived abroad a lot, has interesting and original friends and a lot of interests. I fit all these categories but find Big Brother compulsive, as do my husband and my best friend. Mind you, they have not lived abroad a lot (presumably holidays don't count?) Are there more of us out there? Perhaps we could form a support group.

Vicky Rantzen
Truro, Cornwall

 I'm certainly watching Big Brother. I happily admit it. Friends on the phone, quite a lot of them Guardian readers, swap thoughts as to whether Nasty Nick is just a plant. In the supermarket on Saturday morning more than a few had tears in their eyes for Caggy. It's certainly brightening up my summer viewing. I speak as a Guardian reader for nearly 40 years, soon to be 60 and living in Wiltshire; I'm hardly the typical "under-40s Londoner".

Carole Mitchell
Melksham, Wilts
chris@carole3.freeserve.co.uk

 I note Big Brother's spooky City trader, Nick, shares his surname with American Psycho's unhinged Wall Street broker, Pat Bateman. John Styles
Brighton
john@roedale.mistral.co.uk

 After the tedium of Big Brother, we read Channel 5 is to launch a show awarding someone who can escape from televised incarceration £250,000. We also hear a German TV company is planning a similar voyeuristic exercise offering money to the person who can lose the most weight. Is this the future of TV? We find it a complete turn-off.

J Eunson
Newcastle upon Tyne

fields.headline: Flood of criticism
fields.trailText: There's a steam boat skipper on Windermere who will once again be able to sail to the foot of the lake without the danger of being overturned (Boat power, August 14). Our children in their rubber dinghy are "bombed" for fun by jet skiers and speed boats whose dangerous and anti-social behaviour would be considered intolerable on a road. The ban can't come into force soon enough.
fields.body:

Our children in their rubber dinghy are "bombed" for fun by jet skiers and speed boats whose dangerous and anti-social behaviour would be considered intolerable on a road. The ban can't come into force soon enough.

Eileen Burnip
Hebden Bridge, W Yorks

Heartening to learn that Matt Barrett, who was greeted with a pay package beyond the dreams of avarice, thinks that being motivated by money is a sign of being doomed to failure (Mr Big at the even bigger bank, August 12). Barclays could have saved a lot of money if they had known their chief executive's opinion in advance.

Carol Kohll
London

Can it be true our government is sending £250,000 towards helping the 5m people made homeless by the floods in India (Leader, August 12)? My small terraced house is now worth £250,000. There is something obscenely unbalanced in our world.

Barbara Tayler
London

 £650,000 for the redecoration of the Lord Chancellor's private apartment; £250,000 for the Indian flood victims. I rest my case.

S Hipperson
Lindfield, W Sussex

Of course everyone wanted to know who the headless man was (Letters, August 12). But what I want to know is who was the photographer?

Caroline Collett
Bristol

A more likely explanation for LS Lowry's permanently grey skies (Head in the clouds artist was inspired by science, August 10) is that he was painting Manchester.

Sadie Clifford
Stockport, Gtr Manchester

fields.headline: Woolly thinking
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead may or may not be right in his attack on some degree courses (Woodhead attacks "vacuous" degrees, August 14), but he displays his ignorance - indeed the vacuity of his thinking - in including knitwear. Modern computer-controlled knitting machinery can produce at high speed complete, shaped garments, which need little or no sewing. Other knitted products go into composites for engineering applications. This is advanced modern technology. The emphasis in degree courses in textiles may be on technology, design or management, but these are all demanding subjects.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead may or may not be right in his attack on some degree courses (Woodhead attacks "vacuous" degrees, August 14), but he displays his ignorance - indeed the vacuity of his thinking - in including knitwear. Modern computer-controlled knitting machinery can produce at high speed complete, shaped garments, which need little or no sewing. Other knitted products go into composites for engineering applications. This is advanced modern technology. The emphasis in degree courses in textiles may be on technology, design or management, but these are all demanding subjects.

Textile graduates have a good employment record. It is fashionable to see textiles as a dying industry, but it will be easier for this sector to grow again than to re-establish more monolithic industries such as cars or steel. Fabric manufacturing, as distinct from the cut-and-sew of much garment making, is capital-intensive, so higher labour costs are not a bar to competition. Knitwear is a good guide to the future. In Greater Manchester alone, there are 135 small and medium-sized knitting companies with an annual turnover of £73m.

Prof John Hearle
Stockport
hearle@tensiontech.com

 Given the tabloid-inspired violence of the past few days, Chris Woodhead's populist attack on media studies could not be more ill-considered. We live in an age when most news leaves people half-informed about a random range of subjects, when big business and politicians have made media manipulation into a science, and when much children's television is a form of advertising - to raise just a few areas of concern. Rather than being a "vacuous" waste of time, media studies is an urgently needed field of inquiry.

Richard Bartholomew
London

 John Sutherland (A contest that no one can really win, G2, August 14) makes several valid points regarding the academic league tables and the wasteful bureaucracy that spawns them. He misses, however, the more important feature, which is known to every UK academic. The real social scandal of the research assessment exercise is that it has encouraged, over the past 10 years, the carrying out of almost entirely useless "research", buried in a proliferating number of unread, second-rate journals, at the expense of all that is alive and vibrant in higher education. It is not that the horse is being whipped in order to work while starved of food - it is being whipped to perform inferior circus tricks.

Dr Yiannis Gabriel
University of Bath

fields.headline: Verbal duel
fields.trailText: Perhaps a dictionary editor shouldn't say it, but I'm gobsmacked! How can the compilers of a new dictionary miss out such an important new term as Blairism (No room for Blairism in new OED, August 11)? Have they been asleep for the past three years? Love him or hate him, no one can deny that Tony Blair has changed the face of British politics. The New Penguin English Dictionary, published at the end of August, includes the term, of course. It looks to me as though Oxford simply missed it. And what about other key new words of the "noughties" - cyberchondriac, pronoid, life coach and snakehead, to name just a few?

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Recipients of some early editions yesterday were left reading the racing page of June 5 (page 10, Sport). This was due to a computer-system error at the printers, for which many apologies.
fields.body:
Recipients of some early editions yesterday were left reading the racing page of June 5 (page 10, Sport). This was due to a computer-system error at the printers, for which many apologies.

A leading article yesterday, page 17, said it was time to vary who ran the national lottery, and Sir Richard Branson's company, the People's Lottery, deserved a chance. For the record, the outgoing managing director of Guardian Newspapers, Caroline Marland, is, in her personal capacity, a non-executive director of the People's Lottery.

Also touching on this subject, Tom Bower, page 9, G2, August 10, said the National Lottery Commission's choice of the next operator "requires the approval of Chris Smith and probably Tony Blair". The Department for Culture, Media and Sport points out that the commissioners' decision requires no political approval under the 1998 law governing the lottery.

A hundred children aged five to 14 were murdered in England and Wales last year, not five as in yesterday's G2 cover story. Five was the number killed by strangers.

A column yesterday, page 15, said that the campaign in Scotland against section 28 (which inhibits discussion of homosexuality in schools by banning its promotion) was financed by millionaire Brian Souter. He campaigned against repeal of section 28.

The Saturday Review cover story on August 5 should have given the date of Lisbon's most damaging earthquake as 1755 (not 1775).

An article on BBC TV's new season, page 5, August 9, erred in saying Fred Barron created Seinfeld and the Larry Sanders show. He was executive producer and a writer on these programmes.

Weblife, page 21, the Editor, August 11, said of the TV programme Big Brother: "One million of us - a large number via the [web]site - voted who should be the next contestant to pack their bags." Channel 4 has never activated online voting. The site has only a static Who's your favourite? section, which we mistook for a polling booth.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: You're not alone
fields.standfirst: As ministers get ready to launch yet more exams,  Rebecca Smithers examines the stresses on students
fields.trailText: As ministers get ready to launch yet more exams, Rebecca Smithers examines the stresses on students
fields.body:
Timing is everything in the world of education. On the eve of the annual examination results season, a major survey backed by two of the teaching unions warned that our youngsters are being "tested to destruction", typically facing more than 75 external tests and exams during their time at school.

On cue, in the last few days the Samaritans have launched their first website awareness campaign for young people who don't know how to cope after receiving disappointing exam results.

But undeterred, ministers will bid farewell this week to the existing system of post-16 education and hail the introduction of an arguably more complex raft of exams this autumn as key to its standards-raising agenda.

The scale of the public examination system in England and Wales is already enormous, deploying some of the nation's best educational talent in a short period of time to produce increasing numbers of results across a broad range of qualifications.

Over the next two weeks, for example, more than 750,000 A-level results and more than 5.5m GCSE results will be issued. And at the same time, more than 100,000 results will be issued for foundation, intermediate and advanced GNVQ.

That makes for a daunting "paperchase" - across the board, around 20m separate scripts and items of coursework are submitted by students and marked by an army of around 40,000 examiners and moderators.

Students have a choice of more than 60 subjects across the different types and levels of qualification, involving different choices of syllabus and content. At the more popular end of the scale, GCSE English and maths attract more than 600,000 entries each, yet minority interest subjects such as some non-European languages with as few as 50 entries each are also catered for.

This year, significantly, a major step towards openness and transparency in the public exam system will take place this autumn when - following a limited pilot scheme last year - all students will have the right to ask to see their marked scripts returned. Scripts in all subjects at A-level and in English, Irish, mathematics and Welsh at GCSE will be available.

The government will be hoping that the familiar cry that A-levels are getting easier will be a thing of the past once the new system is bedded in. But it will be another two years before the first students to have had the benefits of the new range of reformed advanced-level qualifications - known as the Qualifying for Success reforms - will emerge from schools and colleges, and their results will inevitably be subjected to detailed scrutiny and analysis.

In the meantime, higher education minister Baroness Blackstone will point to the new system as a much improved version of what we have already, increasing the breadth of study by making it easier to combine vocational and academic qualifications, while stretching the most able pupils to their limit.

The reforms mean that students will take at least one more subject in the first year of the sixth form, which means theoretically that students will be carrying out greater breadth of study. In particular, she will point to new world-class tests as an integral part of the reforms. They are likely to stretch the most able sixth-formers by requiring greater depth of understanding than existing A-levels.

There has been much confusion about the different "labels" being used for this new breed of optional tests. The brand new Advanced Extension Award, for example, will replace the old-fashioned S-level, designed to stretch the most able sixth-formers by requiring greater depth of understanding than A-level. It is in effect the third and final tier of the new world-class tests introduced for nine- and 13-year-olds next year. These are designed to measure the most able students against internationally recognised standards.

The new tests are being introduced following the low take-up among sixth-formers of S-levels, and some top universities have suggested that they could eventually even replace traditional university entrance exams.

Unlike the tests for the younger age groups, which will be in problem-solving and mathematics and taken on a computer, the tests for 18-year-olds will be based on the same curriculum content as the corresponding A-level and will be available in maths, chemistry, physics, English, history, French, biology, geography, economics, religious studies, German, Spanish and Latin.

 New Samaritans national helpline: 08457 90 90 90

fields.headline: Dream time
fields.standfirst: Entrusted with five-figure budgets, teams of young people are allotting money to projects devised by youngsters in areas of profound need. Jerome Monahan on the expanding Youthbank scheme
fields.trailText: Entrusted with five-figure budgets, teams of young people are allotting money to projects devised by youngsters in areas of profound need. Jerome Monahan on the expanding Youthbank scheme
fields.body:
It seems that young people have never had it so good. According to the Y2K Wall's survey, the average weekly pocket money has leapt a "staggering" 29% since last year, to £3.10.

Particularly flush are 15- and 16-year-olds, who have £5.66 a week to lavish on their lifestyles. And - surprise, surprise - top of their shopping lists and soaking up 57p in the pound are ice cream, crisps and chocolate.

But there are other teenagers in the UK with deeper pockets and wider horizons. Across the country, sets of young people have spent the past 18 months becoming philanthropists. Entrusted with five-figure bugets, and in one case a six-figure one, their remit has been to find and fund projects likely to benefit their age group in areas of profound social need.

The scheme is called Youthbank - Cash For Action and following the success of seven pilot programmes, it is due to go national in the next year.

"Youthbank encourages young people between the ages of 15 and 25 to become active citizens," says its creator, Michael Norton - the founder and first director of the Directory of Social Change. "It gives them the opportunity to put money where they believe it will make a difference and be responsible for the decisions they make."

At present, Youthbank is run as a partnership by a number of organisations with a strong commitment to young people's community involvement. These include the National Youth Agency, the Community Foundation Network, the British Youth Council and the charity Changemakers. In addition to distributing an initial £185,000 in trust-fund grants to set up the seven pilot schemes, they have also played an active role in supporting them locally.

According to Michael Norton, while certain principles are key to every youthbank, there is plenty of scope for groups to mould the scheme to suit local needs. "This is not a rigid franchise like McDonalds," he explains. So while the Bristol Youthbank invited applications from across the city, the Shadwell committee in east London chose to focus on their immediate community, and accepted bids from groups sometimes comprising only two people.

"The most important thing," says Lucky Begum of the Shadwell Youthbank, "is that every idea is aimed at benefiting other local young people."

In Northern Ireland the group has spread its net across the entire six counties while moving its monthly meetings from area to area so as to safeguard it from accusations of sectarian partiality.

"This means all involved have to make a considerable commitment," says Vernon Ringland of the Northern Ireland Voluntary Trust, who provides adult support for the group. "It can take two hours travelling either side of the gatherings, and even cutting their assessments to 20 minutes per funding application means they are at it for five hours sometimes."

The Troubles have also meant that Northern Ireland Youthbank members have faced some very challenging situations. "When we go out to assess a scheme, we divide into pairs - Protestant and Catholic together," explains Tricia McNally. "It can be scary as a Catholic going into a Protestant area - you have to take care not to use the slang that can give you away. Even a simple question here such as 'Where are you from?' has to be handled carefully. Although we are never in any danger, people can be aggressive."

Tricia is full of praise for the training the Youthbank team received as part of its induction before the business of grant-making began. "For me the equal opportunities work we did was very valuable. The facilitator did everything he could to challenge our prejudices."

Education is at the centre of all the Youthbank pilots. Each group receives a whole raft of specialist advice, ranging from budget management and accounting, assessing applications, communications and marketing.

Ashan Ali is a member of the Bradford group, which has already distributed £120,000 to more than 3,000 local youth schemes - its coffers swelled by European Social Fund money and other local grants. "I knew nothing about funding at the start," he says. "All the training has helped me, and now I act as a mentor to others."

His view is shared by 15-year-old Gina Mitchell in Bristol: "I have learnt how to look at an application and spot whether or not it really has been filled in by a young person - that is one of our rules."

John Cabbot, at the end of his year 10 GCSE studies, is full of praise for the Bristol scheme: "It is excellent to be involved in real decision making - giving out money to others is one of the greatest things in the world, but it is also very hard to say no."

The Bristol Youthbank was highly critical of the kind of application forms most youth groups have to tackle if applying for money. They spotted that demanding lots of bank details was just intimidating and also irrelevant.

"They would only need that kind of stuff if they were successful," says John Cabbot. His group has distributed £12,000, whittling down 43 applications to just 17 for a payout. "But just because a group has been unsuccessful does not mean they cannot try for funds again," says Cabbot. "We will contact groups that missed out and explain how they can improve their application next time - we are due to start another funding cycle soon."

It is the long-term benefits of Youthbank that prove its greatest attraction to members of the consortium running it. "Not only is the scheme possibly creating the trustees of the future, but it is channelling resources to just the kinds of disaffected young people that adult funding agencies and governments find so hard to reach," says Community Foundation Network director Gaynor Humphreys.

Her view is borne out by the experience of the Shadwell group, who helped two boys buy sound equipment to help train other aspiring musicians in the area and are now seeking more training themselves as their local youth work expands. Elsewhere, Youthbank money has provided for outdoor adventure activities for homeless teenagers in Bradford, cookers for youth centres in Bristol and non-sectarian murals in Newry, Northern Ireland.

One criticism all Youthbanks are sensitive to is the degree that those they fund remain accountable. In Bristol the group is about to embark on a summer-long series of visits to its successful applicants.

In Bradford it is Ashan Ali's experience that people are eager to come in to show off the receipts: "They are pleased they have been trusted," he explains. In Shadwell the proper use of funds is guaranteed by a simple message on the application form: "Don't forget, we live in the area - we know where you are!"

 The next stage of Youthbank will involve developing the scheme as part of the citizenship programme in schools. For further information contact David Phillips at the National Youth Agency on 0116-285 3732. More details about the youthbanks mentioned in this article can be obtained from: Bradford: 01274-752432; Bristol: 0117-989 7700; Northern Ireland: 02890-245927; St Katherine and Shadwell: 020 7782 6962.

fields.headline: Wanted: new scientist
fields.standfirst: It's a sticky job, but someone's got to do it. As Sir Robert May's term expires as chief scientific adviser to the government, Lee Elliot Major asks who will take on his mantle
fields.trailText: It's a sticky job, but someone's got to do it. As Sir Robert May's term expires as chief scientific adviser to the government, Lee Elliot Major asks who will take on his mantle
fields.body:
Applications are sought from scientists wanting to spend five years as a close adviser to the prime minister.

Job requirements include having to appear on the Today programme at a moment's notice to stand up for the government or the scientific community and calm the nation down over any topic - from gaping ozone holes to genetically modified foods - when all other senior academics and officials appear to be suddenly unavailable for comment.

The candidate must also be prepared to be grilled by the Treasury spending committee during Whitehall spending reviews - the equivalent of being interviewed by several John Humprhys at once. Salary: at least £115,000 a year.

Not quite the job advert that was rushed out by senior mandarins at the Department of Trade and Industry a couple of months ago, when one official realised that Sir Robert May's term as the government's chief scientific adviser was fast coming to an end - but perhaps a more realistic synopsis of what will be expected of the new chief scientific adviser working in the modern era of the government's increasingly involved and intense relationship with the scientific world.

Interviews have been completed, and an announcement is expected any day now of the scientific expert who faces the daunting task of following in the footsteps of Sir Bob. During the last five years, May has successfully managed one of the most pressurised posts in the country - perhaps only less pressurised than the England football coach or the prime ministership itself.

May will now serve until the end of September, even though his contract officially terminates this month. It is now unthinkable for the government to be without its adviser ready to dissipate the next scientific crisis and placate the public and press.

Among the usual suspects being bandied around as potential successors are Sir Tom Blundell, former chief of the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council, Dr Paul Nurse, director of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, Professor George Radda, head of the Medical Research Council, Sir Martin Rees, Astronomer Royal, and even Susan Greenfield, the Oxford University neurobiologist, friend of the Blairs and science populariser.

A government official with a mischievous sense of humour told one particularly naive journalist that Carol Vorderman was in line for the position. But we can confirm that there is nothing in this scurrilous rumour: Carol is not about to hang up her Countdown boots just yet.

So what will the major challenge be for his successor? May quips, "Following me." It is a typical Mayism: arrogant in the extreme, but not without a hint of truth to it.

"The problem with Bob is that he thinks he is five times cleverer than anyone else, when in fact he is only two times as clever," muses one senior scientist who has experienced May at close hand on the cliquey science and higher education policy-making circuit.

May is indeed a hard act to follow - in many ways perfectly suited to the job. The government's scientific adviser must have that unusual combination of both academic ability and political acumen.

Whatever their particular expertise, they must also become a true polymath: writing reviews on the complex scientific issues of the day, from human cloning to the safety of mobile phones. They must want to relinquish an established academic life to become the focus of all the country's unease and hostility towards scientific developments and their impact on our lives.

"There are not many people with all those characteristics who government would accept and who would actually want the job," says Dr Peter Cotgreave, director of the Save British Science lobby group.

May, a straight-talking Australian, whose early scientific career - working out the mathematics of extinction - took off in the States, has been a hit with civil servants, ministers, scientists and journalists alike. In many ways he is the very embodiment of un-Britishness, and yet, through force of intellect and personality, he quickly gained respect among the stiff-upper-lipped mandarins within Whitehall. Anyone who has heard him enthuse about tutorials on scientific issues with Tony Blair and a few advisers from the number 10 policy unit will know just how much he warmed to the role.

But it wasn't always like this: when May first took up the post in 1995, many suggested that he didn't have the political nous to prosper in the territorial battles within Whitehall. The scientific adviser has a particularly awkward position within government: acting as civil servant, with all the constraints that entails, on the one hand, but also needing to be, and to be seen as, an independent expert voice.

The dual role is symbolised by the two offices May has come to use in the job - one in the Cabinet Office, representing his role as adviser to the prime minister, the other in the Office of Science and Technology, the department of which he is nominally in charge.

From this small corner of Whitehall, and without any real financial clout, the adviser tries to influence spending on research and development in all government departments, from defence to the environment to fisheries and food. It is a tough challenge, and May has openly conceded that one of his failures has been to prevent research budget cuts at the Ministry of Defence.

Among the three central accomplishments May cites during his time as adviser is his now-renowned statistical analyses of science publications and research spending. These transformed an arcane topic into a widely used source for comparing the research performance of the UK with that of other countries.

When evidence-based policy was all the rage within Whitehall, May's conclusions kept re-emerging in ministerial speeches. But most important of all, the studies finally broke the circular discussions over research spending with Treasury officials, who kept coming back to ask for evidence that the money was being well used.

The statistics showed that the UK was more cost-effective in its science effort than any other country in the world. May has played his part in the renaissance of science within the heart of government, which has seen it emerge as a priority in the last two spending reviews.

Another major success listed by May is the recent government white paper on science and innovation, the seeds of which were planted during May's brief but close relationship with Peter Mandelson, during his short spell as trade and industry secretary. Mandelson, like the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is convinced that the new high-tech businesses are the future powerhouses of the economy.

May also mentions the guidelines for scientific advice now used throughout Whitehall, when departments are making important policy and regulatory decisions. The principles have since been taken up by a number of other Western governments.

Unsurprisingly, the harder times during May's five-year tenure - "interesting moments when I was on steep learning curves" - relate to the series of scientific scares that have plagued the government and blackened the image of science among the general public.

There have been times when his frankness may have flared, rather than subdued, the flames of controversy. He described Arpad Pusztai's research suggesting that genetically modified potatoes damaged rats as "garbage". The leaders of the Soil Association, representing organic farmers, were labelled "ayatollahs" after they questioned the safety of GM foods. And he said there was "not much of a case" for the government's beef-on-the-bone ban.

He has also been on the receiving end of some embarrassing leaks. In a letter to the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, May agreed that ministers should not allow GM crops to be released on to the market before 2003, apparently contradicting the government's policy to refuse demands from environmental pressure groups for a four-year ban.

Then there was the scrap with Rosie Boycott, editor of the Daily Express, after he reportedly described science coverage in the Daily Express and Daily Mail as "crap".

It has been a rocky ride. Yet trawling through press clips of May over the last five years, one gets a clear impression of the high regard in which he is held by journalists. "Honourable" and "admirable" are just two of the words used to describe him. He is a reporter's dream: plain-talking, accessible, with a great turn of phrase - the very antithesis of what most would envisage from a senior academic or scientist.

But May's most lasting impression may well be his contribution to the first tentative steps towards the democratisation of science.

Asked whether the government or scientific community could have done anything to prevent the BSE crisis, he has argued that it is difficult to identify any major mistakes: ministers and advisers simply acted on the best advice available to them at the time. But if there is a lesson that has been learnt, it is that science does not hold all the answers, he says, and ministers often have to make decisions when confronted with conflicting evidence.

This more open and pragmatic approach has been adopted during the recent debates over GM crops. May's latest review concerned the safety of GM foods. It did not conclude that GM foods were safe, but that there was no evidence at all that they were harmful. The report added: "Nothing can be absolutely certain in a field of rapid scientific and technological development."

There is also a growing realisation that science must be made more inclusive. May has backed proposals to set up a world body to police and monitor developments in biotechnology that would aim to find "a consensus among scientists round the world about what is acceptable and what is safe". This would act like the intergovernmental panel on climate change set up by the United Nations to advise all governments.

May often alludes to the surveys that have shattered the myth that the public's distaste of science was predicated on ignorance of the issues. They show in fact that people with greater knowledge of scientific issues are more likely to be resistant to some developments. It is a sobering thought for the largely discredited public understanding of science movement, which was borne of the presumption that scientists had a duty to enlighten the blind plebian masses. Now ministers are talking in terms of SUP - scientists understanding the public.

fields.bodyText: Applications are sought from scientists wanting to spend five years as a close adviser to the prime minister. Job requirements include having to appear on the Today programme at a moment's notice to stand up for the government or the scientific community and calm the nation down over any topic - from gaping ozone holes to genetically modified foods - when all other senior academics and officials appear to be suddenly unavailable for comment. The candidate must also be prepared to be grilled by the Treasury spending committee during Whitehall spending reviews - the equivalent of being interviewed by several John Humprhys at once. Salary: at least £115,000 a year. Not quite the job advert that was rushed out by senior mandarins at the Department of Trade and Industry a couple of months ago, when one official realised that Sir Robert May's term as the government's chief scientific adviser was fast coming to an end - but perhaps a more realistic synopsis of what will be expected of the new chief scientific adviser working in the modern era of the government's increasingly involved and intense relationship with the scientific world. Interviews have been completed, and an announcement is expected any day now of the scientific expert who faces the daunting task of following in the footsteps of Sir Bob. During the last five years, May has successfully managed one of the most pressurised posts in the country - perhaps only less pressurised than the England football coach or the prime ministership itself. May will now serve until the end of September, even though his contract officially terminates this month. It is now unthinkable for the government to be without its adviser ready to dissipate the next scientific crisis and placate the public and press. Among the usual suspects being bandied around as potential successors are Sir Tom Blundell, former chief of the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council, Dr Paul Nurse, director of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, Professor George Radda, head of the Medical Research Council, Sir Martin Rees, Astronomer Royal, and even Susan Greenfield, the Oxford University neurobiologist, friend of the Blairs and science populariser. A government official with a mischievous sense of humour told one particularly naive journalist that Carol Vorderman was in line for the position. But we can confirm that there is nothing in this scurrilous rumour: Carol is not about to hang up her Countdown boots just yet. So what will the major challenge be for his successor? May quips, "Following me." It is a typical Mayism: arrogant in the extreme, but not without a hint of truth to it. "The problem with Bob is that he thinks he is five times cleverer than anyone else, when in fact he is only two times as clever," muses one senior scientist who has experienced May at close hand on the cliquey science and higher education policy-making circuit. May is indeed a hard act to follow - in many ways perfectly suited to the job. The government's scientific adviser must have that unusual combination of both academic ability and political acumen. Whatever their particular expertise, they must also become a true polymath: writing reviews on the complex scientific issues of the day, from human cloning to the safety of mobile phones. They must want to relinquish an established academic life to become the focus of all the country's unease and hostility towards scientific developments and their impact on our lives. "There are not many people with all those characteristics who government would accept and who would actually want the job," says Dr Peter Cotgreave, director of the Save British Science lobby group. May, a straight-talking Australian, whose early scientific career - working out the mathematics of extinction - took off in the States, has been a hit with civil servants, ministers, scientists and journalists alike. In many ways he is the very embodiment of un-Britishness, and yet, through force of intellect and personality, he quickly gained respect among the stiff-upper-lipped mandarins within Whitehall. Anyone who has heard him enthuse about tutorials on scientific issues with Tony Blair and a few advisers from the number 10 policy unit will know just how much he warmed to the role. But it wasn't always like this: when May first took up the post in 1995, many suggested that he didn't have the political nous to prosper in the territorial battles within Whitehall. The scientific adviser has a particularly awkward position within government: acting as civil servant, with all the constraints that entails, on the one hand, but also needing to be, and to be seen as, an independent expert voice. The dual role is symbolised by the two offices May has come to use in the job - one in the Cabinet Office, representing his role as adviser to the prime minister, the other in the Office of Science and Technology, the department of which he is nominally in charge. From this small corner of Whitehall, and without any real financial clout, the adviser tries to influence spending on research and development in all government departments, from defence to the environment to fisheries and food. It is a tough challenge, and May has openly conceded that one of his failures has been to prevent research budget cuts at the Ministry of Defence. Among the three central accomplishments May cites during his time as adviser is his now-renowned statistical analyses of science publications and research spending. These transformed an arcane topic into a widely used source for comparing the research performance of the UK with that of other countries. When evidence-based policy was all the rage within Whitehall, May's conclusions kept re-emerging in ministerial speeches. But most important of all, the studies finally broke the circular discussions over research spending with Treasury officials, who kept coming back to ask for evidence that the money was being well used. The statistics showed that the UK was more cost-effective in its science effort than any other country in the world. May has played his part in the renaissance of science within the heart of government, which has seen it emerge as a priority in the last two spending reviews. Another major success listed by May is the recent government white paper on science and innovation, the seeds of which were planted during May's brief but close relationship with Peter Mandelson, during his short spell as trade and industry secretary. Mandelson, like the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is convinced that the new high-tech businesses are the future powerhouses of the economy. May also mentions the guidelines for scientific advice now used throughout Whitehall, when departments are making important policy and regulatory decisions. The principles have since been taken up by a number of other Western governments. Unsurprisingly, the harder times during May's five-year tenure - "interesting moments when I was on steep learning curves" - relate to the series of scientific scares that have plagued the government and blackened the image of science among the general public. There have been times when his frankness may have flared, rather than subdued, the flames of controversy. He described Arpad Pusztai's research suggesting that genetically modified potatoes damaged rats as "garbage". The leaders of the Soil Association, representing organic farmers, were labelled "ayatollahs" after they questioned the safety of GM foods. And he said there was "not much of a case" for the government's beef-on-the-bone ban. He has also been on the receiving end of some embarrassing leaks. In a letter to the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, May agreed that ministers should not allow GM crops to be released on to the market before 2003, apparently contradicting the government's policy to refuse demands from environmental pressure groups for a four-year ban. Then there was the scrap with Rosie Boycott, editor of the Daily Express, after he reportedly described science coverage in the Daily Express and Daily Mail as "crap". It has been a rocky ride. Yet trawling through press clips of May over the last five years, one gets a clear impression of the high regard in which he is held by journalists. "Honourable" and "admirable" are just two of the words used to describe him. He is a reporter's dream: plain-talking, accessible, with a great turn of phrase - the very antithesis of what most would envisage from a senior academic or scientist. But May's most lasting impression may well be his contribution to the first tentative steps towards the democratisation of science. Asked whether the government or scientific community could have done anything to prevent the BSE crisis, he has argued that it is difficult to identify any major mistakes: ministers and advisers simply acted on the best advice available to them at the time. But if there is a lesson that has been learnt, it is that science does not hold all the answers, he says, and ministers often have to make decisions when confronted with conflicting evidence. This more open and pragmatic approach has been adopted during the recent debates over GM crops. May's latest review concerned the safety of GM foods. It did not conclude that GM foods were safe, but that there was no evidence at all that they were harmful. The report added: "Nothing can be absolutely certain in a field of rapid scientific and technological development." There is also a growing realisation that science must be made more inclusive. May has backed proposals to set up a world body to police and monitor developments in biotechnology that would aim to find "a consensus among scientists round the world about what is acceptable and what is safe". This would act like the intergovernmental panel on climate change set up by the United Nations to advise all governments. May often alludes to the surveys that have shattered the myth that the public's distaste of science was predicated on ignorance of the issues. They show in fact that people with greater knowledge of scientific issues are more likely to be resistant to some developments. It is a sobering thought for the largely discredited public understanding of science movement, which was borne of the presumption that scientists had a duty to enlighten the blind plebian masses. Now ministers are talking in terms of SUP - scientists understanding the public.
